abstract: The Condition of Affairs at
lead_paragraph: The operations against Charleston leave us who are distant from the scene in a quandary which, while tantalizing, does not fail to be a little entertaining. We have very great faith in the skill, energy and resources of Gen. GILLMORE, and doubt not that he sees rifts of light through the clouds which are opaque to us. But we do not see what is to come next. Sumter lies a mass of ruins. Every gun in it is dismounted, and the erstwhile formidable fort is prostrate and helpless for a single offensive effort. It is now ten days since the Chief of Artillery reported "the destruction of the fort so far complete that it is to-day of no avail in the defence of the harbor of Charleston," and respectfully submitted his opinion that "a continuance of our fire is no longer necessary, as giving us no ends adequate for the consumption of our resources." And yet it has been so far a perfectly barren victory. We have not taken Sumter: our flag has not waved for a moment over the ruins which we have made. On the contrary, the symbol of the rebellion still flouts defiance there. The ruins we have made are the proof of our power; the rebel flag planted on those ruins is the proof of the limitations to our power and the challenge to what remains yet to be done. On the whole, it is a very curious pass to which things have come, and quite unlike anything we remember to have read of.

abstract: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- Whatever may be the precise value put upon Mr. FORREST's performances by the critical portion of the community, there is no doubt whatever that his periodical engagements in the Metropolis are looked forward to with much satisfaction by the public at large. The lieges receive him with unabated favor and applaud him to the echo. It seems to be quite unimportant that he never appears in a new part. The old parts are good enough, and hence Mr. FORREST has passed out of the hands of criticism. And it may be said, indeed, that life is not long enough nor is virtue a sufficient reward for the men who would sit through a sound of Mr. FORREST's impersonations with the intention of discriminating between the intensity of his passion to-day, and the vehemence of his age a year age The broom and the eleemosynary penny at a crossing were preferable. Yet it is certain that Mr. FORREST's style has mellowed with years, and that he is a better actor now than he ever was before. In a character like Richelieu (in which the gentleman made his rentree last night) the moderation of a s[???]ous and thoughtful maturity was very noticeable. The alternate flashes of mental and vital power that render the character of the Cardinal Duke so remarkable were seized with great strength, and portrayed with rare vividness. The role is a favorite one with Mr. FORREST, and we can easily imagine that he has bestowed upon it an amount of conscientious research and study. It is assuredly a vigorous and free performance. The best situations were heartily appreciated and applauded by the audience. Mr. FORREST's reception was in every way flattering. The leading characters were sustained by Mrs. J.H. ALLEN, Mr. L.R. SHEWALL and Mr. J. MCCULLOUGH. The lady was, as she always is, charming, graceful and attractive, but her voice seemed to be somewhat less melodious than usual. Mr. SHEWELL played with his customary spirit, and Mr. MCCULLOU[???]H displayed a propriety of gesture and voice, combined with an easy and natural delivery, that promise a brilliant career for so young an artist.

abstract: on Confederate Prospects
lead_paragraph: The Times publishes a letter signed M.F. MAURY, on the prospects of the Confederates, He asserts they were never brighter. The North, he points out, is fighting for conquest and makes the attack; the South is fighting to be let alone and acts on the defensive. The South, therefore, cannot stop the war, but the North can. The Union, the bond of which was voluntary fraternizing, cannot be restored by force of arms. The Union is gone -- neither party can subjugate the other -- and it follows that the war is not to be ended by the sword. Other agencies must be called into play. The war is becoming more and more unpopular in the North. New-York is threatening armed resistance to the Federal Government. New-York is becoming the champion of States' Rights, and to that extent is taking the Southern ground. There are, besides, dissensions in other quarters. Even now Mr. LINCOLN has to keep an armed force not only in New-York and Kentucky, but also in Ohio, Indiana, and other States. He is even now marching upon Iowa to put down there a cry of peace. He is likely to have occupation for all the recruits his conscription will give him in keeping down his own people. The writer concludes by saying that all we (the Confederates) have to do is to maintain the defensive, watch our chances, and strike whenever there is an opportunity for a good blow.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met yesterday. Mr. FROM[???]NT presented a preamble and resolutions in regard to the draft exemption ordinance. The former recites the course of the Common Council and also that of the Mayor and Comptroller, in conjunction with the Board of Supervisors, to establish an exemption fund for conscripts, and expresses surprise that the Mayor and Comptroller should consort with the Supervisors to effect that object, while they were cooperating with the Common Council to attain the same end. The preamble also intimates that the Mayor and Comptroller were discourteous the Common Council in closing their conference with them without excusing themselves from further consultation. The resolutions request the opinion of the Corporation Counsel as to the legality of the exemption ordinance passed by the Supervisors, and it it is legal, whether the Common Council and Supervisors can both act in relieving conscripts from the draft. The Board adjourned over till 2 o'clock this afternoon to receive the opinion asked for, after receiving and daying over a resolution by Mr. OTTIWELL, to give the Seventy-ninth regiment New-York Volunteers (Highlanders) a handsome regimental standard, inscribed with the names of the thirteen battles in which they have participated.

abstract: Later advices from Europe, received by the City of London, which arrived at this port yesterday, are interesting. She left Liverpool on the 19th, and Queenstown on the 20th ult. A decline ...
lead_paragraph: Later advices from Europe, received by the City of London, which arrived at this port yesterday, are interesting. She left Liverpool on the 19th, and Queenstown on the 20th ult. A decline of three per cent. had taken place in the rebel cotton loan, which was quoted at 29@27 discount. The pirate Florida had made her appearance in the Irish Channel, and was off Queenstown on the 18th, where she landed three passengers by a pilot-boat. These passengers were supposed to be rebel agents. A case arising out of agreements for freighting the steamers Lal[???]d and Peterhoff had come before the assizes at Croydon, in the course of which it was sufficiently proven that they were engaged in conveying contraband of war for the rebels. There appears to be no room for doubt that the Ar[???] MAXIMILIAN has accepted the [???] of Mexico. The French Government is sa[???] to have sent instructions to Mexico revoking the pressures relative to the sequestration of properly of those who have taken up arms against the French. A blockade is also ordered, to extend from the La[???]unes, ten leagues south of [???], to Campeachy. There is nothing definite regarding the Polish question, It is asserted, however, that the tone of the English and French [???]tes to Russia is thoroughly pacific. The London Morning Post suggests that in case the replay of Russia is again unfavorable, the P[???] be recognized as belligerents. The Liverpool cotton market was buoyant, and all qualities had advanced in price. The Breadstuffs market was quiet and steady. Provisions were market was quit and steady. Provisions were firm. Consols on the 20th closed at 93 1/[???]@93 1/4 for money.

abstract: The history of the Chicago, Alton and St. Louis Railroad has been a varied one from the date of its opening to the present time. Many have been the vicissitudes, which in its ten years operations, have come upon it, and now just as success has rewarded its now managers for then untiring energy and practical skill, and just as the long suffering stockholders were about to enjoy the luxury of a dividend, already declared, of [???] cent. on their shares, a civil tribunal puts forth the authority of the law, and managers and stockholders are compelled to wait yet a little longer. The first semi-annual dividend under the new arrangement was declared a few days ago, and was payable on the 25th inst. (yesterday.) Before, however, any payments, could have been made, Judge WILLIAMS, of the Circuit Court of this county, issued an injunction restraining the Company from paying this or any dividend, until a hearing could be had on a bill which had previously been filed by CORYDON WEED, [???] of this city, who alleges that he is a creditor of the road, and that his claim should be paid before any profits are divided. The facts, as stated in the bill, are briefly as follows:

lead_paragraph: A young man, aged about 23 years, named RICHARD MANUEL, was arrested on Sunday last, by Detective FARLEY, upon the charge of having stolen $16,511, in notes and bonds, from JAMES A. ROOSEVELT, of No. 94 Maiden-lane. The accused, it appears, was in the employ of ROOSEVELT, as a clerk, at the time the offence is alleged to have been committed, in November, 1861. The property consisted of California bonds, United States Treasury-notes and promissary notes, all of which had been deposited in the safe in Mr. ROSOEVELT's office, for safe keeping. The young clerk had charge of them, and also of the books of the establishment.

abstract: The Board of Enrollment of the Sixth District continued to hear and examine exemption claims during the day yesterday. The number of persons drafted in this District was 3,075. During the last six days that the Board has been in session notices have been issued to about 1,100 to present themselves before the Board, to prove themselves exempt or stand the draft. Thus far about 400 have responded to the notice. The time for those already notified expires on the 3d of September. The number who responded to the notice yesterday was 102, being a small increase on the previous days. Of there, 30 were exempted for physical disability; 15 for being over or under age; [???] for being non-residents of the Ward or District in which they were drafted; 5 for having widowed mothers or aged and infirm parents dependent on them for support, and 3 for being in the service on the 3d of March last. Sixteen presented claims for exemption on account of being foreigners; but all, except two, were laid over for further investigation. The number of foreigners who claim to have lived in this country for six, eight and ten years, and yet deny that they have ever declared their intentions or voted, is truly astonishing, and, If their statements are true, there is a large field yet unexplored for politicians who seek the foreign vote. The drafted men who were held for service yesterday numbered 15. Three paid their commutation of $300, and seven furnished substitutes. The result of the day's labor was that the Government got 22 soldiers and $900 in money. The persons who furnished substitutes were as follows:
lead_paragraph: The Board of Enrollment of the Sixth District continued to hear and examine exemption claims during the day yesterday. The number of persons drafted in this District was 3,075. During the last six days that the Board has been in session notices have been issued to about 1,100 to present themselves before the Board, to prove themselves exempt or stand the draft. Thus far about 400 have responded to the notice. The time for those already notified expires on the 3d of September. The number who responded to the notice yesterday was 102, being a small increase on the previous days. Of there, 30 were exempted for physical disability; 15 for being over or under age; [???] for being non-residents of the Ward or District in which they were drafted; 5 for having widowed mothers or aged and infirm parents dependent on them for support, and 3 for being in the service on the 3d of March last. Sixteen presented claims for exemption on account of being foreigners; but all, except two, were laid over for further investigation. abstract: -Many of the men whose names have been recently drafted in this City seem to have disappeared. A certain class of persons have had a manifest advantage over the rest of the community in the whole matter of the draft. In making the enrollment it was easy to obtain the names of all of our permanent and well-known citizens -- in short, of every one who had a place of residence or business among us. The omission of any such names would be a rare and accidental oversight. The difficulty which the enrolling officers encountered was in obtaining a list of that great class who form so considerable a portion of the population of all large cities, and particularly of this City -- men without families or visible property, laborers, adventurers, loafers, gamblers, and that body of men who make up what is called the floating population. No possible diligence could obtain the names of all these persons, and yet the great mass of them came within the letter and the spirit of the law under which this enrollment was made. They were between twenty and thirty-five years of age, with no one dependent upon them for support, and they were certainly able-bodied enough.

abstract: Yesterday the Brooklyn Navy-yard was the scene of an interesting and unusual occurrence. The second vessel constructed at this port, too large to fit in the regular ship-houses, has been commenced, and to-day her frame will begin to go up. The keel of the United States steamer Wambanogue, or the second Niagara as she is called, from the fact of the ship-house having proved too small for her, was laid in the presence of a large number of the employes of the yard and several officers. In the front and rear of the ship-house the gables have been taken away to enable the hull to protrude from the launching ways some distance toward the Lyceum. The vessel is to be built on whatever plan Mr. DELANO may see fit to adopt, the only requirement absolutely indispensable being speed. She will be over 3,000 tons burden, and some 360 feet long, having greater length than either the steam frigate Niagara or the Royal mail steamer Persia. The body of the ship is to be composed of the best live oak; the frame is to be fastened with extra braces, and every beam secured in the most substantial manner. Her width will be as great as circum stances will permit, but her depth will not probably be so great. She will resemble the Niagara, as that vessel appeared when she was first built, more than any other craft in the navy, although between both there will still be very important points of difference. The manner of arming the vessel will be the same as that adopted in all first-class frigates. She will have broadside guns protruding through porls in the usual manner. The rig is not yet decided on. Her guns will be of the heaviest calibre, and Capt. DRAYTON, the Ordnance Officer of the Navy-yard, intends to have as fine an armament ready for her as can be got up. It is in the engines that she will differ most from all our vessels, iron and wooden. Mr. DELANO is determined to ask for as powerful ones as he can get, and the Navy Department is partially bound to give them. The great strength and enduring qualities of the ship will render her able to stand the working of any machinery, no matter how powerful; and it is reasonable to suppose that she will have cylinders of as great a diameter as those of the iron-clad Puritan or Dictator. The Wambanogue is to be a sort of sister-ship to the Idaho, the vessel which Mr. GEORGE STEERS is to build on his own plan. In almost all respects, except the date of their commencement, they will differ materially, but their size and speed are expected to be about equa[???]

abstract: Union State Convention at Syracuse
lead_paragraph: This Convention, which assembles at Syracuse to-morrow, for the nomination of State officers, and the Young Men's Mass Convention, to follow it on the next day, will be occasions of great interest. On their spirit and action will greatly depend the redemption of the State, this fall, from the dishonor and injury it has sustained from the unfortunate result of last year's election.

abstract: CIRCULATING INCENDIARY HANDBILLS OPPOSED TO THE DRAFT. -- HENRY J. CHILDS, who was arrested last week for circulating incendiary handbills headed "Sons of Liberty," tending to encourage resistance to the draft, had a preliminary examination yesterday before United States Commissioner OSBORN. District-Attorney E.D. SMITH appeared for the Government and G.W. MORTON, Esq., for the accused. It was proved that CHILDS hired Mr. DICKSON, of No. [???] Tryon-row, to print the handbills and engaged a man to post them around the City. The number printed was 2,000, but a small portion of which had been circulated when the offender was arrested. At the close of the examination the prisoner was committed by Commissioner OSBORN for trial. CHILDS is an Englishman about 50 years of age.

abstract: Recruiting the way to peace
lead_paragraph: Gen. MEADE, in the course of his very admirable speech, which we gave yesterday, said: "I have to request of you, gentlemen, who are in civil life, that, when you return home, you will spare no efforts to make the people understand that all we want are men to fill up our ranks. Send these to us. Give us the numbers, and the war will soon be concluded. I think the rebels are now satisfied that their struggle is only a matter of time, as we have the force on our side, and that as soon as they see that we are bringing out that force in earnest they will yield."

abstract: The draft in the First Congressional District was resumed yesterday morning at 9 o'clock, by proceeding with the Second Sub-District or Suffolk County, which comprises the whole of the eastern portion of Long Island. The result of the counting of the ballots, which occupied about half an hour was 4,024, out of which were to be drawn the requisite ...
lead_paragraph: The draft in the First Congressional District was resumed yesterday morning at 9 o'clock, by proceeding with the Second Sub-District or Suffolk County, which comprises the whole of the eastern portion of Long Island. The result of the counting of the ballots, which occupied about half an hour was 4,024, out of which were to be drawn the requisite quota of the county, 1,120. No changes were made in the police or military forces on duty. The drawing for this Sub-District was completed at 5 o'clock P.M. Among those drafted were, DANL. H. OSBORN, Sheriff of the county; the Baptist and Methodist Clergymen of Greenport; JAS. M. OAKLEY, (the man turning the wheel,) of Coram, aged 23 years; and the only son at home of Hon. EDWIN H. SMITH of Smithtown, late member of Congress, To-day, me Provost-Marshal will proceed to draft the quota for Queens County, which consist of the middle portion of Long Island. The following is a correct list of those drafted yesterday:

abstract: Maximilian's acceptance of the throne; Palmerston, Lord, and the Mexican Invasion
snippet: Maximilian's acceptance of the throne; Palmerston, Lord, and the Mexican Invasion
lead_paragraph: It is at last officially stated that the Austrian Archduke MAXIMILIAN has definitively accepted the throne of Mexico for himself and his descendants. This announcement takes no American by surprise, for it has long been perfectly manifest that there could be no other sequel. Every French act in Mexico has betokened a systematic carrying out of a programme thoroughly settled in advance. Even so long ago as when the French Emperor put forward the Jecker claims as his pretext for invading Mexico to secure indemnity, it was morally certain that his real object was the establishment of a throne; and that necessarily involved a previous selection of some fit person to occupy it.

abstract: It seems  that the President has determined to fill the Cadetships at West Point that are left vacant by the operation of the rebellion by the appointment of deserving young men from the army.
lead_paragraph: -- It seems that the President has determined to fill the Cadetships at West Point that are left vacant by the operation of the rebellion by the appointment of deserving young men from the army. Gen. GRANT has received orders from Washington to send in the names of soldiers in his army who are of the proper age and qualified for the position; and examinations of candidates are being made by Gen. SHERMAN. This is an excellent idea. Those who are chosen will combine every element of success, as they will be selected solely for their ability, and without regard to political effect. The young Cadets now at West Point also will have comrades who have been in actual battle, and have enjoyed the baptism of fire. Its effect upon the army will be excellent, and its effect upon West Point will be to elevate still higher its character and spirit. There is no scarcity of proper material in the ranks of our army; even that severe schoolman, Gen. SHERMAN, reports that there is a surprising number of young men qualified for the Cadetships.

abstract: There are a number of things which have been either solemnly promised us ever since the war began, and are still not forthcoming, or which, after we had enjoyed them for a brief period, have mysteriously disappeared, to which we think it is but right the attention of the public should be called. We should like to know, in the first place, what has come of that army that was to be raised in the North to light the battles of the South, whenever the war broke out, and which a Mozart Hall politician offered to raise and lead himself on receipt of $100. Where did it march to? Who saw it going off, and what has been its fate? Is it not extraordinary that in a country so saturated with publicity as this, a work such as that was, or was to be, should have vanished into obscurity without as much as furnishing an "item" to a newspaper?

abstract: We  have not for some time had news of the precise location of the army of Gen. LEE, but our special telegram this morning enables us to fix its general outline. It is not established at any one point, but covers a great space of country being scattered from the line of the ...
lead_paragraph: -- We have not for some time had news of the precise location of the army of Gen. LEE, but our special telegram this morning enables us to fix its general outline. It is not established at any one point, but covers a great space of country -- being scattered from the line of the Blue Ridge on the west to Fort Royal, upon the Rappahannock, on the east, and thence south as far as the line of the Virginia Central Railroad. EWELL has the left, LONGSTREET the right, and A.P. HILL the centre, while a North Carolina brigade occupies Fredericks-burgh, and a brigade of cavalry has moved into the Shenandoah Valley, and LEE himself is in Richmond. The object of thus scattering the rebel army is to facilitate the obtaining of subsistence. It would appear from this that LEE has no intention of undertaking any offensive operation, unless, perhaps, some raids of cavalry. His army will, doubtless, remain where it is until bad weather comes on and makes movement impracticable, after which Winter quarters will be the order of the time. Considering how his army is planted, we should think it furnished excellent opportunity for some operations on the part of our cavalry.

abstract: The annual reopening of the Mercantile Library, which took place at Clinton Hall, last evening, furnished the occasion for another of those pleasant reunions that have so often lent a charm to the progress of that popular and useful Institution. The Mercantile Library Association has now been in existence forty-two years, and however sanguine may have been the hopes of its liberal and enlightened founders, they have been more than realized by the success that has attended its career. The library numbers at present nearly 70,000 volumes, comprising the best miscellaneous collection of books for general reading to be found in this country. Its reading-room is unsurpassed by any in the world, containing a larger number of newspapers, magazines, reviews, &c., both of this country and Europe, than can be found in any reading-room extant. During the last two weeks in which the library has been closed, the rooms have been thoroughly cleaned and painted, a large number of new books have been added, and the entire establishment presents an air of neatness, elegance, and classic repose that cannot fail to charm the student and the man of leisure.

It is said to occupy the country from the line of the Blue Ridge on the west to Port Royal, on the Rappahannock River below Fredericksburgh, on the east. EWELL is believed to command the left, A.P. HILL the centre, and LONGSTREET the right. Stirring news may be expected soon from the Rappahannock, as an expedition has been fitted out to recapture the gunboats Reliance and Satellite, now in possession of the rebels at Port Royal.

abstract: The steamship Africa, which arrived at Halifax yesterday, brings advices from Europe, three days later. She left Liverpool on the 22d, and Queenstown on the 23d of August. The news is interesting. The United States Consul at Frankfort had displayed the Mexican flag. An explanation of this is given in the Europa, published in that city, which states that President LINCOLN has authorized the representation of Mexico in European countries by United States agents.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Africa, which arrived at Halifax yesterday, brings advices from Europe, three days later. She left Liverpool on the 22d, and Queenstown on the 23d of August. The news is interesting. The United States Consul at Frankfort had displayed the Mexican flag. An explanation of this is given in the Europa, published in that city, which states that President LINCOLN has authorized the representation of Mexico in European countries by United States agents. The London Times publishes the official correspondence between our Government and Great Britain regarding interference with the Bermuda trade. The closing letter is from Earl RUSSELL to Lord LYONS, dated the 18th of July, in which the latter is instructed to address a fresh remonstrance to our Government -- a previous one having failed of the desired effect. Nothing more was known of the movements of the pirate Florida. A report was current that the object of her visit was to take on board Mr. MASON, the rebel Envoy to England, and convey him home. The rebel cotton loan, on the 21st. realized one per cent. In France, an important decree has been published condemnatory of the letters of the Bishops on the subject of elections, and declaring them an abuse of ecclesiastical authority. Polish affairs appear to be without change. Nothing relative to the presentation of the notes of the three Powers to Russia had transpired. The King of Prussia still declined to be present at the Congress of the German Princes. Later news from India and China is interesting. The Chinese Imperialists had attacked Nanking, and had captured the outworks. The Japanese had paid the indemnity demanded by England, and the Nikadado had issued orders to expel all foreigners, and to close the Japanese ports. The great earthquake at Marita is said to have caused a loss of 540,000.000. The body of Lord CLYDE had been deposited in Westminster Abbey, with appropriate ceremonies. The Liverpool Cotton market is reported buoyant, with higher prices. Breadstuffs were generally tending downward, and Provisions were quiet. Consols were quoted at 93 1/8@93 1/4 for money.

abstract: Tribune on its Army News and the Rochester Union; On the TIMES' Army News
snippet: Tribune on its Army News and the Rochester Union; On the TIMES' Army News
lead_paragraph: -- The Tribune make some pertinent remarks upon an impudent sentence of the Rochester Union of Tuesday last, which said that the "NEW-YORK TIMES pretended to have information which left no doubt that ROSECRANS was moving." Before giving the Tribune's comments we may say that the Rochester paper was quite unhappy in its selection of an instance or an occasion upon which to throw doubt concerning the authenticity or reliability of the information for which we vouched. It was on the 22d of August that we made the exclusive and positive announcement, received by special advices from the Army of the Cumberland, that Gen. ROSECRANS had left his old camping ground near Tullahoma, and was advancing with his entire army upon Chattanooga; and it was only three days afterward, or the very day that the Rochester paper made the above remark, that the announcement was made through a telegram, which was published all over the country, and we suppose in the Rochester Union, that ROSECRANS' advance had actually arrived at Chattanooga, and was shelling it, to which was added the news two days ago, that the whole Army of the Cumberland, with Gen. ROSECRANS at its head, had crossed the Tennessee River. In every detail the news, which the Rochester Union borrowed from us, but pretended to doubt, has been confirmed by subsequent facts. We advise such journals as are published outside of this City, and which find it necessary to copy the greater part of their matter from the Metropolitan Press, to avoid, at the same time, insulting their benefactors, who, at a heavy cost, furnish them the news with which they cheaply fill their columns. The following are the Tribune's remarks, which, we may say, are entirely voluntary on its part:

abstract: We are therefore, in most instances, precluded from exercising our skill and knowledge to benefit our patients; on the other hand, the confidence of the public is so much abused by a class of self-extolling practitioners, who pretend to have discovered infallible means of curing diseases such as we have described, that innumerable difficulties surround the subject. Specifics for all the ills of life have been discovered daily and hourly; and if the public Press is to be taken as our guide -- for not a sheet issues from the Press but amongst the advertisements will be found the bold assertion of some loud proclaimer of his power -- unguents, liniments lotions and injections are all brought before the astonished world as possessing infallible power for curing the deaf. There is necromancy, witchcraft and marvelous power in everything he propounds. He has never been known to fail, according to his own assertion; and what chance has he who has devoted his life to inquiry, has honestly to confess that the deviations of nature surpass his expectations, that her ways are often Inscrutable, and all he can do is to study, to learn, and to attempt to cure, without professing that every malady is subjected to his superior skill?

abstract: This Committee were in session yesterday, as advertised, at No. 73 Duane-street. lead_paragraph: This Committee were in session yesterday, as advertised, at No. 73 Duane-street. The printed certificates and affidavits for indigent drafted persons were ready for use, out those for the firemen, militiamen and policemen will not be ready till to-day. The applicants for aid of the Committee were not numerous, and nearly all of them had not yet passed the necessary medical examination and been accepted for service by the Enrolling Boards of their respective Districts. Five drafted persons having families to support, and who had passed examination and been accepted, made oath to these facts, and also that they were in indigent circumstances, and had been unable to procure substitutes. Upon these statements and affidavits, certificates will be awarded them for presentation to the Comptroller, who will attend to the payment of their commutation.

abstract: Those who were in the habit of perusing Copperheaded newspapers and speeches during the dark days of last Winter may remember that the things which afforded them most delight, and on which they were never tired of dwelling, was the alleged inability of the Government to raise any more men, and the general reluctance to volunteer. They contrasted the general enthusiasm of 1861 with the general apathy of 1862, and asked with scornful triumph to what was the change owing, except to the widespread disgust caused by the Anti-Slavery policy of the Government. The "900,000 men," whose appearance on the scene as soon as the Emancipation Proclamation was issued, had been promised by Mr. GREELEY in a moment of poetic exultation, furnished a constant subject for taunts and sneers, and jokes more or less ponderous. The future was, of course, doubtful, and many unexpected things might happen, hut of one thing the public were requested to rest assured, and that was that there could not be 10,000 men more in all the loyal States induced for either love or money to enter the National army to carry out the policy which had been traced out in the Proclamation and the Confiscation act. The only hope there was of being able to carry on the war at all lay, we were told, in a return to the programme traced out in the President's Message and the resolutions of Congress, which at the very outset limited the object of the war to the restoration of the status quo.

They contrasted the general enthusiasm of 1861 with the general apathy of 1862, and asked with scornful triumph to what was the change owing, except to the widespread disgust caused by the Anti-Slavery policy of the Government. The "900,000 men," whose appearance on the scene as soon as the Emancipation Proclamation was issued, had been promised by Mr. GREELEY in a moment of poetic exultation, furnished a constant subject for taunts and sneers, and jokes more or less ponderous. The future was, of course, doubtful, and many unexpected things might happen, hut of one thing the public were requested to rest assured, and that was that there could not be 10,000 men more in all the loyal States induced for either love or money to enter the National army to carry out the policy which had been traced out in the Proclamation and the Confiscation act. The only hope there was of being able to carry on the war at all lay, we were told, in a return to the programme traced out in the President's Message and the resolutions of Congress, which at the very outset limited the object of the war to the restoration of the status quo.

abstract: The London Times Account
lead_paragraph: The letter of the Southern correspondent of the London Times, describing the battle of Gettysburgh, does not perhaps contain more misstatements than was to be expected, but it certainly contains some which are too great to be passed over in silence. First and greatest is the statement that "both armies have drawn off terribly shattered from the battle-field," and that the Federal army drew off "because it feared its inability even upon the vantage ground to repel another attack." This is utterly untrue. Our army never "drew off" from the battle-field of Gettysburgh. At the close of the struggle on Friday, July 3, our army held the field and our pickets were advanced. On Saturday, according to another statement of this same correspondent, both armies staid in position, and "the big guns frowned at each other in angry silence." On that night the rebels moved off. On the next morning our forces went forward, occupied the earthworks which the rebels had built, and then turned in pursuit of their retreating forces. So far from fearing an attack upon our ground, another day would have seen our army taking the offensive; and this LEE knew, and he prudently retreated beforehand.

abstract: -Our New-  Orleans correspondent gave a vivid account the other day of a grand demonstration in honor of Maj.-Gen. BANKS, that was lately made in the City of New-Orleans. It was not by his own soldiers, nor by office-holders, nor by contractors, but by the public schools and school-children of the Crescent city. The enthusiasm among the young Southern folks was wonderful, and only reached its climax, according to our correspondent,...
lead_paragraph: -- Our New-Orleans correspondent gave a vivid account the other day of a grand demonstration in honor of Maj.-Gen. BANKS, that was lately made in the City of New-Orleans. It was not by his own soldiers, nor by office-holders, nor by contractors, but by the public schools and school-children of the Crescent city. The enthusiasm among the young Southern folks was wonderful, and only reached its climax, according to our correspondent, "when the entire mass of little fairies, as if by some preconcerted plot, and disdaining all restraint, clustered around the General like so many swarming bees around honey, and commenced fairly smothering him with kisses! It seems as if he never could get away again from that stormy little ocean of rosebuds and lilies."

abstract: The session of the Union State Convention commenced yesterday forenoon at 11 o'clock. Judge Low, Chairman of the State Committee, called the Convention to order. There being some differences of opinion among the delegates as to the proper mode of organization, the Convention took a recess until 2 o'clock P.M., with a view to more harmonious action. Upon reassembling, WARD HUNT, of Oneida County, was chosen temporary Chairman.
lead_paragraph: The session of the Union State Convention commenced yesterday forenoon at 11 o'clock. Judge Low, Chairman of the State Committee, called the Convention to order. There being some differences of opinion among the delegates as to the proper mode of organization, the Convention took a recess until 2 o'clock P.M., with a view to more harmonious action. Upon reassembling, WARD HUNT, of Oneida County, was chosen temporary Chairman. Committees on Contested Seats and Permanent Organization were then chosen, and the Convention took a further recess until 5 o'clock. During the evening session the permanent organization was effected without difficulty -- the Committee reporting the name of ABRAHAM WAKEMAN for President, with the requisite number of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries. Mr. WAKEMAN, On taxing the chair, made a pertinent and patriotic address. The nominations for the State Ticket were made vira voce, and are as follows:

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- Mr. JOHN BROUGHAM -- lost to sight though to memory dear -- loses no chance of communicating with his old admirers on this side of the Atlantic. Every artist who visits Europe comes back with a play from his pen, and as all the theatres in New-York are "star" theatres (with the exception of the respective establishments of Wallack and Barnum) it is almost a mathematical certainty that every play written by Mr. BROUGHAM will, at some time or other, find its way to the Metropolitan stage. It may be stated, fondly but sadly, that they are not always good. Lately, however, he has given us the "Duke's Motto," and last but not least a dramatic version of Miss BRADDON's well-known novel called "Lady Audley's Secret." The latter was produced on Tuesday night at the Winter Garden, for the double purpose of giving that admirable actress, Mrs. D.P. BOWERS, a new role, and of introducing a spectral illusion. Both these meritorious ends were accomplished in a satisfactory manner. The lady gave a vivid and powerful interpretation of Miss BRADDON's heroine, and the Ghost behaved with propriety. It is hardly necessary to say more, except that Mr. L.P. BARRETT, Mr. DAVENPORT, Mr. NORTON, and other members of this company contributed to the success of the evening, and that the " Mystery of Audley Court will be repeated until further notice.

abstract: Letter on the Confederacy
lead_paragraph: -- The last ditch of the rebels is not to be in the South, but in the North, probably in New-York, most likely in Second-avenue. In other words, after they have been defeated, and have reached the last ditch on their own soil, they still look for aid and the construction of another ditch by their friends in the Northern States. Their hopeful prospect in this line is now the burden of the rebel song on both sides of the sea. It is the North which is to rush to their assistance in the final moment; it is the "mudsills" which are to sustain the Confederacy; it is the "small-fisted farmers" who are to ply the rebellious spade; it is the "greasy mechanics" who are to mend up the cracked Confederacy. It is in this view of the case that the scientific and political quack, M.F. MAURY, writes to the London Times that the prospects of the Confederates were never brighter than now. The brightness which he beholds is exclusively in the Northern heaven. "New-York is threatening armed resistance to the Federal Government; it is taking Southern ground." "Mr. LINCOLN has to keep an armed force not only in New York and Kentucky, but also in Ohio, Indiana, and other States." "He is even now marching upon Iowa." "He is likely to have occupation for all the recruits his conscription will give him in keeping down his own people," -- and so on.

abstract: President LINCOLN's letter to the Springfield Convention has all his characteristic solidity of sense and aptness of expression. It hits, as his written efforts always do, the very heart of his subject. Its contrast in downright directness of sentiment and style with many of the missives that used to be sent from the White House, in the days when glittering generalities were thought the only courtly language, is odd enough; but "plain people," who make up, in fact, the real people, like ABRAHAM LINCOLN none the less for this ingenuous freedom.

abstract: The news from the expedition which has recently penetrated Arkansas under command of Gen. STEELE, is important. Advices from Gen. STEELE, to the 26th ult., state that an advance, under Gen. DAVIDSON had encountered and defeated MARMADUKE's cavalry, about 3,000 strong, and driven them in utter route from Barnsville. Later advices, by way of Pilot Knob, state that PRICE's forces were driven across the Arkansas on the 29th, and that the rebels were in full retreat. Our forces are, probably, by this time in possession of Little Rock.

abstract: THE RECENT ATTACK UPON A NEGRO's HOUSE. -- The colored man, WILLIAM JACKSON, who was so brutally assaulted at his residence in Stewart's alley, on Sunday morning, by some five or six persons, died of his injuries at the City Hospital yesterday morning. His skull had been completely smashed in with a paving-stone, which was thrown at him as he came to the door to see what the trouble was. An investigation into the circumstances will be made thus afternoon by Coroner NORRIS. JOHN H. WALKER, arrested on the charge of being implicated in the assault, was discharged from custody yesterday by the Coroner, there being no evidence to identify him as one of the party. The three others arrested are in jail.

abstract: In this District the number of persons examined yesterday and the day before was 128, of whom 11 furnished substitutes; 1 commuted by paying $300; 6 were exempt for alienage; 31 for disability; 19 for over-age; 1 for under-age; 8 for non-residence; 5 for having widowed mothers dependent on them for support; and 1 for being now in the service; 37 were adjourned over for further hearing, most of whom claimed to be aliens: 8 were held for service, and were generally allowed a week's furlough. One or two Copperhead papers, whose sole business appears to be to endeavor to excite odium against everything except Slavery and Seymour Democracy, have tried to find fault with the way in which Capt. ERAHARDT conducts the examinations in this District, alleging that it is a secret affair, &c., &c. This is an atrocious libel. In none of the Districts is more pains taken to accommodate the Press than in the Fourth District, The accommodations are no limited that not more than two reporters can be present at a time during the examinations; but after they are through, all are allowed access to the records, and the recording clerk spends from half to three-quarters of an hour every day after his duties are over is assisting the reporters in their work.

abstract: A Stevenson, Ala., correspondent of the Cincinnati Gazette writes, upon the authority of Union citizens of Alabama and Tennessee, that VALLANDIGHAM while in the South, repeatedly exhorted the rebels to hold on to Vicksburgh, declaring that the success of his party in Ohio depended altogether on the ability of the rebel Government to baffle the Union armies besieging that place. The evidence of this fact the Gazette writer declares to be indisputable.

abstract: Institute; 35th annual fair
lead_paragraph: The thirty-fifth annual exhibition of the American Institute opened last evening, at the Academy of Music, under the must favorable auspices, and bids fair to become, ere its close, one of the most successful which the Institute has yet produced. It was predicted that owing to the disturbances of the country, a want of industrial enterprise would be felt and the Fair, as compared with those of past years, would prove a failure. Such has not been the case manufacturers and inventors have been as prolific as ever before, and American art, industry and science still evince their proud superiority in this, their greatest annual display. The war has produced but one effect, to all appearance, the addition of military and naval goods and inventions to the [???]. As s[???]n last evening, the exhibition was in little more than a chaotic state. Only four hundred exhibitors had received their assignment of space, and brought their goods -- much crowding and want o[???] economy in [???]pace, many empty cases and uncovered walls were to be seen; but in two or three days four hundred more exhibitions will be represented, all the arrangements will be perfected, and we may then expect to see the fair recognized as it has been in former years, not only as a metropolitan, but a national pride. A catalogue of the articles; on exhibition will be prepared and issued on Monday next.

abstract: THAT TREASONABLE CANADIAN CORRESPONDENCE. -- As was to be expected, the New-York papers deny the existence of a treasonable correspondence, the object of which was to invite an invasion of Canada by the Lincoln dynasty, and in which certain persons in this country are implicated. This denial does not in the least shake our faith in the correctness of the main statement that such a correspondence has passed; and we are quite willing to await till the facts fully develop themselves, in order that it may be seen where the truth lies. When we made our first statement we had not heard any of the names of the conspirators mentioned, but since then rumor has been busy, in this city, in their identification. We forbear, however, to repeat the names freely mentioned upon the street. -- Toronto Leader, Aug. 31.

abstract: Journals of strong Anti-Slavery principles are springing up in all the cities of the South that are within the Union lines, and particularly in the Mississippi Valley. New-Orleans has two of them -- one in English, the other in French. Memphis has two. Nashville has two. Of course there are plenty of them in St. Louis, and they exist in all the chief towns of Missouri. Kentucky, as yet, has none of them, but they are spread largely over the State from the other side of the Ohio River. One is about to be started in the City of Vicksburgh, to be called the Union, the prospectus of which is now before us, and which announces that "it will advocate in the most solemn and earnest manner the entire and immediate extinction of the cause of all our present troubles and the curse of the South -- African Slavery." Nearly all the Press of Baltimore is Anti-Slavery, and in Wheeling at one extremity of Old Virginia, and Norfolk at the other, there are able Anti-Slavery Presses. The organ at the latter important point, the Norfolk Virginian, which is edited by the able and effective writer Dr. WM. PORTER RAY, is about to appear as a daily, with excellent support, fine prospects and steam presses. All these journals seem to have a good local patronage, and must exercise a powerful influence upon the public sentiment of the South. It is ridiculous to say they are supported by Government contractors, as every one who knows anything about the publishing of a daily newspaper well understands. It is a curious anomaly of the times, that while we thus find scores of journals in the chief cities of the South battling for freedom and the Union, they find their bitterest antagonists in the pro-slavery and semi-secession journals still existing in the North.

abstract: The Union State Convention at Syracuse, which closed its labors on Wednesday night, was followed yesterday by a Mass Convention of Loyal Young Men, which met at Wieting Hall at 11 o'clock in the forenoon. ELLIOT F. SHEPARD, of New-York, was selected as presiding officer. President LINCOLN'S letter was read, and received the most enthusiastic indorsement of the Convention.
lead_paragraph: The Union State Convention at Syracuse, which closed its labors on Wednesday night, was followed yesterday by a Mass Convention of Loyal Young Men, which met at Wieting Hall at 11 o'clock in the forenoon. ELLIOT F. SHEPARD, of New-York, was selected as presiding officer. President LINCOLN'S letter was read, and received the most enthusiastic indorsement of the Convention. The resolutions adopted fully indorse the war policy of the Administration, and declare that "the object of the war is not to reduce the inhabitants of the South to a state of vassalage, nor to hold them in the condition of a conquered people, but to preserve the nation and enforce the laws, and to secure a lasting peace," and that when these purposes are attained the insurgent States will be welcomed back into the Union. The resolutions also promise a hearty support to the nominees of the Union State Convention. A brief session was held in the afternoon, during which Hon. GERRIT SMITH and other gentlemen made patriotic addresses, after which the Convention adjourned sine die.

abstract: We are informed and believe that a meeting of the persons drafted in the City of Brooklyn, will be held to-night at the City Hall Park. The sentiments of those in charge are, as we ascertain from one of them, thoroughly loyal, and the purpose of the demonstration is by no means to oppose or interfere with the Government or its measures. Mr. JACOBS of the Express, Mr. MCCLUSKY OF the News, Mr. MCDERMOTT of the Eagle, and other well-known persons who are among the lucky ones, will probably address the meeting. The intention, we understand, is to excite a public sentiment which shall force the authorities, the Banks and monied institutions generally, to extend a helping hand to the people who are summoned to the stern realities of war. Mr. JACOBS of the Express makes the fair offer to Mr. T. TILTON of the Independent, that if he will literally shoulder his musket and comply with the requisition of the Government, he will do the same.

abstract: The Exemption Committee of the Board of Supervisors had a busy session yesterday, the number of applicants for relief being quite large. The Committee act cautiously, and give the needed relief only in cases where it is evidently deserved.

abstract: A few days ago a mongrel craft, called the Etta, arrived in this port from Nassau, with a lead of pineapples, which she discharged at a sock in Jersey City. By some means the United States District Attorney o Jersey, Mr. A.Q. KEASEEY, ascertained that the Etta was a [???] rebel privateer, and he yesterday field a [???] against her, and put her in charge of the United States authorities. The Etta was formerly a tugboat employed in this harbor. She went to the South Carolina coast in the employ of the Government and fell into the hands of the rebels, who [???] her out as a [???] named her the Retribution, and sent her out privateering. During her cruise she [???] in [???] several merchantmen, but getting out of condition, she was taken into that depot of rebel pirates, Nassau, where she was [???] as unseaworthy. She was then altered to her present condition and sold. The sale, however is [???] to have been bogus, and the probabilities are that the craft is now owned by rebels, who being unable longer to use her as a privateer, conclude to engage her in a little legitimate commerce with the Yankee mudsills. The pineapples that she brought to us are said to be Excellent, but as the Yankees are not yet ready to carry on an extended commerce with privateer men, the owners of the Etta will be required to establish their loyalty before she will be allowed to return for another cargo.

abstract: The return match between the above clubs was played on Wednesday and Thursday at Hoboken, and terminated in another victory for St. George, who played their professional cricketer, HARRY WRIGHT, in their Eleven. The Willow Club furnished an extraordinary "cosmopolitan" Eleven, consisting of Sharp, Higham, Hudson, Pearce, Hammond and Lindsey, of the New-York Club; Higham acting as wicketkeeper, and Captain for the Willows, as he always does for New-York, Hammond being also the professional of the Willow Club. They had also the services of Mr. Draper, of the Boston Club, of Massachusetts, and of Mr. Bainbridge, of the St. George's Club; consequently the few visitors on the ground had a good display of cricket on the part of some of the players from these various clubs, who are so well known that criticism is superfluous.

BANDMANN, the Anglo-German actor, whose success in the character of Shylock has provoked a silly statement from his agent that his impersonation of that part is a "wonder of the age," as if it were a feat on the trapeze, or an act of ventriloquism; Mr. DANIEL E. BANDMANN, whose success in the part we have named was complete and merited last season, commenced a new engagement at this house on Tuesday evening.

abstract: A soirco of the Seventy-first regiment detachment, stationed at High Bridge camp, came off yesterday afternoon at the camp grounds. It was given by Lieut. R. APPLEBY to many friends, as well as the members of Company H, to which he is attached, and in which Company G, stationed at the camp with Company H, were invited to participate. Lieut. APPLEBY placed the entire arrangements in the hands of Sergt. G.O. BRADY, who carried out the desirable object. The camp itself itself was a pattern of task. The tents were beautifully dressed with flowers and evergreens. The army and navy flags floated proudly from a tall pole which had been erected specially for the occasion. When dancing was over, a parade of all the men in camp took place, at which Col. TRAFFORD was present, and was loudly cheered, the whole invited party sat down to a splendid collation. After partaking of which the crowd began to disperse, but not without giving hearty cheers for Col. TRAFFORD, Capt. TURNER, Lieut. APPLEBY, and the other officers.

abstract: The Trotting match between these horses took place on Wednesday at the Fashion Course, Butler winning in three straight heats. Both horses were in fine condition, but the two first heats were very slow; ...
lead_paragraph: The Trotting match between these horses took place on Wednesday at the Fashion Course, Butler winning in three straight heats. Both horses were in fine condition, but the two first heats were very slow; the third heat compensated for the disappointment by being done in 2:23 1/2, with something to spare for Butler. About 2,000 persons were present, among whom were a moderate attendance of the fair sex in carriages, and a band of music discoursed sweet sounds to the great annoyance of the betting men.

abstract: Conrad Poppenhusen and Frederick Konig vs. Aaron Van Valkenburgh, Assignee of Frederick Muller. -- Plaintiffs, as judgment creditors, on behalf of themselves and some other creditors of the firm of Thorn & Muller, brought an action in the Supreme Court for a general accounting of the assignee of that firm. A similar action was brought by Ernest Richter in the Court of Common pleas. The plaintiffs in the action in the Supreme Court now come into the Court of Common Pleas, and pray that William Sinclair, the Receiver first appointed of the assigned property [???] Receiver of the whole property; that the [???] assigned property must be delivered to, vest in and remain under the control of Sinclair. The plaintiffs also pray that the appointment in the action in the Court of Common Pleas be vacated, and the Receiver pay the amount of plaintiffs' judgment to Poppenhausen and Konig. Decision was reserved. Robert Dodge for the motion, C. Bainbridge Smith, opposed.

abstract: Wednesday, Rear, Rear-Admiral FARRAGUT inspected the chief iron-clad vessels of war in course of construction in this neighborhood. He visited the Navy-yard early in the forenoon, and was shown the new mail corvette Miantonomah, which he examined minutely, inquiring into the arrangement of every department with critical curiosity. He also went on board his own flagship, the Hartford, which is now moored alongside the wharf, and spent some time there. Having remained for some hours at the Navy yard, he embarked on the steamer Vanderbilt for Greenpoint. He arrived at the Continental Works before noon, and was shown the iron-clad frigate Puritan, the Onondaga, and the new light draft vessel in course of construction. He was particularly struck with the magnitude of the Puritan, and prophesied that she would be a credit to the navy. He went on board the Onondaga, entered the turrets, went through the lower apartments of the vessel, and critically investigated everything connected with her hull, engines and turrets. This vessel is preparing rapidly fur sea, extra hands being put on her, and it is expected that she will be ready for service in two or three weeks. Admiral FARRAGUT seemed to like her very well, It is understood that the Admiral intents to Jersey City, Thirteenth-street, and Williamsburgh, for the purpose of personally examining the condition of the armored vessels at these places.

abstract: And Steele's Western Campaigns
lead_paragraph: We have two inland-armies of considerable strength operating at the present moment beyond the reach of the telegraphic wire, but whose footsteps and progress deserve to be watched with the deepest interest by the nation. We refer to the army under Gen. BURNSIDE in East Tennessee and the army under Gen. STEELE in Arkansas. Our latest news from both these armies is just ten days old, or up to the 26th of last month. At that date Gen. BURNSIDE's columns were filing over the mountain region of East Tennessee, at a point about forty miles west of Cumberland Gap, and were marching toward the town of Kingston, situated at the point formed by the junction of the Clinch and Tennessee rivers, and only a short distance from Knoxville and the line of the great East Tennessee and Virginia Railroad -- the "backbone" road, as it is called -- and which, when once reached, will give us an opportunity of literally cracking the rebellion's backbone. Gen. STEELE, operating in Arkansas, had marched from Helena on the Mississippi to the White River, which he crossed and struck directly for the Arkansas River and the Capital of the State, by way of Brownsville. The latter point, a dozen miles or more from Little Rock, he had reached, and had there a fight with MARMADUKE's cavalry, which were defeated and driven off. We suppose that by this time his army has arrived on the banks of the Arkansas; but as all the rebel forces in that region have been gathered and concentrated at Little Rock, under Gen. SMITH, or somebody else, it may be a little time before Gen. STEELE is fully prepared to offer them battle.
headline: {'main': 'Two Western Campaigns.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Two Western Campaigns.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- There is a remarkable absence of news from both the fields of active military operations -- from the army of Gen. GILMORE and the army of Gen. ROSECRANS. It is now a week since we had any direct intelligence from either the force operating against Charleston or the force operating against Chattanooga. The reason of this undoubtedly is that both are engaged in preliminary operations of great importance, in which the commanders feel the importance of secrecy and guardedness. Gen. GILLMORE has all army correspondents under strict surveillance, and Gen. ROSECRANS allows the transmission of nothing over the telegraph wires. The public, however, has long ago learned to be patient with these necessary restrictions; and although this policy prevents our being able to follow minutely the progress of operations, it will undoubtedly be best in the long run. The public must meanwhile possess its soul in patience and enliven its faith with hope.

abstract: In the case of MICHAEL BARRETT, arrested by Provost-Marshal NUGENT as a deserter, it will be recollected that Judge LEONARD of the Supreme Court last week issued a habeas corpus directing the Marshal to produce the body of the prisoner and that the Marshal made a return declining to produce the body, as his instructions from the War Department required him to hand the prisoner over to the military authorities for trial by Court-martial. The refusal la produce the prisoner was based on the want of jurisdiction of the State Courts, as set forth in the famous case of ABLEMAN vs. BOOTH. On Saturday last, Judge LEONARD decided that the Marshal must produce the body on Monday, or an attachment would issue against him for contempt. The body was not produced, and yesterday an attachment was issued. It is understood that Marshal NUGENT has concluded, under the advice of counsel, not to offer any resistance to the service of the attachment, but to allow himself to be arrested, when his counsel will apply to Judge BETTS, of the U.S. District Court, for a habeas corpus to take him out of the custody of the State authorities.

abstract: Our energetic City Inspector, Alderman B00LE, has conceived an idea of reform in our sanitary condition that was broached and discussed long ago, but which has never been pot In execution. It is the Abolition of slaughter-houses in the City, and their removal country ward. The notion of carrying out the reform and the framing of a practical plan for the purpose, are Mr. BOOLE's, it can hardly be doubted that he will speedily accomplish the good work. He proposes to extirpate the slaughter-houses and in their stead to adopt the Parisian abbatoir system, building an abbatoir on the outskirts of the east and west sides of the City, but not upon a scale so large us those of Paris. He has consulted the principal butchers and won their warm indorsement of his design, which he will embody in an ordinance soon to be presented to the Common Council. The two betiding and grounds necessary to be submitted for the two hundred and twenty-eight slaughter-houses now scattered through out the City, in their business capacity, it is estimated, will cost $260, 000 or $250,000 at the most, and the revenue which could be made derivable from them would make the investment a good one for the City. It would be a good thing to be rid of the slaughter houses, even at the highest figure he names, for the reestablishment of the slaughtering business elsewhere on sanitary and scientific principles.

abstract: Capt. BARTON, of the ship B.R. Milam, foundered at sea, makes the following report relative to the loss of his ship: Aug. 19, during a heavy blow from the east, found the ship leaking; sounded pumps and found three feet of water in the hold; kept both pumps continually going; at 7 A.M. sounded again; found six feet, it having gained three feet in an hour; hove deck load overboard; 9 A.M. found nine feet of water in the hold, ship rolling very deep; had no control of her with the wheel; ship under close-reefed topsails; 11 A.M., ship full of water; got our boats ready; ship settling very fast by the head; hove both anchors off the bows; wind light from N.E.; At daylight next day cairn; ship still settling fast; two feet of water on deck; latter part of night, deck breaking up, and cargo coining through the star board side; sea making a clean breach over her. At daylight 21st, a bark in sight to the westward steering for us. At 9 A.M., she came up, and proved to be the Br. bark Thebes, from Jamaica, pound to London, the Captain of which kindly took us on board, for which, I return my sincere thanks. Aug. 22, lat 43° lon. 47° 10[???], spoke the Swedish bark Minona, from Gottenberg for New-York, and myself and mate and steward were transferred to her, the remainder of the crew going to London in the Thebes.

abstract: State Convention, the
lead_paragraph: The delegates to this body did the work which they were sent to do, faithfully and well. They made good the call under which it was convoked. By the spirit of their discussions, the sentiments of their resolutions, and the selections of their candidates, they proved it to be literally and truly what it professed to be -- a Union State Convention. It was made up of men of widely varying party antecedents, and indeed of different shades of sentiment in respect to some of the minor topics of the present time; and yet it may be doubtful whether there ever was an assemblage of the kind in this State whose proceedings throughout exhibited greater harmony. This came simply from the fact that every man thoroughly understood the necessity of redeeming the State from its false position, and felt bound by every consideration of patriotism to act with exclusive reference to that end. There was no disposition to stand out on non-essentials, for the very good reason that there was genuine earnestness concerning the one grand essential. When people are devoted to one object, and are truly determined to succeed in it, they find little difficulty in pulling together.
headline: {'main': 'The Union State Convention', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Union State Convention', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: It has all along been apparent that it was the ignorance which prevailed at the South of the condition of the North, as well as that of all foreign countries, which made it so easy for the leaders to precipitate the Slave States into revolution. On these points, at least, the stump orators, who, according to ...
lead_paragraph: It has all along been apparent that it was the ignorance which prevailed at the South of the condition of the North, as well as that of all foreign countries, which made it so easy for the leaders to precipitate the Slave States into revolution. On these points, at least, the stump orators, who, according to Mr. JAMES BROOKS, constitute such an excellent substitute for books, and schools, and newspapers, failed to enlighten their pupils. The Yanceys and De Bows were consequently able to go on, year after year, painting those curious but effective pictures of "free society," over which free society has so often made merry, but which slave society has always valued as all but photographically accurate. And none of them was such a favorite, or worked so much mischief, as that which represented free society as horribly weak, and ready to fall to pieces at the touch of a strong master hand.

abstract: Assurances have reached Washington, from a distinguished officer of the Army of the Potomac, that Gen. LEE has given no evidence whatever of a purpose to move his forces. It is believed, on the contrary, that he is waiting the result of the operations of Gens. ROSECRANS, BURNSIDE and GILLMORE, and that, should they be successful, LEE will exert his influence in favor of peace.

abstract: The rebel  agent in England, MAURY, in his letter to the London Times, showing that the "prospects of the South were never brighter" than now, makes a remark of which we had a mention by telegraph, but which is so much more striking as given in full by himself, that we think it worth while to repeat it.
lead_paragraph: The rebel agent in England, MAURY, in his letter to the London Times, showing that the "prospects of the South were never brighter" than now, makes a remark of which we had a mention by telegraph, but which is so much more striking as given in full by himself, that we think it worth while to repeat it. He is speaking of the plans of the rebels, and their mode of operating in the North to "offset the tide of military reverses which in the first weeks of July ran so strong against the South;" and his words are: "Other agents have to be called into play. What are they? Let us inquire. They are divisions in the camp of the enemy, dissensions among the people of the North. There is already a peace party there. All the embarrassments with which that party can surround Mr. LINCOLN, and all the difficulties that it can throw in the way of the war party in the North, operate directly as so much aid and comfort to the South."

abstract: The Harbor Obstructions
lead_paragraph: The true nature of the obstructions of Charleston Harbor is the profoundest mystery of the war. What Admiral DAHLGREN may have been able to learn by boat reconnoissances, remains, of course, with himself. An item in to-day's dispatches states that a naval officer had gone up in a boat at night to within a short distance from the city and found no obstructions. This statement would not receive credence, even if its source were not, as it is, one we have learned to distrust.

abstract: When the British Government ostensibly withdrew from the coalition against Mexico, a year ago last March, it assigned as its reason a fear that there was a design to transform that republic into a monarchy, which it could not honestly abet. It now appears, by the Memorial Diplomatique, that the agreement between the French Emperor and the Archduke MAXIMILIAN was made in the October previous. The English landed their troops at Vera Cruz in the intervening January. Now, one of two things follows: Either the British Premier practiced duplicity in proposing to withdraw from the expedition for the reason assigned, or he was for five months hoodwinked by the French Emperor. Either he was a dissembler or a dupe.
lead_paragraph: When the British Government ostensibly withdrew from the coalition against Mexico, a year ago last March, it assigned as its reason a fear that there was a design to transform that republic into a monarchy, which it could not honestly abet. abstract: Bronson, Hon. Greene C.
lead_paragraph: The death of Hon. GREENE C. BRONSON, which occurred at Saratoga Springs on the night of Sept. 3, has already been announced. Judge BRONSON was widely known throughout the State and in this City, as an active politician, an able lawyer, and a man of unflinching integrity. He came from an old New-England family, and was admitted to the Bar, as an attorney-at-law in 1817. For twelve years he practiced his profession at Utica -- serving one term in the Assembly meanwhile -- when he removed to Albany, having been chosen Attorney General by the Legislature, which was then strongly favorable to JACKSON and VAN BUREN. In 1836, Gov. MAR??? appointed him a Judge of the Supreme Court of the State, and in 1845 Gov. WRIGHT named him Chief Justice of the same Court as Judge NELSON'S successor. On the adoption of the present State Constitution in 1846 he was elected one of the four Judges of the Court of Appeals and drew the four-year-term. He resigned this position a short time before the expiration of his term of office, and removed to this City in 1851. In 1853 President PIERCE appointed him Collector of the Port, but he held the office only a short, time, as his independent line of policy prevented his being made a party tool by those who hoped to use him. In 1859 Judge BRONSON was elected Corporation Counsel and continued to discharge the duties of that position until last January, when he retired to private life.

abstract: We have important news this morning from East Tennessee. Kingston was captured by Gen. BURNSIDE on the 2d inst., our forces meeting with little serious opposition. Part of a brigade from Gen. ROSECRANS' army entered the place simultaneously with Gen. BURNSIDE'S troops. The dispatch which brings us this information also announces that all East Tennessee, with the exception of the Chattanooga region, has been evacuated by the rebels, and is now free!

abstract: Vermont, the loyalty of
lead_paragraph: Nearly complete returns show that the Union candidate for Governor is elected by about 23,000 majority, that the State Senate is wholly Union, and that the House will show only seven Copperheads. This is a noble record. Vermont is one of the smallest States in the Union, and, by reason of its agricultural character, as well as its distance, has a slighter connection with the South than almost any other. Yet no State has furnished so many soldiers in proportion to its young men. None has treated its soldiers with such liberality; for it not only starts them with a complete outfit in every needed comfort and medicine, but has from the beginning engaged to give every man of them seven dollars a month during service, in addition to the Government pay. No soldiers have fought with greater bravery. A Vermont brigade held the key of the position at Gettysburgh, and did more than any other body of men to gain the triumph which decided the fate of the rebellion. To crown all we, now have this crushing defeat of Copperheadism at the ballot-box. Twenty-three thousand in Vermont against this vile pest is equivalent to a majority of three hundred thousand in New-York -- calculating with reference to the difference in population. When shall we come up to that mark? All honor, we say, to the sturdy little Green Mountain State.

abstract: Beauregard, Pierre Toutant and his boasts
snippet: Beauregard, Pierre Toutant and his boasts
lead_paragraph: We had a word to say letely about puffing rebel braggarts, showing how most of these heroes have been made out of very poor stuff; and again we have before us one of the most notable instances of the war. PIERRE TOUTANT BEAUREGARD, Lieutenant-General of the rebel army, was first introduced to the world's notice on the investment of Sumter and its few dozen men by seven thousand traitors in arms, commanded by that hero in person. At that period the Press was filled with wondrous tales of this marvelous genius. He was held up to the admiration of mankind as the condensation of heroism and skill, and we were bidden to be still and listen, and this unequaled, engineer would some Spring morning, devour Sumter for breakfast, take Washington immediately after dinner, and sup at the base of Bunker Hill. We waited, and soon the echo came back from the bombarded fort; the man had opened fire upon the hungry garrison with almost twenty times their weight of metal, and forced a surrender which he knew they would have been obliged to make within a couple of days from sheer starvation. In reward for all this, he received adulation that elevated him above the gods, and the Southern Press at once hailed him as the coming man who was to overrun the North and dictate terms to the mudsills from their own cities.
