abstract: The Maori War
lead_paragraph: England's third war against the Maori has been hopefully commenced. Gen. CAMERON, the present commander of the troops in NewZealand, is evidently a soldier who knows how to deal with the native strategists. Instead of taking the field, like his predecessor, at the head of an unwieldy force, and making his approaches to the strongholds of the enemy by the process of sap and siege, he has adopted the plan of subdividing his army into small detachments, which move from place to place with celerity, and carry the pahs by storm. The efficacy of this style of action was first put to the test on the morning of the 4th of June. After the massacre at Faranaki, the Maori had thrown up earthworks at Tataraimaka, and stationed a garrison two hundred strong there. To signalize the opening of the war, and to strike terror into the foe, Gen. CAMERON determined on the surprise and capture of this work. Accordingly, 650 men, with three pieces of artillery, were ordered to leave New-Plymouth on the night of the 3d, and to proceed to the accomplishment of the enterprise. An armed steamer was also ordered to sail up the Katikava River, on which the pah stood, and to cooperate with the land forces by shelling it from the shore. The result was such as might have been anticipated. Though the Maori made a stiff defence, they were speedily overpowered and driven from their stronghold, after losing forty of their chief warriors in the struggle. Such was the first blow struck by the British in the new Maorian war. It shows that Gen. CAMERON is the "right man in the right place," and that under his leadership the white troops are pretty sure to conquer. There is, however, nothing in the capture of a rude fort and a garrison of a couple of hundred half-armed savages, by thrice their number of disciplined soldiers, aided by a battery and a vessel equipped with Armstrong guns, about which to be at all vainglorious. Yet, owing to the many reverses which the British met with in the former war, their Press is quite jubilant over this unlooked-for success, and magnify it extravagantly. But were the achievement as important as it is insignificant, no glory could accrue from it.
headline: {'main': 'The Anglo-Maorian War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Anglo-Maorian War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Board of Councilmen met specially at noon yesterday, and passed the $3,000,000 exemption ordinance over the Mayor's veto by a unanimous vote, twenty-one members being present, and three Messrs. BRICE, Cook and JOYCE were recorded in the affirmative by permission of the Board, in pursuance of their request, made through Messrs. HAYES and BRANDON.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen met specially at noon yesterday, and passed the $3,000,000 exemption ordinance over the Mayor's veto by a unanimous vote, twenty-one members being present, and three -- Messrs. BRICE, COOK and JOYCE -- were recorded in the affirmative by permission of the Board, in pursuance of their request, made through Messrs. HAYES and BRANDON. There was no debate on the question. Mr. GROSS said talk was unnecessary -- the people understood the matter well. Mr. BRANDON explained his vote, saying that he had voted against the pledge to overrule the Mayor's veto, because he thought it was unnecessary to make the pledge; hut he had been in favor of the ordinance from the first. The Mayor sent in a message vetoing the resolution directing the Street Commissioner "to take such measures as may be necessary to cause the immediate removal of the artillery and cavalry from all the squares, parks and other public places be-longing to the City." The Mayor says the correspondence between Gov. SEYMOUR and Gen. Dix, recently published, demonstrates the necessity for the presence of the troops to insure the peaceful enforcement of the draft; that Gen. Dix proposed to leave this duly to the military power of the State, but the Governor refused, stating that "under no circumstances could the State authorities perform duties expressly confided to others." The Mayor continues: "Inasmuch, therefore, as the enforcement of the act, one of the supreme laws of the land, was left to others, we cannot fairly find fault with those others for their presence here, especially in view of the fact that they have saved our City from another disgraceful outbreak." The Mayor concludes by saying that "the necessity for the presence of the troops is hut temporary and will soon be past. So long as they are here, we have no other places so suitable for their accommodation as the public grounds which they now occupy." The Board adjourned to the 14th inst.

abstract: Floyd, J. B.. history of
lead_paragraph: If it were probable that the gallows would have received their due loyal well might unite with rebels in lamenting the death of John B. Floyd, which transpired at Abingdon, Va., on Aug. 26, according to the Richmond papers. For one whose name has received such frequent mention during the last two or three years the record of his earlier life is singularly barren and uninteresting. He was born in Virginia in 1805, graduated at South Carolina College, studied law, removed to Arkansas to practice, returned to Virginia, was elected to the Legislature in 1847 and 1849, was made Governor in the last named year, and again in 1855; but, although personally popular in his native State, he did nothing to make himself felt outside of it until he was fortunate enough to be chosen Presidential elector in 1856, when he voted for James Buchanan, -- a service for which he received ample compensation by an appointment to the Secretaryship of War. He availed himself of the advantages afforded by this high position to equip to the best of his ability with arms from the Government arsenals the rebels who were plotting to overthrow it, and for this treachery he was rewarded with a Brigadier-Generalship in the Confederate army. Possibly he helped to restore to the Government nearly as many arms as he robbed it of, for his career in Western Virginia was a constant series of failures, and he was instrumental in throwing Fort Donelson into Gen. Grant's hands, although, as every one will remember, he took good care to evacuate the position on his own account, leaving his troops to take care of themselves. This and his previous failures brought him into discredit with those whom he had turned traitor to assist, and for the last few months he has virtually been deprived of a command.

abstract: Through all the struggle which went on for years between civilization and barbarism for the possession of this land of ours, there was no part of the country where the contest was fiercer than in Kentucky. It was there that barbarism made its most determined stand, and the terrible scars of the conflict long remained indelibly impressed upon the hearts and souls of her people.
lead_paragraph: Through all the struggle which went on for years between civilization and barbarism for the possession of this land of ours, there was no part of the country where the contest was fiercer than in Kentucky. It was there that barbarism made its most determined stand, and the terrible scars of the conflict long remained indelibly impressed upon the hearts and souls of her people. The name of "The Dark and Bloody Ground" which is left written upon her plains and valleys was to the children of this and of the past generation, a name associated with whatever of horror, of savage cruelty, of bloodthirsty destruction can characterize Indian warfare. It sent a thrill over their young hearts, a thrill of terror that such things should have ever been, a thrill of rejoicing that they had passed away forever. But the scenes of olden time oft return again. The conflict of civilization and barbarism returns upon us, and we who, in boyhood shuddered over the associations of the dark and bloody ground, have lived to see them almost cast into the shade by present and actual occurrences. Says Gov. BRAMLETTE, of Kentucky, in his inaugural address, "We have been overrun by invading armies and marauding bands of guerrillas, and are still likely to have them to harass us." "We should thoroughly organize, and should revive the spirit of our ancient defence, which characterized our lathers, and gave to their homes protection against a not more savage foe."

abstract: A few liberal men of wealth in this City have secured the church building in Fifty-fifth-street, near Lexington-avenue. It is a large and handsome structure, and when completed will make one of the best edifices in the City for convenience and beauty. It is located near the great Park, and will supply a deficiency long felt in that part of the City. The church lecture-room will be opened for divine service upon the second Sabbath in September, when services will be conducted by prominent clergymen in this City. It is expected that the edifice will be completed for worship in the large audience room at an early day. Friends of the Church, residing in that part of the City, are cordially invited to aid in this good work.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen met in special session yesterday afternoon. There were only twelve members present.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen met in special session yesterday afternoon. There were only twelve members present. The farce of passing the $3,000,000 ordinance over the Mayor's veto was the order, and it was done! Unanimously it was done, the whole gallant twelve voting for it -- every one of them -- all of the twelve -- including Messrs. COOK, JOYCE, BRICR and SANFORD, whose names, at their own request, were recorded in the affirmative. All voted for it, all the twelve, including the four gentlemen who requested their names to be recorded as so voting. It was a "big thing," this passing of the defunct ordinance. It will be a bigger thing when they get a cent subscription on the strength of it. A richer, more ludicrous farce was never enacted; nor one which has more excited the the risibilities of the public. Why not yield with a good grace to the honest action of the Comptroller, Supervisors and Mayor. This kicking against the pricks only betrays weakness or something a good deal worse.

abstract: Battles; Official Reports of; Official Reports of
snippet: Battles; Official Reports of; Official Reports of
lead_paragraph: This is a volume of extraordinary interest, being nothing less than the rebel official statements of battles, for the account of which we have heretofore had to rely upon the reports of our own officers and descriptions of newspaper correspondents. These, however honest in spirit, must necessarily be one-sided, from the fact that they were written only on one side, without knowledge of the other. This volume opens with probably the least reliable report in the whole collection -- BEAUREGARD'S report of the battle of Manassas. It is full of falsity in essential particulars. He states that " the Federal army consisted of at least fifty-five regiments of volunteers, eight companies of regular infantry, four of marines, nine of regular cavalry, and twelve batteries, 119 guns;" and would give the reader to understand that, making allowances for sick and details, the Federal force engaged amounted to at least fifty thousand men. His own force he states to have been in the aggregate thirty-two thousand. He does not distinctly state how much of this force actually participated in the conflict; but nearly all must have done so, since he virtually admits that it was the arrival of JOHNSTON'S columns in the afternoon, by railroad, that decided the fortunes of the day. Now, we have Gen. MCDOWELL'S statement in his official report that "he orossed Bull Run with about 18,000 men of all arms." Gen. MCDOWELL docs not attempt to specify the number of his adversary; but after a general description says: "What all this amounted to, I cannot say, certainly much more than we attacked them with. BEAUREGARD'S own statement proves this. There was a difference of at lenst ten or twelve thousand in favor of the Confederate forces. BEAUREGARD states that he had fifty-five guns, and that we had one hundred and nineteen. Major BARRY, Chief of Artillery under MCDOWELL, in his report, states that "the whole force of artillery of all calibres was 49 pieces, of which 2S were rifled guns," and he gives a particular specification of the different batteries. He states that of these 49 pieces only 24 actually crossed Bull Bun to the battle-field. The rest were held in reserve. BEAUREGARD, therefore, enormously exaggerates the real fact. Taking his statement of his own artillery strength, it seems that he had six. more pieces than our army, including our reserve, and 31 pieces apart from that reserve.

abstract: The New-Orleans Picayune publishes the following curious card, dated Confederate Prison, Aug. 26: "In your evening edition of this day I notice an allusion to myself, copied from a Washington paper which I should not notice but that it contains an error which places me in a position inconsistent with the acts and sentiments of my whole life.
lead_paragraph: -- The New-Orleans Picayune publishes the following curious card, dated Confederate Prison, Aug. 26: "In your evening edition of this day I notice an allusion to myself, copied from a Washington paper which I should not notice but that it contains an error which places me in a position inconsistent with the acts and sentiments of my whole life. The notice to which I allude represents me as having voted for CHARLES SUMNER, while I was a member of the Legislature of Massachusetts. This is not true. Mr. SUMNER was elected to the United States Senate in May, 1851, while I did not become a member of the Massachusetts Legislature until January. 1852, and, therefore, could not have voted for SUMNER, as stated. Hon. ASADEL BUCK, my immediate predecessor, voted steadily against SUMNER. If the antecedents of so humble a person as myself are to be paraded before the public, I may, in self-defence, be permitted to say that I am a South Carolinian, and have ever been true to the principles and traditions of my native State; that I have never given nor received an Anti-Slavery vote in my life, and that I was the first, while a member of the Massachusetts Legislature, to oppose the celebrated ' Personal Liberty bill,' and all other measures of an Anti-Slavery tendency. As a prisoner of war, I may not be entitled to much courtesy. May I not ask that this note be published as an act of justice?"

abstract: BRUTAL TREATMENT OF A SERVANT GIRL. A notice was received yesterday, at the Coroners' office, requesting that an ante-mortem examination be made in the case of a German girl named GERTRUDE WEBER, who according to the testimony of her physicians, was lying at the point of death at house No. 130 Seventh-street. Coroner NAUMANN proceeded to take the girl's statement.
lead_paragraph: BRUTAL TREATMENT OF A SERVANT GIRL. -- A notice was received yesterday, at the Coroners' office, requesting that an ante-mortem examination be made in the case of a German girl named GERTRUDE WEBER, who according to the testimony of her physicians, was lying at the point of death at house No. 130 Seventh-street. Coroner NAUMANN proceeded to take the girl's statement. The following is its substance: On the evening of the 7th of July last Mrs. MARGARET REHMANN, residing at No. 311 Fifth-street, discharged GERTRUDE from her employ as a servant. When the girl went to her sleeping-room for the purpose of obtaining her trunk, Mrs. REHMANN undertook to prevent her; a quartet ensued, during which the girl, as she testifies, was severely beaten by Mrs. REHMANN. The latter undertook to eject her late servant from the house, but being enable to do so alone, she called to her aid Mr. HERMANN, a brother of hers. The two finally managed to get her out, but not until she had been badly beaten, and, according to the testimony of the doctors, several of her ribs were broken. Her injuries are such that death will probably be the result. The jury rendered a verdict o the effect that GERTRUDE WEBER came to her injuries from blows received at the hands of Mrs. MARGARET REHMANN and her brother HERMANN. Upon the rendition of this verdict the Coroner held the parties to ball to await the result of the girl's injuries.

abstract: Deputy Provost-Marshal THOMAS G. GIRVAN arrived here from New-York yesterday morning for the purpose of hunting up deserters from New-York regiments, and went down to the Conscript camp to ascertain whether any of the substitutes down there were the men he wanted. On loosing over the crowd he recognized four New-York deserters who had been accepted as substituted in districts in this State, and at once arrested and ironed them in pairs, bringing them up from the island in the last boat. On reaching the wharf he took them into Milk-street, intending to bring them up that street to the City Prison, but when they were approaching Congress-street, Mr. GIRVAN being in the rear, the leading couple turned short off and ran down the cross street at full speed. Mr. GIRVAN was in doubt first whether to follow or not, but thinking the loss of a couple of scoundrels no small matter, he went after them at full speed, although he did not succeed in overtaking them, or finding where they had gone. Of course the two who were left behind were not slow to avail themselves of the chance given them for escape, and they, too, started, on their own hook; but the foresight of Mr. GIRVAN had checkmated them, as he had set a small boy to watch them, and through this boy the two were arrested and locked up in the Tombs. The names of these are EDWIN COFLE, a deserter from the Ninety-third New-York regiment, and GEO. W. LEE, alias GEO. H. HOWARD, from the Fire Zouaves. The names of the two escaped are GEO. CLARK, alias WILDER, of the Eleventh New-York, and WM. SHEPPARD, alias HALL, of the Third New-York. Mr. GIBVAN takes his loss quite philosophically, as he says there is no doubt they will turn up in course of time. -- Boston Herald, Sept. 5.

abstract: Ableman vs. Booth; Habeas Corpus
lead_paragraph: The pertinence of the decision of the Supreme Court of the United State in Ableman vs. Booth, in cases arising under the Conscription law, has been called in question in some quarters, but Judge E. DARWIN SMITH, of Rochester, recently rendered a decision affirming its applicability, and a few days ago Judge BACON, also of the Supreme Court of the Fifth Judicial District, gave a decision sustaining the position taken by his colleague, very much to the disappointment of the Copperhead journals in that part of the State, which had in some manner become possessed of a knowledge of the fact that Judge BACON'S first impressions were opposed to the conclusions arrived at after mature examination. The fac???s alleged in the petition on which the ??? was issued are as follows: One Charles ??? was held as a deserter, under the provisions of the Conscription act, by Provost-Marshal Richardson. A petition, omitting that fact, was presented to Judge BACON and the writ issued. The Provost-Marshal made a general return, setting forth the authority ??? which he held the prisoner, and declining to produce him. An attachment was moved for, and upon a motion to vacate that attachment, the case was argued and the decision given.

abstract: The Party of
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, as Esop tells the story, a man was seen making a journey, mounted upon an ass, and attended by his son on foot. The people came about the old gentleman and resolved themselves into a "public meeting." They reproached him bitterly for taking his ease upon an ass while his tender son trudged in the dust. The "laboring classes" were much excited, and the father dismounted and put his son upon the animal. This only seemed to make matters worse, and volleys of abuse were launched at the unfortunate party because the hale and robust youth rode and the father walked. To meet this new objection the father and son both rode. This change of base, instead of satisfying the crowd, only made them more outrageous. They denounced the arrangement as a gross imposition upon the ass, and perhaps called it "unconstitutional." The old gentleman and his son had but one recourse left. They took the jackass upon their shoulders and departed in peace.

abstract: Campaigns of Rosecrans and Buell
lead_paragraph: The remarkable resemblance between the present position of the Union army in Tennessee, under Gen. ROSECRANS, and the position of the same force under Gen. BUELL last year, is worth looking into, with a view to note both how far the resemblance goes and where it breaks off. In the early days of September of last year Gen. BUELL's advance was within shelling distance of Chattanooga, just as Gen. ROSECRANS' advance now is: and yet precisely this day a year ago, the Union army was in full retreat on its secondary base at Nashville, thrown back by a flank movement on its line of communications executed by Gen. BRAGG; and from Nashville it was, by a further movement of Bragg by the right, thrown back on its primary base --Louisville and the Ohio River. Is there any reason to anticipate a similar result for Gen. ROSECRANS' army? We think there is not: and we will briefly indicate the reasons why we think there is not.

The advices from Salvador do not corroborate the intelligence from that State brought by a previous arrival, that the Guatemalan invasion was at an end, on account of the defection of CANERA' troops.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Champion arrived at this port yesterday, from Aspinwall on the 27th ult., bring ing $279,043 in treasure, and later news from Gentral and South America, and from the United States of Colombia. The advices from Salvador do not corroborate the intelligence from that State brought by a previous arrival, that the Guatemalan invasion was at an end, on account of the defection of CANERA's troops. It now appears that President BARRIOS only holds the Capital and the single road to Libertad -- his only revenue being from the sale of confiscated goods. There was a rumor at Panama that a revolution had been started at Bogota by the priests against MOSQUERA, in his absence, but there is nothing definite regarding it. The few priests remaining at Panama were on the 19th ult. again required to take the oath to support the new Constitution, and on their refusal they were ordered to leave the country immediately. Nothing of importance was occurring in the South American Slates. Bolivia had as yet taken no steps to precipitate hostilities with Chili. There is considerable talk of the discovery of very rich gold and siver mines in Peru. Affairs are still unsettled between the Argentine Confederation and Uraguay.

abstract: Orders have been issued by Gen. CANBY for the removal of the troops from the City, and have already, in a measure, been acted on. During the continuance of the thousands of soldiers, from all sections of the country, in this City, their conduct has elicited the admiration and commendation of citizens. They have been orderly, respectful, peaceable...
lead_paragraph: Orders have been issued by Gen. CANBY for the removal of the troops from the City, and have already, in a measure, been acted on. During the continuance of the thousands of soldiers, from all sections of the country, in this City, their conduct has elicited the admiration and commendation of citizens. They have been orderly, respectful, peaceable, and, on all occasions, courteous There has been no complaint against a single one of their numbers: and notwithstanding the fact that nearly all of them have been for two and more years in service, all were suddenly called to a city affording temptations and opportunities for dissipation, the cases have been so rare as not to have attracted any attention. Residents in the vicinity of the various camps and other quarters bear willing testimony to the uniform good conduct of the men, and the entire absence of any annoyance attributable to their presence. It is doubtful if the same number of men of any other army in the world could or would under similar circumstances leave such an excellent name behind, and carry so much of good feeling with them. Of course much credit is due for all this to the officers, whose example was emulated, and whose orders were with the especial view of acquiring for their men just the fine repute they have won.

abstract: Exemption Mania, The
lead_paragraph: Everyone seems to be agreed that men who have families dependent on them for support, and have been drafted, ought either to be relieved from the necessity of serving, or have their families provided for out of the public funds. The "Conservative" party of this City, represented by the Aldermen and Common Council, go a long step further, and hold that no man ought to be obliged to serve, or to purchase his own exemption, if he is "unwilling" to do so: and they propose to pay out of the pockets of the taxpayers whatever sum may be necessary to secure everybody's exemption, rich or poor, married or single, fatherless, motherless, or blessed with both parents. The former of these doctrines is being put into practice by the Board of Supervisors, while the Aldermen and Common Councilmen have made desperate efforts to carry out the latter. Whichever party succeeds in keeping the field to itself, it is quite certain that nobody will be sent to the army from New-York who can give any good reason either for not serving, or for not purchasing his own exemption; and it is also quite certain that if the Common Council can get into the field "for the relief of the drafted." what with sham "indigents" and runaway substitutes, some three millions of dollars will pass into the pockets of the scum of the City population, and few or no men into the ranks of the army.

abstract: All the principal Broadway establishments will be open to-night, with the exception of LAURA KEENE's Theatre, which is still in the hands of the decorators. Those who require an entertainment of the best class will find it at Niblo's, where Mr. FORREST and Mr. BANDMANN appear in "Hamlet" and "Narcisse," supported by a good general Company. At the other establishments the Spectral Drama is still the rage; the Ghost, in fact, is everywhere, and everywhere prosperous. The Influence of the spirits is proved by the fact, that whilst Mrs. BOWERS (who is, by all odds, the best actress we have had in this City for many years) was sustaining a heavy weekly loss in endeavoring to keep up a respectable kind of entertainment, she has pasted to immediate profit by lending herself to the prevailing rage. Who can wonder that she has thrust a lot of ghosts into a piece where there is no justification for their presence. We refer to "Lady Audley's Secret," which is now the rage at the Winter Garden, and which, notwithstanding the ghosts, derives much of its interest from the fine impersonation of the heroine by Mrs. BOWERS. At Mr. WALLACK's establishment the play called "True to the Last" is still drawing enormous houses, and will continue to do so until it is brushed away by the authoritative hand of Mr. WALLACK. Mr. BARNUM, it is stated, has imported the real ghost, and will introduce it in a few days. In the meantime the Museum furnishes theatrical performances twice a day. The New-York Theatre (formerly WALLACK's, corner of Broome-street and Broadway,) will open to-night for a regular season. It has been newly decorated and improved. The entertainments are of the Ravel kind, and will be interpreted by the Martinetti and Marzetti troupe of pantominists.

abstract: His Letter to Springfield Convention
lead_paragraph: The President's letter to the Springfield Convention receives the unqualified admiration of loyal men throughout the breadth of the land. Various as have been their sentiments on some of its topics, it is yet their universal testimony that nothing could have been more true or more apt. Its bard sense, its sharp outlines, its noble temper, defy malice. Even the Copperhead gnaws upon it as vainly as did the viper upon the file.

abstract: Park Theatre, Brooklyn, the New
lead_paragraph: Appreciating the great growth of the population of Brooklyn, and the evident demand for a nightly dramatic entertainment, an enterprising citizen of that unique place of habitation, has erected quietly and unostentatiously, in one of its most frequented thoroughfares, a beautiful; theatre. It faces on Fultonstreet, immediately opposite the City Hall, in the immediate vicinity of the new Court-house, and at the intersection of the various lines of City railway. Its location is wisely chosen. The material of which it is built is known as Nova Scotia stone, running up into a front of sixty feet in height by fifty feet in width , the main entrance being directly in the centre, with a stairway ten feet in width leading to the second story. The basement is divided into three rooms, one of which is sixty by eighty feet in size, and the others are twenty by fifty feet. The ground floor presents on Fulton-street two stores, twenty by sixty feet each, with large windows of French plate glass. In the rear, fronting on Adams-street, is a large hall for public use, whose dimensions are sixty by eighty feet, with a ceiling fifteen feet high.

abstract: The steamship Germania, which arrived at this port last evening, is a new ship, built by Messrs. CAIRD & Co., Greenock, 2,900 tons measurement and 2,123 tons register, with all the modern improvements in machinery. On the voyage from Hamburg to Southampton, the Germania averaged, against strong head winds, a rate of twelve knots per hour. Her saloon is most elegantly fitted up in every respect, the panels being adorned with paintings of scenes in Germany, England and the United States. There is a first-rate piano and a good library on board for the use of the saloon passengers, and everything is provided that can conduce to their comfort. The steerage accommodations are excellent. The space between the decks is  81/2 feet high, and is thoroughly ventilated. The Germania is commanded by Capt. H. EHLERS, late of the Saxonia, who is well known and universally respected by all classes of passengers. This is the seventh steamship built by Messrs. CAIRD & Co., of GREENOCK, for the Hamburg American line. The company's fleet now consists of six large steamships, viz,: the Germania, Saxonia, Teutonia, Bavaria, Borussia, and Hammonia. The last five are of 2,500 tons measurement. By them fortnightly communication is maintained between Hamburg, Southampton and New-York.

lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamships City of NewYork, from Liverpool and Queenstown, and Germania, from Southampton, we receive advices from Europe to the 27th ult., four days later. The news is of considerable importance. There was a report that a rebel pirate steamer, named the Atlanta, had put into Brest for repairs, and having no bill of health on board, had been forced to go into quarantine. It is stated by the Paris correspondent of the London Globe, that a number of vessels on the model of the Alabama, are being constructed for the rebels in French ports. The writer points out the fact that there will be no difficulty in fastening responsibility upon the French Government, as it has supreme control over all matters relating to the shipyards. A memorial from the British Emancipation Society was, on the 25th ult, presented to Earl RUSSELL, on the subject of the new iron rams alleged to be in process of construction for the rebel Government in England. The memorial states that two powerful iron-plated steam rams have, for sometime, been in preparation in the Mersey, by the builders of the Alabama, one of which was expected to fail about the 27th, and to be received by the Florida then hovering off the coast. Still another is mentioned as being built on the Clyde. Earl RUSSELL is urged to order a prompt investigation into the circumstances detailed. It does not appear from our dispatches, however, that his lordship had taken any action in the matter. The response of Mr. SEWARD to the Address to President LINCOLN, adopted by the Anti-Slavery Conference at Manchester on the 3d of June last, is published. Mr. SEWARD says that the President received the Address and the papers that accompanied it with lively satisfaction, and that he readily accepts and avows, as an additional and irresistible motive to suppress the insurrection and maintain the Constitution, the suggestion made by the friends of America in Europe, that the success of the insurrection would result in the establishment, for the first time in the history of the human race, of a State based upon the exclusive foundations of African Slavery. The rebel I[???]an, [???] the 26th was quoted at 24 to 22 discount. Having recovered some 3 per cent. There was nothing new regarding the Polish question. The Liverpool Cotton market was firm at an advance. Brea[???]tuffs and Provisions were steady. Cons[???]s were unchanged.

abstract: The War with
lead_paragraph: The news which we published yesterday from Japan fully prepared our readers for the announcement which comes to us this morning by the Pacific telegraph that war has broken out with that country. The quarrel which has led to hostilities is exclusively an English one, yet it seems to have been an American vessel which received the first hostile shot from the Japanese, and an American man-of-war which opened active of offensive operations; and if they were English troops who fought the first land fight, they were American sailors who achieved the first naval victory.

abstract: European advices, three days later, are received by the steamship Scotia, which passed Cape Race on the 5th inst. She left Liverpool on the 29th and Queenstown on the 30th ult. The news is important.
lead_paragraph: European advices, three days later, are received by the steamship Scotia, which passed Cape Race on the 5th inst. She left Liverpool on the 29th and Queenstown on the 30th ult. The news is important. The Florida had captured and burnt the ship Anglo-Saxon, loaded with coal, bound from Liverpool for New York, on the 21st ult, only thirty miles southeast of Kinsale, she being in charge of a channel pilot at the time. It was uncertain what disposition had been made of the crew. There was a report also that the Alabama had gone into the French port of Cherbourg for repairs The Mexican question is assuming new and interesting phases. An American protest in regard to the French proceedings in Mexico, it was believed, would be presented to the French Emperor during the current week. There is a likelihood, also, that the Mexican throne may not, after all, be accepted by MAXIMILIAN. The King of the Belgians recommends him to insist upon certain conditions, winch are equivalent to a refusal; and it is understood that the Imperial family at Vienna are resolved that his acceptance must be followed by a renunciation of all his political rights as a scion of the House of Austria. The American Consul at Frankfort still continues to display the Mexican flag. The English papers very generally until in urging the British Government to prevent the departure of the iron-clad rams and other war vessels now building in British ports for the rebels. We hear nothing further regarding the vessels alleged to be in course of construction for the rebels in French dockyards. There is nothing new regarding the Polish question. The Liverpool Cotton Market was buoyant, and prices had still further advanced. Breadstuffs and Provisions were quiet. Consols were quoted at 93 3/8@93 1/2 for Money.

lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: News from Japan, of a highly important character, to the 24th of July, is received by way of San Francisco. Actual hostilities between the Japanese and the Treaty Powers had commenced. On the 15th of July, an English ship, bound from Nargasadi to Kanagawa by an inland passage, was fired upon by Japanese forts and vessels, which had previously fired upon the American ship Pembroke.
lead_paragraph: News from Japan, of a highly important character, to the 24th of July, is received by way of San Francisco. Actual hostilities between the Japanese and the Treaty Powers had commenced. On the 15th of July, an English ship, bound from Nargasadi to Kanagawa by an inland passage, was fired upon by Japanese forts and vessels, which had previously fired upon the American ship Pembroke. She was much injured, and had four men killed and six wounded, Subsequently the American steamer Wyoming visited the place to punish the Japanese for firing upon the Pembroke. She blew up one Japanese steamer and sunk another, and silenced nearly all the neighboring forts. She received twenty shots, and had five men killed and six wounded. The forts were afterward attacked by two British war vessels and after a bombardment, a detachment of British troops were landed, who destroyed the fortifications and an adjacent village. The Japanese showed very little fight.

abstract: on State Unity and Emancipation
lead_paragraph: There are extreme Anti-Slavery men who insist that the rebel States have lost their essential State polity by their rebellion, and that, until reconstituted by the consent of the National Government, they are to be treated as mere territories. This doctrine we have, from the outset, opposed, as utterly false and full of mischief. It implies that secession is not only possible, but an actual fact -- that South Carolina and Georgia are to-day no more integral parts of the Union than Sonora and New-Brunswick -- and that the progress of the Union arms into their domain is conquest pure and simple, to be followed by just such a disposition of the people and their property, as the conqueror, under the law of nations, may see fit to ordain. The true principle is, that secession is possible neither by legislation nor by violence -- that all doings toward that end are void from the beginning -- and that whatever forfeiture may be visited upon those engaged in this war, is a penalty for violated law, and not the spoliation of the victor.

abstract: In the Matter of Thomas Gahagan. -- Mr. Thos. Gahagan having been arrested by a policeman named John Cooney, sues out a writ of habeas corpus for his release. It is alleged in the petition of the prisoner that Cooney arrested him and held him as a deserter; that then Cooney went to some of the prisoner's friends and offered to release him on the payment of $100, which was refused. He further states that he is perfectly innocent of the charge of desertion. The Justice granted the writ.

abstract: A STAGE PICKPOCKET CAUGHT. A young man, who gave his name as WM. RYDER, was yesterday brought before Justice KELLY at the Jefferson Market Police Court, charged with having picked the pocket of Mr. HENRY A. WEEDEN, of the Howard House. The accused and Mr. WEEDEN were riding up Broadway in a Fifth-avenue Stage, sitting side by side.
lead_paragraph: A STAGE PICKPOCKET CAUGHT. -- A young man, who gave his name as WM. RYDER, was yesterday brought before Justice KELLY at the Jefferson Market Police Court, charged with having picked the pocket of Mr. HENRY A. WEEDEN, of the Howard House. The accused and Mr. WEEDEN were riding up Broadway in a Fifth-avenue Stage, sitting side by side. The latter rode only a few blocks and very soon after getting out he discovered that his gold watch, valued at $75, was gone -- the same having been unscrewed from the chain to which it was attached. Having strong suspicions that RYDER was the guilty person, he pursued the stage, overtook it, and with the aid of Officer OAKLEY made a thorough search of the vehicle. The watch was found secreted under the cushion of RYDER's seat. When taken before the Court he denied all knowledge of the theft, but the testimony was such as to induce the Justice to commit him in default of $1,000 bail. The Police say that his real name is THOMAS MURPHY, and that he has just been discharged from the State Prison, after having served a year and nine months.

abstract: The Chilian bark Caspar, of Valparaiso, BAIN, master, from Pisaqua, (Peru,) for New-York, foundered at sea, in lat. 36 20', len. 71 40', on the morning of 29th August. She was 362 tons burden, and had a cargo of 300 tons (nitre of soda) saltpetre, consigned to GEORGE B. HOBSON, of New-York. She had experienced some heavy weather off Cape Horn, but had not received any damage.
lead_paragraph: The Chilian bark Caspar, of Valparaiso, BAIN, master, from Pisaqua, (Peru,) for New-York, foundered at sea, in lat. 36° 20′, len. 71 40', on the morning of 29th August. She was 362 tons burden, and had a cargo of 300 tons (nitre of soda) saltpetre, consigned to GEORGE B. HOBSON, of New-York. She had experienced some heavy weather off Cape Horn, but had not received any damage. On 28th August, at 7 A.M., pumped ship, but got only a few buckets full of water, the wind being from southwest, pleasant weather, and the ship going about 6 1/2 knots; at 10 o'clock, the Captain went in the hold to look for something, and thought he heard a rush of water in the hold; sounded the pumps, and found 22 inches of water in the well; manned both pumps, which were of 7-inch bore and in good order, and by noon the lean had gained two inches; hauled for the nearest land, keeping the pumps going, the water gradually increasing; examined the hold with the carpenter, but found the sides dry as far as could be seen. Morning of 29th, had five feet of water, and the saltpetre rapidly dissolving; fearing the vessel would turn over got out the boats and placed the passengers in them with ten days' provisions. At 7 A.M. 29th the bark went down. After chasing a vessel which did not see them, they made sail on the boats and steered for New-York, the other boat in charge of the Second Mate containing the cook, steward and six seamen, went off before the wind apparently for Bermuda. That night it blew heavy with a cross sea, and hove the boat to with the oars lashed together as a drag. At 2 P.M. on the 30th, were taken on board the schooner Transit, Capt. Honns, bound to Demarara, who kindly consented to land them at Bermuda. On the 2d September, spoke British schooner Lilla, from St. Thomas for New-York, to whom they were transferred and arrived at this port yesterday. The following are the names of those saved in the Captain's boat: Alexander Bain, Master; Wm. Benson, First Officer; Wm. Prayer, carpenter; Martin Brila and Alfred Mitchell, seamen; Mrs. Bain Mrs. Sutherland, Mrs. Benson, John Bain and Wm. A. Bain, passengers.

abstract: Correspondence with Hon. F. Wood on Peace; Correspondence with President Lincoln on Peace
snippet: Correspondence with Hon. F. Wood on Peace; Correspondence with President Lincoln on Peace
lead_paragraph: For some months past the whole country has been assured by gentlemen of the "Peace party" that President LINCOLN had declined a proposition from leaders of the Southern Confederacy, which looked toward and would have insured a restoration of the Union. Mr. VALLANDIGHAM ventured on a very distinct statement to this effect during some of the harangues which led to his arrest, and our fellow-citizen, Ex-Mayor WOOD, has more than once made the same assertion, with all the emphasis which he usually gives where intrinsic improbabilities require this extraneous support. It is only a few days since he declared his belief, in a note published in the TIMES, that the Government might have ended the war and restored the Union at any time within the last year, if it had desired to do so.

abstract: Yesterday Commodore JOSEPH SMITH, Chief of the Bureau of Yards and Docks, arrived in this City from the National Capital, on his annual tour of inspection of the Navy-yards. He was received at the Brooklyn yard by Admiral PAULDING, and after staying some time at the quarters of that officer he pro  ceeded to the different departments, which he examined critically.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday Commodore JOSEPH SMITH, Chief of the Bureau of Yards and Docks, arrived in this City from the National Capital, on his annual tour of inspection of the Navy-yards. He was received at the Brooklyn yard by Admiral PAULDING, and after staying some time at the quarters of that officer he pro ceeded to the different departments, which he examined critically. He first visited the constructing department, where the new vessels Nyack, Wambanogue, ???uin, T???oma and Peoria, are building Mr. DELANG, the Naval Constructor, explained to him the progress and condition of each vessel. He then visited the engineering department, the machine shop, the blacksmith shop and the other mechanical departments, Having spent some hours n inspecting the condition of things, he returned to this City, and will proceed to-morrow to Boston, and in a few days afterward to Portsmouth, N.H. It is said that Commodore SMITH intends to suggest some alternations at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, which may be the erection of two or three mere ship-houses.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamer New-Jersey at Philadelphia we receive advices from Charleston to the 3d inst. The monotony of the siege operations had been varied by a general engagement on the 1st inst., between the iron-clads and Forts Sumter, Wagner and Moultrie, in which much damage was done to the forts.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamer New-Jersey at Philadelphia we receive advices from Charleston to the 3d inst. The monotony of the siege operations had been varied by a general engagement on the 1st inst., between the iron-clads and Forts Sumter, Wagner and Moultrie, in which much damage was done to the forts. During the action Fleet Capt. OSCAR C. BADGER, the successor of Capt. RODGRERS, had his leg broken by a shell, and it was thought that amputation would be necessary. The position of Fleet Captain of the South Atlantic Squadron appears to be somewhat fatal. At the time the New-Jersey left four Monitors had gone up to renew the action, and wore nearly abreast of Sumter. Gen. GILLMORE's land batteries, meantime, were firing night and day. The bombardment of the city had not been resumed, but it was expected to be as soon as certain new batteries were completed. Everybody was in fine spirits and confident of success.

abstract: The, and the Nation
lead_paragraph: Politicians in their calculations of the future are quite too apt to omit what is really the most important element namely, the sentiment of the army. They imagine that because soldiers do not generally exercise the right of suffrage, therefore they are of little political account. Yet the truth actually is, that for years to come the influence of the men now under arms will be the predominant agency in shaping the political policy of the country.

abstract: their Military Relations
lead_paragraph: It is difficult, in the utter absence of details, to say precisely what the evacution of Knoxville and the abandonment of the line of the Virginia and East Tennessee Railroad -- whose supreme importance we have so often pointed out -- in a military sense means. If the rebel army in that region is not so far demoralized as wholly to escape the ordinary rules of criticism, the withdrawal from Knoxville and the upper mountain region of East Tennessee would simply be an act of concentration on the part of Gen. BRAGG, which, though involving the giving up of an important point, and the abandonment of the main line of communications between the right and centre zones of the theatre of war -- a great temporary sacrifice, to be sure -- might yet be ultimately justified by the result of operations in other portions of the field.

abstract: Invalid Corps, The
lead_paragraph: We do not know precisely to whom the nation is indebted for the idea of organizing an Invalid Corps, but his foresight and consideration entitle him to national gratitude. For the maimed or broken down officer or soldier of the regular army ample provision has always been made -- not so for the volunteer. The advantages of a �retired list� do not inure to him; and beyond a pension of a most modest figure indeed, he has nothing to subsist him on his voyage down the �river of time," unless, perchance, fortune had previously favored him. Even the pension, necessary though it may be to the recipient, is accepted with reluctance, and is often repulsive to the sensitive nature of the brave soldier; for, though a just tribute for his faithful discharge of duty, it is rendered without a present return, and gives rise to a feeling of mendicancy.

abstract: By the Galway steamer Adriatic, which passed Cape Race, yesterday, we receive advices from Europe three days latter. The news is not of much importance. The Liverpool Mercury professes to have reliable information that the Vanderbilt was sunk by the Alabama on the 13th ult., but it is nothing but a repetition of the old story, which has so many times been disproved.
lead_paragraph: By the Galway steamer Adriatic, which passed Cape Race, yesterday, we receive advices from Europe three days latter. The news is not of much importance. The Liverpool Mercury professes to have reliable information that the Vanderbilt was sunk by the Alabama on the 13th ult., but it is nothing but a repetition of the old story, which has so many times been disproved. The question of ships for the rebels still occupies the attention of the London Times, which hopes the British Government will find the law sufficient to enable them to stop the departure of such vessels from the British ports. It is stated that the Jeff. Davis Government had made a pressing appeal to Spain for recognition, but that Spain declined, though the appeal was coupled with a guarantee thru Cuba and Porto Rico should not be interfered with. Advices from Japan to the 4th of July had reached England. At that time there appeared to be a growing affinity between the Tycoon's Government and the foreigners -- the Tycoon having even gone so far as to charter a British steamer to transport troops. There, is nothing by this arrival regarding the intentions of MAXIMILIAN touching the Mexican throne. Of the Polish question there is nothing definite. A report was current in Paris that Russia will not reply to the three notes, but will give a Constitution to Poland. Meantime hostilities still go on. A Polish village, the inhabitants of which had executed a Russian spy, was recently burnt by the Russians, and all its inhabitants, men, women and children, sent to Siberia. The Liverpool Cotton market was quiet and unchanged. There was rather more demand for Breadstuffs. Consols 93 1/2@93 5/8.

abstract: The position about to be assumed by the Democratic party of the State of New-York will possess much more than local or temporary importance. The great issues of the day have assumed a vastness and complexity of character with which machine-management will find itself unable to grapple.
lead_paragraph: The position about to be assumed by the Democratic party of the State of New-York will possess much more than local or temporary importance. The great issues of the day have assumed a vastness and complexity of character with which machine-management will find itself unable to grapple. In presence of the solemn verities of the war -- fields strewn with the dead, seas covered with armed ships, immense regions desolated by the foul fiend of rebellion, foreign nations planting empires in contiguous countries, and nearly a million of American citizens facing each other in line of battle -- the usual clap-trap of party organization will avail little, and only those principles can secure success which are approved by the popular judgment, and are accepted as faithful expositions of the popular will.

abstract: A SOLDIER ROBBED IN GRAND-STREET. KNEELAND BADGER, a private in Company K of the Fourth Vermont Volunteers, while passing along Grandstreet, near Mercer, about 1 o'clock yesterday morning, was suddenly attacked by five men.
lead_paragraph: A SOLDIER ROBBED IN GRAND-STREET. KNEELAND BADGER, a private in Company K of the Fourth Vermont Volunteers, while passing along Grandstreet, near Mercer, about 1 o'clock yesterday morning, was suddenly attacked by five men. His arms were pinioned, his mouth gagged, and while in that condition he was robbed of all the money he had. A few minutes after the thieves had left, two Policemen, of the Eighth Precinct came up and relieved BADGER from his unpleasant condition. They then pursued the offenders, and after a severe chase took three of them into custody. Yesterday they were taken before Justice KELLY, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, where they gave their names as THOMAS WATSON, THOMAS GILMARTIN and JAMES MURRAY. They were fully identified by Mr. BADGER. After an examination, WATSON was committed in default of $2,000 bail, GILMARTIN in default of $1,000, and MURRAY was locked up to await a further examination.

abstract: Harbor; Gen. Gillmore's Operations
lead_paragraph: Gen. GILLMORE's operations are progressing slowly but steadily and beautifully in Charleston Harbor. The rebels now inform us that on Sunday last they evacuated all of Morris Island -- including, of course, their batteries Wagner and Gregg -- the bombardment of which was reopened by Gen. GILLMORE on Friday morning last, and continued for fifty or sixty hours, until the evacuation. The panic-smitten rebels add that the Union forces now "hold Cummings Point, in full view of the City," and the "all quiet" which they announced on Monday morning was broken before sunset by an interchange of compliments between the Monitors and Fort Moultrie, on the opposite or left side of the harbor. The rebels proclaim that our forces made an assault on Battery Gregg, which was repulsed, as was our assault on Battery Wagner some weeks ago. But it is probable the assault was more successful than they announce, as they admit a loss of 150 men, and the capture of some prisoners.

abstract: In Re Michael Cox. A writ of habeas corpus was allowed in this case, directed to Col. Nugent,  commanding him to produce the body of Michael Cox, who, it is alleged, is in his custody. Cox is the person whose application was rejected a short time since by Justice White, of the Superior Court, on ...
lead_paragraph: In Re Michael Cox. -- A writ of habeas corpus was allowed in this case, directed to Col. Nugent, commanding him to produce the body of Michael Cox, who, it is alleged, is in his custody. Cox is the person whose application was rejected a short time since by Justice White, of the Superior Court, on the ground that a State Court had no jurisdiction. Col. Nugent made the same return to the writ issued by Justice LEONARD us he did to that issued by Justice White -- that he is forbidden to, produce the body, and that the State Courts hare no jurisdiction; he further plead that the matter had been adjusted by Judge White.

abstract: The London  Times makes some remarkably absurd comments remarkably absurd for the London Times, we mean in relation to the three iron-clad vessels which the rebels are arming and equipping against us.
lead_paragraph: The London Times makes some remarkably absurd comments -- remarkably absurd for the London Times, we mean -- in relation to the three iron-clad vessels which the rebels are arming and equipping against us. The nub of the absurdity is in the following sentence: "We (the English) should ask ourselves with what feelings we should regard similar proceedings on the part of others." Now, what has that to do with making money? What has it to do with shopkeeping? What has LAIRD to do with such ideas? What has the "Emperor of China" to do with them? They are fanatical, ridiculous, preposterous. It is trifling with the solemn theme of � s.d. to suggest them -- to talk about doing to others as we should like them to do to us. Coming from an American journal, such a remark might have a certain appositeness and pungency; but, coming from the London Times, it shows that that journal has at last gone clean daft.

abstract: The grounds, of which a description was given in the TIMES of Tuesday, was opened yesterday. Not many of the Club were present, and the expected display of fine stock and speed did not take place. Commodore VANDERBILT, Messrs, DE FORREST, BAKER, HALL and others were present, and a large number of invited parties. A very neat little brush took place between the Commodore with his handsome and fast span of little mares and Mr. DE FORREST with his superb nag. The latter afforded more work for the span than they could easily accomplish, and exhibits great speed and beautiful style. The Club have concluded that the saloon shall not be opened to the public, so henceforth the "dear people" are outsiders. Mr. STEPHEN DUBOIS received the guests in courteous and liberal style, dispensing his hospitalities with bountiful hand. If the purposes of the Pleasure Ground, as initiated, are fully carried out, it will do much for the improvement of stock and for an increased appreciation of speed and style.
lead_paragraph: The grounds, of which a description was given in the TIMES of Tuesday, was opened yesterday. Not many of the Club were present, and the expected display of fine stock and speed did not take place. Commodore VANDERBILT, Messrs, DE FORREST, BAKER, HALL and others were present, and a large number of invited parties. A very neat little brush took place between the Commodore with his handsome and fast span of little mares and Mr. DE FORREST with his superb nag. The latter afforded more work for the span than they could easily accomplish, and exhibits great speed and beautiful style. The Club have concluded that the saloon shall not be opened to the public, so henceforth the "dear people" are outsiders. Mr. STEPHEN DUBOIS received the guests in courteous and liberal style, dispensing his hospitalities with bountiful hand. If the purposes of the Pleasure Ground, as initiated, are fully carried out, it will do much for the improvement of stock and for an increased appreciation of speed and style.

abstract: The disbursements of the Comptroller upon the order of this Committee amounted yesterday to the sum of $50,050. Only 18 persons applying to the Committee for aid on account of indigence have had their commutation of $300 paid for them to the Government. In all the other cases the parties have either procured substitutes for themselves, to whom the $300 was paid, or the Committee have procured substitutes for them. One hundred and forty-eight substitutes have already been procured by the Committee, to whom $300 each was paid, and one who was procured for $250. The action of the Committee is based, in ail cases, upon the principle that the Government wants men instead of money; and from the large numbers who are daily offering themselves to the Committee as substitutes, the prospects are that nearly all of the money appropriated by the Board of Supervisors will be spent -- as it ought to be spent -- in procuring soldiers for the army, while, at the same time, it affords relief to that class of our citizens for whom it was intended.

abstract: Fast Day Sermon in Richmond
lead_paragraph: -- Rev. Dr. STILES, formerly well enough known in these parts, preached a sermon in Richmond, on JEFF, DAVIS' late Fast Day, which he seems to have thought deserving of publication, and in which opinion we certainly concur. His text was "Righteousness exalteth a nation," and the celebrated Southern Confederacy was of course the grand ideal of moral, social and political righteousness. He thought the changes which were now going on in the political and Christian world, and which were likely to result in the establishment of the Confederacy, were premonitory of the rapid approach of the millennium; and he cogently inquired, "Is it not reasonable to suppose that God will inaugurate this glorious era of the Church by wheeling some one nation out of the ranks of the world, to take ground for God and man under the banner of the Gospel?" -- and what nation could this be but the well-known Southern Confederacy. He seemed to think that it had already been "wheeled out of the ranks of the world," for he inquires: "Why should it seem a thing incredible to you that God should raise this nation from the dead, and raise hernow?" -- by which defunct nation he means the so-called Southern Confederacy. He further calls on the rebels to "arouse and seize this one great niche of time in the history of the world, and occupy that national position."

abstract: A BOLD ATTEMPT AT INCENDIARISM ARREST OF THE OFFENDER, About 1 o'clock yesterday morning, Officer SHUOK, of the Twenty-second Precinct, while patroling his beat, heard the cry of fire, and upon making an examination he found that all the upper floors of house No. 371 West forty-fifth-street were on fire. lead_paragraph: A BOLD ATTEMPT AT INCENDIARISM -- ARREST OF THE OFFENDER. -- About 1 o'clock yesterday morning, Officer SHUOK, of the Twenty-second Precinct, while patroling his beat, heard the cry of fire, and upon making an examination he found that all the upper floors of house No. 371 West forty-fifth-street were on fire. The officer immediately ascended to the upper stories, when he found the bedroom, occupied by EDWARD STAINSBURY and his wife enveloped in flames. Through the efforts of the officer the occupants were saved after much exertion. Later in the day, STAINSBURY was arrested on the complaint of his wife, who testified that her husband came home about midnight, and after beating her severely, deliberately placed a fluid lamp to the feather bed, with the avowed intention of burning up the entire establishment. Fire Marshal BAKER was called to make an investigation, and this officer, from testimony in his possession, caused STAINSBURY to be committed on the charge of arson in the first degree. The accused is a painter by trade, aged 33 years, and a native of England.

abstract: The siege is progressing favorably. That is all that can be said. The engineers are busily engaged constructing both defensive and offensive works, and before many days perhaps something of importance will have transpired. The monitors hold a position nearer than usual to Sullivan's Island, but do not evidence any further intention of making an attack.

abstract: We have the news that on Tuesday last the rebel army evacuated Chattanooga, and yesterday Gen. ROSECRANS' army marched in and took possession of the great Western mountain stronghold. The rebels are reported to have fled southward into Georgia; but sure it is that if they could not hold their unsurpassed natural fortress at Chattanooga, they can hold no point from the mountains to the seaboard.

abstract: As the Democracy, whenever convenient lay particular stress on "established usage," "party precedent " and "time-honored traditions," we trust they will not overlook the action of the Democratic party of this State during the War of 1812-14. During our difficulties on the Niagara frontier in 1814, Senator MARTIN VAN BUREN, who was then spokesman of the Democracy in the upper House of our State Legislature, introduced a bill for the purpose of drafting and placing at the disposal of the National Government twelve thousand men from the militia -- such drafted men to serve for two years or the war.

abstract: Democratic Wish for its Withdrawal
lead_paragraph: Whenever the history of this war comes to be written, there wilt be nothing in it that will excite more surprise than the anxiety of the peace or peaceful Democrats to have the Emancipation Proclamation withdrawn. There would be nothing singular in this feeling, if they imagined that it was really effecting, or was likely to effect a complete abolition of Slavery at the South, or even to exercise any influence on it whatever, because we all know that they consider the maintenance of Slavery not only not objectionable, but essential to the preservation of the Union. But nothing can be more notorious than that they ascribe to it no such potency. For them it is a brutum fulmen -- the. "Pope's bull against the comet," the "King's proclamation forbidding belief in God," the decree of the inquisition against the earth's motion -- everything, in short, that is vain, foolish, null and void. It will, they tell us, liberate no slaves; it has liberated no slaves; it has not withdrawn a single soldier from the Confederate ranks; or caused a pang of apprehension on a single plantation. All the negroes that have been lost to their owners would have been lost if it had never appeared; all that still remain to them will remain to the end, in spite of it. It is the march of the Union armies that is injuring Slavery -- the touch of the iron hand of war which blasts everything it passes over, scorches up the fields, ruins the villages, and spreads desolation like a tide. The Proclamation has nothing to do with the crumbling of the institution. It is but the silly words of a foolish man, inscribed on a sheet of paper, of about the same efficacy as the verses of the Koran, which Eastern Muftis write on a plate, to be licked off by sick believers as a remedy for their maladies.

abstract: The steamer Patapsco, from Havana on the 3d inst., arrived at this port yesterday, bringing news from Vera Cruz to the 15th ult. by way of Santiago de Cuba. Tampico was occupied by the French on the 11th ult., having been captured after slight resistance. There were rumors at Vera Cruz that Matamoras had declared for the French "intervention," and had disarmed the Juarez garrison. Accounts from the interior of Mexico indicate that the entire country is in a condition bordering on anarchy. The only news from the Capital is a report that Count SALIGNY had been seriously ill.

abstract: Our Paris corre  spondent writes that the Grand Duke MAXIMILIAN is anxious to mount the Mexican throne, but he first demands the fulfillment of three conditions, the first of which is that the United States Government shall recognize the new order of things in Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Our Paris correspondent writes that the Grand Duke MAXIMILIAN is anxious to mount the Mexican throne, but he first demands the fulfillment of three conditions, the first of which is that the United States Government shall recognize the new order of things in Mexico. The Grand Duke need not have gone on enumerating any additional conditions. He might have stopped with the first. The fact that he made such a condition indicates a fantastical ignorance of the public sentiment and state of affairs in this country not at all creditable to HERZOG MAX. If he delay assuming the sceptre, or rather, we should say, the shepherd's crook of Mexico, until the United States Government recognize the Forey usurpation, he may long continue to enjoy himself in his new palace at Trieste, but he will never have an opportunity of reveling in the halls of the Montezumas.

abstract: We have this morning highly important rebel news from Charleston. The Richmond Enquirer of yesterday contains a dispatch from the doomed city, dated the 7th, which announces that Morris Island was evacuated by the rebels on the previous afternoon. Our forces, it appears by the dispatch, had dug their way up to the very moat of Wagner, and it being impossible longer to hold the work, BEAUREGARD ordered its evacuation. Fort Gregg was also necessarily evacuated, and Gen. GILLMORE was in full possession of Cummings' Point, in full view of the City of Charleston. At last accounts heavy firing was going on between the monitors and Fort Moultrie and the batteries on Sullivan's Island. A demand had been made for the surrender of FortSnmter, but it had been refused.
lead_paragraph: We have this morning highly important rebel news from Charleston. The Richmond Enquirer of yesterday contains a dispatch from the doomed city, dated the 7th, which announces that Morris Island was evacuated by the rebels on the previous afternoon. Our forces, it appears by the dispatch, had dug their way up to the very moat of Wagner, and it being impossible longer to hold the work, BEAUREGARD ordered its evacuation. Fort Gregg was also necessarily evacuated, and Gen. GILLMORE was in full possession of Cummings' Point, in full view of the City of Charleston. At last accounts heavy firing was going on between the monitors and Fort Moultrie and the batteries on Sullivan's Island. A demand had been made for the surrender of FortSnmter, but it had been refused.

abstract: The Knoxville Register  has commenced its migrations through the Southern Confederacy, precisely after the amusing fashion set by that other unquenchable Tennessee rebel organ, the Memphis Appeal, which has moved from town to town ...
lead_paragraph: The Knoxville Register has commenced its migrations through the Southern Confederacy, precisely after the amusing fashion set by that other unquenchable Tennessee rebel organ, the Memphis Appeal, which has moved from town to town .and State to State in the South, as our armies advanced, until now it is published away down in Georgia. The Register has made a leap from Knoxville to Cleveland, near the Georgia State line, but as BURNSIDE's army is a few miles north of Cleveland, and ROSECRAN's army a short distance south of it, and the Register is thus between two fires, we fear it will not be found convenient to issue it for any length of time from that locality. After Cleveland, Atlanta would, geographically speaking, be the next most eligible point for publication; but there is one Tennessee paper, the Appeal, stationed there already, and beside, militarily viewed, Atlanta is no better than Cleveland, but rather worse. We advise all these wretched and routed rebel newspapers to commit harikari at once. They have dope immense damage to the South, and their annihilation will be of prodigious benefit to it -- particularly when it is considered their places are at once filled, as our armies advance, by loyal, logical, grammatical and well printed journals.

abstract: On Sunday intelligence was received in this city from Gen. BURNSIDE that a portion of his army had entered and taken possession of Knoxville, the principal military position and city of East Tennessee, and that the Star-Spangled Banner, in all its brilliancy, was again floating over that late rebel stronghold. Gen. BUCKNER, with a strong rebel force, upon learning of the arrival of Gen. BURNSIDE at Kingston, concluded to retire toward Chattanooga, which he did successfully. Gen. BURNSIDE went with a portion of his army and took possession of Knoxville, while the remaining portion crossed form Kingston over the railway, which had been torn up, and, taking the pike, went in pursuit. The mam portion of Gen. Burnside's army is pashing on to reinforcement R[???]secrans, and no doubt exists but that the advance has already reached the army of the Cumberland BUCKNLR has reinforced BRAGG, and reports are current, and believed at the headquarters of ROSECRANS, that a portion of JOHNSTON's army from the extreme South has also arrived and reinforced "a little more grape, Capt. BRAGG."

abstract: This body took its place in Tweedle Hall with very much the same air that the culprit goes into the dock as different from the bearing of the " unterrified Democracy " of other days as can be well imagined.
lead_paragraph: This body took its place in Tweedle Hall with very much the same air that the culprit goes into the dock -- as different from the bearing of the " unterrified Democracy " of other days as can be well imagined. It showed at once that it felt itself on the defence, and that the evidence was to be terribly against it. From the beginning to the end, it seemed to think of nothing but extenuation and deprecation. It did not challenge acquittal, but begged merciful consideration; and begged it, too, with a hang-dog look that unmistakably indicated that it had no hope of anything of the kind.

abstract: We give up one-half of the entire surface of to-day's issue of the TIMES to the important speech upon our Foreign Relations, delivered by Senator SUMNER, in this City, last night.
lead_paragraph: We give up one-half of the entire surface of to-day's issue of the TIMES to the important speech upon our Foreign Relations, delivered by Senator SUMNER, in this City, last night. The subject at the present moment is one of such deep public interest, and of such overshadowing National importance, that we believe we cannot do a greater service than by giving in full the views of one who, by his official position as Chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs, by his relations with some of the foremost publicists of England and France, and by his intimate knowledge of the whole subject, is capable of speaking with intelligence, if not with authority.

abstract: We have this morning full confirmation of the news of the occupation of Chattanooga by a portion of Gen. ROSECRANS' army, published yesterday. Gen. CRITTENDEN took peaceable possession on Thursday, and Gen. WOOD was put in command of the place.
lead_paragraph: We have this morning full confirmation of the news of the occupation of Chattanooga by a portion of Gen. ROSECRANS' army, published yesterday. Gen. CRITTENDEN took peaceable possession on Thursday, and Gen. WOOD was put in command of the place. The rebel infantry evacuated the place on Wednesday morning, but the cavalry did not leave until a short time before our forces entered it. The rebel line of retreat is along the Georgia State line of railroad, which is threatened by our advance, and is quite likely to be interfered with.

abstract: Capt. WEBSTER, late of the ship Constitution, captured by the privateer Georgia, makes the following statement: June 25, at 6 A.M., in sight of the Island of Trinidad, South Atlantic Ocean, lat. 20  31' S., long. 29  16' W., made a steamer with English colors flying, close under the land; I hoisted the American ensign and continued on my course with all sail set, the steamer steering directly for us; 8 A.M. she fired ...
lead_paragraph: Capt. WEBSTER, late of the ship Constitution, captured by the privateer Georgia, makes the following statement: June 25, at 6 A.M., in sight of the Island of Trinidad, South Atlantic Ocean, lat. 20 31' S., long. 29 16' W., made a steamer with English colors flying, close under the land; I hoisted the American ensign and continued on my course with all sail set, the steamer steering directly for us; 8 A.M. she fired a blank cartridge; I paid no attention, but continued on my course; 8:30 A.M. she fired two shots, which fell short; at 9 A.M., steamer being near, and seeing no way to escape, I deemed it best to heave to; in the meantime they had lowered the English and hoisted the Confederate flag; they came alongside and sent a boat with First Lieutenant and boat's crew, all armed, on board, demanded the ship's papers, and ordered me on board the steamer; the commander. Capt. MAURY, who after examining the papers, told me he considered my ship a prize to the Confederate steamer Georgia, and myself and crew prisoners, ordering us on board our ship to stand in under the island and anchor in twenty fathoms. Having anchored about 4 o'clock, the steamer keeping near by, the prize crew then took full charge and commenced searching the ship, taking all the fire arms, chronometers, quadrants, sextant and charts, with all navigation books, and even the knives and razors belonging to us. On the 26th com enced taking out some of the cargo, which, being coal, they were glad to get. On the 28th the steamer took the ship City of Bath, from Callao for Antwerp, said ship having a French cargo; they ran??? her for $20,000; we were put on board of her, not having sufficient water; touched at Pernambuco, where my crew were delivered to the American Consul -- 14 men -- six having joined the steamer; myself and family, with first and second officers remained on board the City of Bath, as the Consul would do nothing for us. When standing into Pernambuco Roads saw the United States steamer Venderbilt, and signalized her; she sent a boat on board to whom we gave the whereabouts of the Georgia, and how they might be likely to find her, as she secretes herself under the island and cannot be seen more than four or five miles off.

abstract: The United States steam transport Daniel Webster, PHILLIPS, from Fortress Monroe in twenty-four hours, arrived last night. On the 9th inst., at 10 1/2 A.M., inside of Cape Henry, was boarded by a boat belonging to frigate Minnesota, from the blockading fleet, off Wilmington, N.C. She reported being on shore with her boats, and had a fight with some rebels, killing twelve, and capturing two guns, which they brought with them. The Minnesota is bound up to Fortress Monroe. At 2 P.M., off Hog Island, exchanged signals with steamships Baltic and Atlantic, bound South.

abstract: Less than half of the money called for by the Board of Supervisors under the Two Million Relief ordinance has as yet been subscribed. We hope the whole of the sum that is still lacking will be promptly furnished by the Insurance Companies and by capitalists.
lead_paragraph: Less than half of the money called for by the Board of Supervisors under the Two Million Relief ordinance has as yet been subscribed. We hope the whole of the sum that is still lacking will be promptly furnished by the Insurance Companies and by capitalists. A good part of the subscriptions thus far has come from those who are not in the habit of subscribing to public loans. Yet this loan is an inviting and perfectly safe one, and there is no doubt of its legalization by the Legislature. If the amount called for were subscribed at once, the operations of the Supervisors' Committee would very soon be brought to a just and satisfactory close.

abstract: The return game between these clubs took place yesterday, at Hoboken, and terminated in favor of the Atlantics by the result of the 8th innings, the previous game being in favor of the Mutuals, by 27 to 26. There were between five and six thousand persons on the grounds, and excellent order and good feeling prevailed during the match, and friendly speeches by Mr. BYRNES, of the Mutual, and Mr. BABCOCK, of the Atlantic, and counter cheering, which made the glasses dance on the well-spread refreshment table, cemented the renewed good friendship between these famous clubs. The play was first-class, and the decisions of Mr. HUDSON, the Umpire, just.
