abstract: The First Massachusetts regiment, now stationed on Ricker's Island in our upper Bay, the rendezvous of the conscripts of this State, was honored, yesterday, while reflecting honor, by the presentation of an elegant flag sent to them by the City of Boston, whose Chief Magistrate came hither to bestow the gift in person. In the morning a large party, consisting of several distinguished citizens and many members of the Press, left ...
lead_paragraph: The First Massachusetts regiment, now stationed on Ricker's Island in our upper Bay, the rendezvous of the conscripts of this State, was honored, yesterday, while reflecting honor, by the presentation of an elegant flag sent to them by the City of Boston, whose Chief Magistrate came hither to bestow the gift in person. In the morning a large party, consisting of several distinguished citizens and many members of the Press, left this City for the island, where they were handsomely received by the officers in charge. Among the company were Gen. CANBY, Col. FRANE E, HOWE, Col. ERRIE, the Inspector-General of the Army of Gen. GRANT, LEWIS W. TAPPAN, Gen. ROBT. COWDEN, whose faithful services in a score of battles are known to the entire country, Hon. E.C. COWDEN, Gen. WM. DWIGHT, Gen. J.S. TYLER. President of the Board of Aldermen of Boston, Capt. CLINTON, and many others of no inconsiderable note. Mrs. Maj. Gen. BANKS was also present, and contributed greatly to the pleasure and interest of the occasion.

abstract: An unusually interesting trotting-match took place yesterday on this fine course, which has been refenced, and new stands erected. The contest was between two fast trotting horses from "Way Down East," Lady Morrison being driven by HIRAM WOODRUFF, and Sorrel Dan by DAN MACE. Previous to starting for the $2,000, it was found that the mare had a sore leg, and that it was bandaged, and the betting, in consequence, went up 4 to 1 in favor of the gelding.

abstract: Tammany and Mozart at the Democratic State Convention
snippet: Tammany and Mozart at the Democratic State Convention
lead_paragraph: For the past month that venerable damsel, Tammany, has been arrogant and boastful of what she would do at the Democratic State Convention. To read her organs and hear her leaders, one would suppose that young Mozart was, in advance, hidden from sight and sound beneath the amplitude of her crinoline. So confident was the old lady of this that it was declared she would not sit in the same Convention with the wild, reckless, unprincipled Mozart, and that, with maidenly modesty shocked and outraged, she would retire if this bold, vigorous, and at times indecorous youth, was admitted. On getting to Albany, however, the question was found not so much to be whether Tammany would sit with Mozart, as whether Mozart would sit with Tammany; whether the latter would be allowed to sit at all. Mozart, with becoming and commendable gallantry, came to her aid, however, and while rejecting the billing and cooing which sought to propitiate, at the same time did service toward her retention. Her delegation, headed by the old War Horse, and composed of seventeen, who with very few exceptions were office-holders, instead of withdrawing as threatened, found great cause for thankfulness in that they were not wholly excluded, and stood ready to gratefully pick up such crumbs from the political platter as were too small for the attention of Mozart.
headline: {'main': 'Tammany and Mozart.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Tammany and Mozart.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A RELIC. -- Mr. H.F. JOHNS, proprietor of a hotel in Washington, has shown us a suggestive relic of the days just before the rebellion, in the shape of a gold-headed cane, bearing the superscription, "Ex-President JOHN TYLER to his son, Gen. JOHN TYLER, 1856." Mr. JOHNS came into possession of this cane in rather peculiar circumstances. Gen. JOHN TYLER stopped at his hotel in 1860, and after he had been there a week, constantly drunk, Mr. JOHNS presented his bill, amounting to about $60. True to the principles of the F.F.V.'s, Gen. TYLER scorned to pay any attention to such base pecuniary demands, and Mr. JOHNS forthwith proceeded to eject him from his establishment, making use of such applications as the emergency demanded. As Gen. TYLER reached the lowest step of the hotel, he valiantly turned, and raising the identical cane in question, which he said his father had presented him for killing one -- Yankee, he threatened to thrash Mr. JOHNS. By a skillful flank movement, the belligerent General was laid sprawling upon the pavement, and his cane was transferred to Mr. JOHNS' possession, where it has since remained. During the session of the Peace Convention in Washington. Mr. JOHNS called upon Ex-President TYLER, Who was one of the delegates, and stating the circumstances, offered to give up the cane if the board bill was paid. The Ex-President pooh-poohed the idea, and the cane therefore did not again change owners. Now Mr. JOHNS proposes to melt down the gold and sell it for whatever he can get.
lead_paragraph: A RELIC. -- Mr. H.F. JOHNS, proprietor of a hotel in Washington, has shown us a suggestive relic of the days just before the rebellion, in the shape of a gold-headed cane, bearing the superscription, "Ex-President JOHN TYLER to his son, Gen. JOHN TYLER, 1856." Mr. JOHNS came into possession of this cane in rather peculiar circumstances. Gen. JOHN TYLER stopped at his hotel in 1860, and after he had been there a week, constantly drunk, Mr. JOHNS presented his bill, amounting to about $60. True to the principles of the F.F.V.'s, Gen. TYLER scorned to pay any attention to such base pecuniary demands, and Mr. JOHNS forthwith proceeded to eject him from his establishment, making use of such applications as the emergency demanded. As Gen. TYLER reached the lowest step of the hotel, he valiantly turned, and raising the identical cane in question, which he said his father had presented him for killing one -- Yankee, he threatened to thrash Mr. JOHNS. By a skillful flank movement, the belligerent General was laid sprawling upon the pavement, and his cane was transferred to Mr. JOHNS' possession, where it has since remained. During the session of the Peace Convention in Washington. Mr. JOHNS called upon Ex-President TYLER, Who was one of the delegates, and stating the circumstances, offered to give up the cane if the board bill was paid. The Ex-President pooh-poohed the idea, and the cane therefore did not again change owners. Now Mr. JOHNS proposes to melt down the gold and sell it for whatever he can get.

abstract: "Vigor" During the Riots
lead_paragraph: Resolved, That the administration of HORATIO SEYMOUR as Governor of New-York meets our highest Approval; * * * * * his fidelity to the Constitution, the administrative energy evinced in promptly sending the militia of the State to repel the invasion of Pennsylvania by the Confederate forces, and the vigor winch he displayed in putting down a lawless and reckless mob, and the statesmanship exhibited in his whole public action, present a record of which not only our own State, but the whole American people may justly be proud.

abstract: His Tennessee Campaign
lead_paragraph: Strategy, which was first the mania and then the mockery of our fickle public, has never had a more perfect illustration than the campaign in Tennessee, which has culminated in the capture of Chattanooga. Indeed, there is some reason to fear that the very bloodlessness of the victory which Gen. ROSECRANS has achieved will blind us to the surpassing importance of the victory itself. Victories won in the awful shock of arms, by their brilliant picturesque effects and sensational elements, readily address themselves to the public eye and ear; but victories won by simple superiority of generalship demand for their appreciation a finer sense and a deeper study. Besides, the very vastness of the theatre of war on which Gen. ROSECRANS is operating, and the imperfect knowledge people generally have of that theatre, compared with the familiar geography of the Virginia battle-fields, make an intelligent appreciation of his operations rare. Strategical operations -- which are operations conducted out of sight of the enemy, in contradistinction to tactical operations, which are conducted in sight of the enemy -- require for their appreciation a full knowledge of times and places: of roads, distances, lines of communication, lines of retreat, and the positions and relations of the contending forces.

abstract: At the opening of the Court on Thursday morning, MARGARET WILKINS, a colored girl, 16 years of age, was put on trial for stealing $220 in greenbacks from JAMES McCLOUGHLIN, in Seventh-avenue, corner of Fiftieth-street. MARGARET was a chambermaid in the house where the complainant lodged, and was charged with taking his pocket-book from under his pillow, where he had deposited it for safe keeping, but had gone off in the morning and forgotten it.
lead_paragraph: At the opening of the Court on Thursday morning, MARGARET WILKINS, a colored girl, 16 years of age, was put on trial for stealing $220 in greenbacks from JAMES McCLOUGHLIN, in Seventh-avenue, corner of Fiftieth-street. MARGARET was a chambermaid in the house where the complainant lodged, and was charged with taking his pocket-book from under his pillow, where he had deposited it for safe keeping, but had gone off in the morning and forgotten it. The pocket book was finally restored to the owner, and as there was no positive proof that the prisoner had taken it, or if she did take it that she intended to keep it, the jury acquitted her.

abstract: Speech on Foreign Relations
lead_paragraph: Mr. SUMNER is to be thanked for his thorough exposition of the course of England and France in respect to our great struggle. It is something which has long been needed. One of the strangest things of this strange time has been the quietude with which our Congressmen have submitted to these breaches of international law and good faith. They have seemed to ignore entirely the fact that it particularly devolved upon them to appeal to the judgment of the civilized world. Our Secretary of State, and our Ministers in England and France, have done their own appropriate duties well. But their duties were purely diplomatic. Their arguments and their remonstrances were necessarily addressed to the private car of Government only. They were bound not to know any such tribunal as public opinion. It was for our Senators and our Representatives in Congress to make manifest the indignation of the American people they professed to represent, and to invoke the severest condemnation of all people everywhere against the monstrous injustice we are suffering. It was for them to proclaim how international law, and how American precedent, debarred foreign governments from showing our rebels the slightest favor, and how every moral principle of the age entitled our struggling Government to the moral support of every civilized Power. They did nothing of the kind. From the beginning to the end of the last Congress, there was not a solitary debate, in fact not a solitary speech, of any weight, upon the subject of our foreign wrongs. The everlasting flood of Parliamentary impertinence on the other side of the water was met only by a dead Congressional silence on this. So far as depended on the men in our Capitol, Europe had a right to conclude that the once imperious Republic was thoroughly heartbroken, and ready to submit to any fate PALMERSTON and NAPOLEON might see fit to allot her. This quiescence was the more remarkable, because in such absolute contrast to the old habits. Time was, nay it always was, when a suspected clipper stopped, a stray loafer seduced into enlistment, a Mosquito Indian patronized, a patch of Pacific sand camped upon, a cod and mackerel ground curtailed -- anything, even the ninth part of a hair sometimes, was sufficient to bring down Senatorial thunders which would shake the two continents. And yet here, when there was vital occasion, when foreign Powers were recklessly tampering with the very lifestrings of the nation, there was not the slightest whisper.

abstract: -- The Russian steam frigate Osljaba, Commander BOULAKOFF, from Cadiz, arrived at this port yesterday. She is at anchor off the Battery.

abstract: The Resignation of
lead_paragraph: The resignation of Gen. BURNSIDE is announced from Cincinnati. No cause is assigned in explanation of this step, though it is believed he had contemplated it for some time. We are sure the bluerest of Gen. Burn??? ought not to ??? him the opportunity of ??? from the ??? of the Department of the Ohio with credit on himself. If Gen. ??? has not always acted wisely, no man can doubt that he has ??? and patriotically. It was his misfortune to have had, in the command of the army of the Potomac, a weight thrust upon him greater than he could bear, and greater than he felt he could bear. His last campaign, though it did not afford him the occasion for any brilliant feats of arms, was yet well planned and executed with entire success. It must be a gratification to him, as it is to his friends, that not an armed rebel remains on the soil of the Department he had commanded.

abstract: PARK THEATRE, BROOKLYN. -- It will be seen by advertisement that this new and elegant theatre, on Fulton-street, opposite the City Hall, Brooklyn, opens for the regular season on Monday. It is under the lessee and managership of Mr. GABRIEL HARRISON, and the Company embraces many well-known for their talent. The promise is that the enterprise will be an entire success. Two excellent pieces, affording capital opportunity to test the Company, are presented -- BUCKSTONE's fine comedy of "Married Life," and the musical after-piece of a "Loan of a Lover."

abstract: Messrs. MERRICK & SONS have just completed, under the surperintendence of Mr. W.K. THOMAS, U.S. Inspector of iron-clad steamers, two new and improved boilers for the United States gunboat James Adger. They have also completed the engines for the United States Monitor Tonawanda, now building at the Philadelphia Navy-yard; the boilers are already in the vessel. The machinery for the light-draft Monitor Yazoo, which is being built by CRAMP & SONS, is fast being closed in, and it is expected that before the close of the year she will be launched. Twenty of this class of vessels are under way, all of which, it is expected, will be ready for service in eight months. They will be put into service as finished. The large number of iron vessels now building require the rolling-mills to run night and day. The Canonicus, a sea-going Monitor, built at Boston, will be ready for service in about thre[???] Philadelphia [???]

abstract: The Midshipmen attached to the United States sloop-of-war Marion have ended their Summer cruise. The vessel is now bound from Portsmouth, N.H., to Newport, where her young middies will be sent on shore to complete their course of education at the Academy. A few of them will remain on board of the Marion, and several will be transferred to the frigate Santee, which is the maritime rendezvous of the young gentlemen at Newport. The young officers of our navy have seldom had a more pleasant cruise than that which has just been made in the Marion. Their vessel has been cruising between Portland, Me., and Philadelphia; has visited all the Navy-yards and passed through the Hudson River -- remained some time at the West Point Military Academy, the young men visiting it, and also the West Point Foundry. She underwent some slight repairs during her sojourn at New-York. The following is a list of her officers:

abstract: the Right or Wrong of
lead_paragraph: The complete silence into which the fall of Vicksburgh and Port Hudson and the defeat of Gettysburgh has thrown the leading Secessionist agents abroad, is the best possible proof that the only Union arguments that can really be called cogent in that quarter are victories. Mr. SPENCE has only made his appearance once in print since the capture of Vicksburgh, and that was to make head in the Times against the rapid depreciation of the rebel loan, not, however, on the ground that the case of the Confederacy was not hopeless, but on the ground that, whatever happened, the South would still form an influential portion of the Union, capable of maintaining its own honor and seeing that its engagements were fulfilled. At the last meeting of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce, his statement that he had better not say much "about American affairs," in allusion to the formal repudiation of him by the Richmond Enquirer, was received with shouts of laughter. His colleagues have not borne up with even as much fortitude as he. ROEBUCK, who usually stars it in the provinces at this season, and gives the men of Sheffield, at least, a bit of his mind on the conduct of foreign Powers, has not opened his lips since he made his motion early in July for a recognition of the Confederacy. Messrs. LINDSAY and LAIRD have followed his example, though the former warned Lord PALMERSTON that the news expected every hour at that date (of the capture of Washington by LEE) would probably cause him to change his resolution not to recognize the Confederacy, with a rapidity which would certainly appear humiliating. As these were almost the only prominent friends of the South who went so far as to advocate recognition, we shall probably hear no more on this branch of the subject. The fact that Parliament is not in session, and will not be in session until February next, furnishes them with a reasonable excuse to the Southern agents for not bringing it up again at present, even if they feel loth to hurt their feelings by urging on them the necessity of retrieving their late reverses.

abstract: A very curious, instructive and valuable chart, exhibiting the "Fluctuations in the Price of Gold in 1863," (and also last year,) has been gotten up by Mr. J.P. HOWARD, of this City. By a series of rising and falling lines, the rise and fall of the precious metal on every day of the year is exhibited at a glance, and the political and military events which are supposed to have caused the more notable perturbations are indicated. After Gen. SHERMAN's repulse before Vicksburgh, near the beginning of the year, gold shot up from 134, steadily up, with trifling fluctuations, until, on the 24th of February last, it touched 172. From this point it suddenly drooped down to 150, on the passage of the bill taking transactions in gold, and so, ever varying, out pretty steadily falling from the price at the close of February, it fluctuated till, after Gettysburgh, Vicksburgh and Port Hudson, it touched as law as 122. The chart is Cleanly and clearly gotten up, and deserves a place in every broker's office, bank and mercantile establishment in the City.
lead_paragraph: A very curious, instructive and valuable chart, exhibiting the "Fluctuations in the Price of Gold in 1863," (and also last year,) has been gotten up by Mr. J.P. HOWARD, of this City. abstract: By the arrival of the United States steamer A ago at this port and the United States steamer  Massachusetts at Fortress Monroe, we have two days, later news from Charleston Bar.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the United States steamer A ago at this port and the United States steamer Massachusetts at Fortress Monroe, we have two days, later news from Charleston Bar. On Tuesday the Ironsides and monitors engaged the batteries on Sullivan's Island and a shell from the Wech[???]ken exploded one of the magazines in Fo[???] M u[???]ie. Half the town of Moultrieville was destroyed by fire, occasioned by the shelling of the Ironsides, and all the shore-batteries were extensively damaged. After the bombardment had cl[???]ed. Admiral DAHLGREN ordered a boat expedition to advance upon Sumter, in the hope of taking it by storm. The attempt, however, ended in the repulse of the expedition with a loss of sixty men -- among whom were six Lieutenants and an Easign -- and five boats. Gen. GILLMORE's forces were busied in erecting batteries from which to s[???] the city. Four additional pieces of ordnance had been exhumed from the sand on Morris Island, making an aggregate of thirty-six pieces captured by our troops.

abstract: Died, at Clifton, Staten Island, Aug. 19, 1863, Capt. HENRY W. HICKS, Jr., late of the One Hundred and Sixty-fifth regiment, N.Y.V., (second battalion Duryea's Zouaves,) in his 24th year. Capt. HICKS, a son of the late JOHN H. HICKS, a well-known merchant of this City, was among the first to take up arms to assist in putting down the rebellion, having accompanied the Seventy-first regiment N.Y.S.M., from the time of their departure from New York till after the battle of Bull Run. Upon the second call for the militia he again served for three months, this time with the Seventh regiment; and immediately on his return was offered a Captaincy in the second battalion Duryea Zouaves, which he accompanied to New-Orleans December, 1862. He was engaged in all the different assaults upon Port Hudson, in one of which he led the regiment with distinguished gallantry, and by his humane conduct to the rebel wounded after the fight, commanded the admiration of both friend and foe. After the fall of Port Hudson he resigned his commission and came North, but immediately after reaching home he was attacked by typhoid fever, contracted from exposure during the siege, of which he died after a short illness.

abstract: THE DRAFT AMONG THE FIREMEN OF BROOKLYN -- COMMENDABLE ACTION OF MONTAUK ENGINE COMPANY NUMBER TWENTY-TWO. -- The members of this Company held a special meeting on Friday evening last, for the purpose of defining their position relative to the draft. The Company was unanimous in their determination to maintain their organization, draft or no draft, and adopted a series of resolutions to that effect. This Company has already sent a dozen of the number to the war, and now when the chances of the draft have deprived them of seven more, they patriotically refuse to join in any movement having for its object the disorganization of the Volunteer Fire Department of Brooklyn.

abstract: Tecumesh, Iron-clad; Launch
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning the new iron-clad Tecumseh was launched from the yard of Messrs. SECOR, at Jersey City. Thousands of people had assembled to witness the launch, and at 7:45 o'clock the venerable Admirable GREGORY, who was a special guest on the occasion, made his appearance, accompanied by his daughter-in-law, who had consented to christen the iron-clad. The Admiral was accompanied by a number of naval officers, and was greeted with vociferous cheers. Mr. STINER, General Inspector of Ironclads, was among those accompanying him. Soon after, Mr. BIRKBECK, the Superintendent, perfected all arrangements for the launch. The Admiral and his party ascended the deck of the Tecumseh, followed by a multitude of ladies and gentlemen. The bolt was immediately afterward drawn, and, amidst the cheers of thousands, the waving of handkerchiefs and hats, she went handsomely into the water, gliding gracefully upward of quarter of a mile after reaching it. So soon as she was afloat Mrs. GREGORY broke a bottle of wine over the bow, christening the beautiful vessel the Tecumseh.

abstract: Frankfort, the Congress at
lead_paragraph: At latest European dates, the assembled Princes of Germany were still in deliberation at Frankfort, touching the reconstruction of the Federal Union. Notwithstanding the affability and popular deportment of the Kaiser, many of those potentates had expressed uneasiness at the absence of the Prussian King, and therefore it was resolved, immediately after the opening of the Congress, that a joint note should be sent to WILLIAM, inviting him to take part in their proceedings. The sovereign of Saxony was the bearer of this missive, which failed, however, to produce the desired effect.

abstract: The officers at Tarrytown report that the best feeling prevails throughout the district, the people having been satisfied that everything is fairly conducted.
lead_paragraph: The officers at Tarrytown report that the best feeling prevails throughout the district, the people having been satisfied that everything is fairly conducted. However, as a precaution, a regiment of troops from New-York will be distributed throughout the District on the days of the draft. In July last, during the "reign of terror" in this City, the Provost-Marshal's headquarters were seriously menaced. A turbulent class of people from the neighborhood threatened to demolish them and to treat the officers to powder and ball. A crowd of no less than 500 men, partly armed, and all infuriated, had got as far as Irvington, (two miles distant,) on their way to Tarrytown, and were only deterred from invading, and perhaps burning the place, by the salutary intelligence that the Provost Guard and a body of loyal citizens were determined to make deadly resistance. The latter had provided themselves with a brass field-piece, plenty of grape and canister, and good United States rifles, and would have made good their words. Their force, however, was feeble in numbers, and they stood guard for three days and nights, by turns, until relieved by troops sent from this City. In the meanwhile, however, they managed by way of precaution to ship some $80,000 worth of United States uniforms, held by the Marshal on board the Nyack ferry-boat, and send them down to Fort Hamilton for safe keeping. The draft lists and other documents connected with the office were concealed for nearly a fortnight, and all the operations of the draft were suspended. The arrival of a couple of gunboats, which took station in the bay below the town, aided by the presence on land of a strong military force, at length secured immunity from further alarms.

abstract: Mr. SUMNER is to be thanked for his thorough exposition of the course of England and France in respect to our great struggle.
lead_paragraph: Mr. SUMNER is to be thanked for his thorough exposition of the course of England and France in respect to our great struggle. It is something which has long been needed. One of the strangest things of this strange time has been the quietude with which our Congressmen have submitted to these breaches of international law and good faith. They have seemed to ignore entirely the fact that it particularly devolved upon them to appeal to the judgment of the civilized world. Our Secretary of State, and our Ministers in England and France, have done their own appropriate duties well. But their duties were purely diplomatic. Their arguments and their remonstrances were necessarily addressed to the private ear of Government only. They were hound not to know any such tribunal as public opinion. It was for our Senators and our Representatives in Congress to make manifest the indignation of the American people they professed to represent, and to invoke the severest condemnation of all people everywhere against the monstrous injustice we are suffering. It was for them to proclaim how international law, and how American precedent, debarred foreign governments from showing our rebels the slightest favor, and how every moral principle of the age entitled our struggling Government to the moral support of every civilized Power. They did nothing of the kind. From the beginning to the end of the last Congress, there was not a solitary debate, in fact not a solitary speech, of any weight, upon the subject of our foreign wrongs. The everlasting flood of Parliamentary impertinence on the other side of the water was met only by a dead Congressional silence on this. So far as depended on the men in our Capitol, Europe had a right to conclude that the once imperious Republic was thoroughly heartbroken, and ready to submit to any fate PALMERSTON and NAPOLEON might see fit to allot her. This quiescence was the more remarkable, because in such absolute contrast to the old habits. Time was, nay it always was, when a suspected clipper stopped, a stray loafer seduced into enlistment, a Mosquito Indian patronized, a patch of Pacific sand camped upon, a cod and mackerel ground curtailed -- anything, even the ninth part of a hair sometimes, was sufficient to bring down Senatorial thunders which would shake the two continents. And yet here, when there was vital occasion, when foreign Powers were recklessly tampering with the very lifestrings of the nation, there was not the slightest whisper.

abstract: The first great National Horse Fair hereabouts will commence at the Fashion Course, on the 15th of this month, holding four days. The finest stock in the country it is expected will compete for the premiums, which, in the aggregate, amount to $4,500. Among the celebrated horses which are certainly expected present will be Butler, Fillingham, Prince, California, Danville, formerly Columbia, In the course of the Fair there will be exhibitions of equestrianship, driving, mule races, &c. It will be gotten up in a liberal scale.

abstract: A circular from this institution announces that the regular Winter course of lectures will commence on the 19th of October next.. A preliminary course of lectures upon subjects not embraced in the Winter course, will commence on Monday, the 14th inst., and will be free to all students entering for the Winter course. Extra attention will be paid to subjects connected with military hygiene and surgery, in view of the great demand of the country for skill in those departments.

abstract: His Speech on Foreign Relations; Correspondence with the President on Peace
snippet: His Speech on Foreign Relations; Correspondence with the President on Peace
lead_paragraph: FERNANDO WOOD, in his correspondence with the President, made his representations of what "the Southern States" were prepared to do, on the strength, as he said, of "authority which I deem likely to be well informed, as well as reliable and truthful." Whether that authority was an official personage or not, he does not say. If it were not, of course no importance could be attached to it -- no more than could be attached to his own representations of what the Northern States are prepared to do. If it was, how can it be reconciled with the speech made by ALEXANDER H. STEPHENS at about the same time? Surely, if there is anybody connected with "the Confederate Government," who would be more likely than any other man to favor arrangements for the return of the South to the Union, it would be its Vice-President. He was the last public man of the South to yield to the secession movement, and did so then apparently because it was no longer possible to withstand the pressure. Of cool temperament, of magnanimous spirit, and of great discernment, possessing more of the respect of the North, both as a statesman and a man, than any other rebel functionary, and known also to have very little confidence in most of the rebel chiefs, he was the very man of all others to have this desire for reconciliation with the old Government, if there were any such feeling anywhere in the rebel councils. Yet it was just before the date which Mr. WOOD gives as the time when he was advised of what he communicates to the President, that this same ALEXANDER H. STEPHENS delivered a speech in Crawfordville, Ga., published by us soon afterwards, the entire burden of which was an exhortation to the people never to give up. He said:

abstract: A boatman, named WILLIAM FINLEY, aged about 20 years, residing at No. 193 East Twentiethstreet, was fatally stabbed by some man unknown, about 10 o'clock on Tuesday night, on the corner of Second-avenue and Seventeenth-street.
lead_paragraph: A boatman, named WILLIAM FINLEY, aged about 20 years, residing at No. 193 East Twentiethstreet, was fatally stabbed by some man unknown, about 10 o'clock on Tuesday night, on the corner of Second-avenue and Seventeenth-street. The deceased had been on an excursion to Jones' Wood, and was returning to his home in a car of the Second-avenue Railroad. At Seventeenth-street he alighted, and immediately after he reached the sidewalk he was accosted by some man, whose name is unknown, and an altercation ensued. After a few words had passed the unknown man drew a knife, and stabbed FINLEY through the heart, and immediately ran away. FINLEY was taken to the drugstore of Dr. BLAISDELL, in First-avenue, where his wounds were dressed, and then he was removed to his residence. Dr. MOTT and several other physicians attended him, but he died from the effects of his wounds on Saturday morning. Dr. BOUGHTON, of the Coroner's office, assisted by Dr. BLAISDELL, yesterday made a post mortem examination of the body, and the facts elicited by them show that this is one of the most remarkable cases on record. Their evidence is that FINLEY lived three days and nights after a large wound had been made through his heart.

abstract: Kay, J.; Condition and Education of the People of England
snippet: Kay, J.; Condition and Education of the People of England
lead_paragraph: This volume is a republication of the chapters relating to England of Mr. KAY'S book, entitled The Social Condition and Education of the People of Europe, published in London, in 1850. Mr. KAY was commissioned by the Senate of Cambridge University, England, to travel through Western Europe for the purpose of examining the comparative social condition of the different countries, and the result is the work whose title we have just mentioned. Summing up his estimate of the position of England's population, he says on the last page of this volume: "The poor of England are more depressed, more pauperized, more numerous in comparison to the other classes, more irreligious and very much worse educated than the poor of any other European nation, solely excepting Russia, Turkey, South Italy, Portugal and Spain." The kind of social anatomy attempt by the author requires a cool and steady hand and scalpel. Mr. KAY succeeds only moderately well. His book is stocked with facts and statistics; but it utterly lacks the life, humor, and dramatic richness of MAYHEW's London Labor and London Poor.

abstract: The regular boat Matteawan and the opposition boat D.R. [???], which ply between this City and Keyp[???]rt, very greatly endangered the lives of the many passengers on each, on Thursday evening. When opposite Tompkinsvlle, Staten Island, both boats were abreast, and a struggle for supremacy ensued. The Martin closed in upon the Matteawan, and soon the wheelguards of the two were in contact: the latter endeavored to re[???]a[???]lia[???]e by, in this position, crowding her competitor on shore at Fort Tompkins, or compel her to drop off. Both efforts were unsuccessful, however, and at a speed of twenty miles an hour, in a cross sea, in the lower bay, these shamefully managed boats, for twenty minutes, alternately dashed against each other to the great anxiety of some, and the overwhelming alarm of other passengers. Eventually, the Matteawan turned away, and both steamboats arrived at their respective wharves at the same moment, having run thirty miles in an hour and a half. The outrageous conduct on this occasion, to which many would willingly testify, demands the attention of the proper authorities, and it is hoped that they will promptly prevent its repetition.

abstract: Capt. WALLING, of the Twentieth Precinct, aided by Officer IRVING, succeeded, on Friday night last, in effecting the arrest of MATHEW ZWEICK, a native of Germany, aged about 33 years, who is charged with having been a ringleader in the riots, and also with heading a party of about half a dozen ruffians, who murdered and afterward hung a colored man named JAMES COSTELLO, on the 15th day of July last.
lead_paragraph: Capt. WALLING, of the Twentieth Precinct, aided by Officer IRVING, succeeded, on Friday night last, in effecting the arrest of MATHEW ZWEICK, a native of Germany, aged about 33 years, who is charged with having been a ringleader in the riots, and also with heading a party of about half a dozen ruffians, who murdered and afterward hung a colored man named JAMES COSTELLO, on the 15th day of July last. The officers in question are certainly entitled to the thanks of all order-loving and law-abiding citizens for their efforts in securing ZWEICK. They have labored diligently in the work, and it was only after much time spent, and by the most ingenious and skillful management, that they accomplished their object.

abstract: The Park Theatre in Brooklyn will open tonight for the first time. BUCKSTONE'S excellent comedy called " Married Life"--played last season at Wallack's --and the musical burletta of the "Loan of a Lover" are the dramatic attractions of the occasion,
lead_paragraph: The Park Theatre in Brooklyn will open tonight for the first time. BUCKSTONE's excellent comedy called " Married Life" -- played last season at Wallack's -- and the musical burletta of the "Loan of a Lover" are the dramatic attractions of the occasion. But more than these will be the novelty of having in Brooklyn a first-class theatrical establishment, where the better class of residents can pass a pleasant evening without any of the vexatious inconveniences attendant on a visit to a New-York theatre. We are persuaded that there is a profitable field operations for such an enterprise -- provided, of course, that in company, appointments, scenery and music, it is not inferior to its neighbors on this side of the river. These points will be determined to-night, and we hope by a full and competent jury of Mr. HARRISON's fellow citizens.

abstract: By the arrival of the United States steamer Arago at this port and the United States steamer Massachusetts at Fortress Monroe, we have news from Charleston Bar to the 9th.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the United States steamer Arago at this port and the United States steamer Massachusetts at Fortress Monroe, we have news from Charleston Bar to the 9th. On Tuesday last the Ironsides and monitors engaged the batteries on Sullivan's Island and a shell from the Weehawken exploded one of the magazines in Fort M[???]ultrie. Half the town of Moultrieville was destroyed by fire, occasioned by the shelling of the Ironsides, and all the shore-batteries were extensively damaged. After the bombardment had closed, Admiral DAHLGREN ordered a boat expedition to advance upon Sumter, in the hope of taking it by storm. The attempt, however, ended in the repulse of the expedition with a loss of sixty men -- among whom were six Lieutenants and an Ensign -- and five boats. Gen. GILLMORE's forces were busied in erecting batteries from which to shell the city. Four additional pieces of ordnance had been exhumed from the sand on Morris Island, making an aggregate of thirty-six pieces captured by our troops. Rebel advices two days later have come to hand in a Richmond paper received at Fortress Monroe. BEAUREGARD claims to have captured 113 prisoners -- including 13 officers -- in the affair of the navy at Fort Sumter, besides four boats and three colors, including the original flag of Fort Sumter, which was lowered by ANDERSON, and which Admiral DAHLGREN hoped to replace. On the night of the 10th a steady fire was kept up against our batteries on Morris Island, which was unnoticed on our part. Gen. GILLMORE was getting guns in position at Battery Gregg bearing upon Sullivan's Island, and a shell from the rebels on James Island exploded the magazine in that work. There was very little firing on either side on the 11th.

abstract: We have a few additional details of the European news by the City of Manchester, via Cape Race. The Paris Pays denies that our Government...
lead_paragraph: We have a few additional details of the European news by the City of Manchester, via Cape Race. The Paris Pays denies that our Government has either protested or made verbal complaint to the French Government respecting the proceedings of the French in Mexico, and strives to prove that our Government has no right to raise any objection. The Congress of German Princes had concluded its consideration of the propositions of the Emperor of Austria and accepted them. There were rumors of an alliance between France, Russia and Prussia, which, however, were denied by the Pays.

abstract: The Santa Fe Gazette the 22d reports the Navajo Indians still very troublesome and daring. Though a large force has been sent into their country, they send out bunds which range through the Mexican settlements, coming occasionally within a few miles of Santa Fe. Their home is west of the Rio del Norte, yet these predatory excursions reach this side of the Pecos, and as far east as the Canadian. They have driven off stock at half a dozen different places, widely separated. At Chaparita the report was that they had gone off with 10,000 head of sheep from Manza, and they look away 70 head of cattle. Near Chaparita they had a fight with a detachment of New-Mexican volunteers, and killed two of them Such occurrences seem to show that our invasion of the Navajo country has not yet had the salutary [???]. So far from bringing them to terms, it does not appear to have caused them much alarm. -- Missouri Republican, Sept. ll.[???]

abstract: Up to within a few days the army of Gen. LEE was planted on a long line sweeping from near the base of the Blue Ridge Mountains and the upper waters of the Rappahannock to the village of Port Royal on the Lower Rappahannock, some 20 miles below Fredericksburgh.
lead_paragraph: Up to within a few days the army of Gen. LEE was planted on a long line sweeping from near the base of the Blue Ridge Mountains and the upper waters of the Rappahannock to the village of Port Royal on the Lower Rappahannock, some 20 miles below Fredericksburgh. The corps of LONGSTREET was near Fredericksburgh, and the corps of EWELL and HILL, near Culpepper Court-house and Gordonsville. News has been reaching us for some days that important movements were going on in this army of Gen. LEE, and these movements all had the appearance of a general falling back. It has been thought by some that another advance against Washington and the Army of the Potomac was really intended by Gen. LEE, and many apprehensions have been expressed for the result. Even the apparent retrogressive movements were conceived to be only feints covering some dangerous and deep design.

abstract: Rebel and Copperhead Success
lead_paragraph: "Let LEE drive MEADE into Washington, and he will again raise the spirits of the Democrats, confirm their timid and give confidence to their wavering." So it is said in the Richmond Enquirer. It is made the conclusive argument why LEE should again take the offensive. It seems to be recognized in Richmond that there is an intimate connection between the prosperity of the rebels and the prosperity of "the Democrats." The idea is that, the more the Government at Washington can be pressed from the South, the more open it will be to attack from the North, and rice versa; and that therefore the rebels and the Copperheads are a mutual support to each other, and natural allies. MAURY, the rebel agent in England, only put the fact in another form in his recent letter to the London Times, when he said that "all the embarrassments with which the Peace party can surround Mr. LINCOLN, and all the difficulties that it can throw in the way of the War party in the North, operate directly as so much aid and comfort to the South."

abstract: Decline and Fall of the
lead_paragraph: The time has now come when even the most cautious and critical can safely look forward to the speedy termination of the war. We have ourselves, in our treatment of military affairs, continually judged it best to take due note of the strength of the rebels and their cause, and we have on a thousand occasions felt it to be our duty to moderate the ardor or undo the illusions of the public by considerations of the vastness of the task involved in the subjugation of the revolted States. But we rejoice to believe that the worst of the business is now over. Without losing sight of what yet remains to be done, we can still see our way out of it. It is of course vain attempting to anticipate the exact duration of the war; but everything justifies the belief that the end of the year will see its close, and it is certainly fair to believe that the expiration of the three years' term of service for which our army of volunteers enlisted, will witness the task for which they took the field gloriously finished by the complete crushing of the Great Rebellion.

abstract: Departure of for California
lead_paragraph: Mr. F.L. OLMSTED sails to-day for California, where he is about to assume the position of Manager for the Mining Company which has recently purchased the Mariposa estate from Gen. FREMONT. His loss will be felt keenly in the East, not only by troops of warm and admiring personal friends, but by the public, which, for more than seven years, he has served with a fidelity for which, in our day, it has almost ceased to look. It, is less than ten years since he wrote for this journal the remarkable series of letters, which he afterward republished in the volume known as the Seaboard Slave States, and which, followed by the Journey Through the Back Country, and the Texas Journey, have, perhaps, done more to influence public opinion touching the social and economical results of Slavery, than all the rest of the innumerable publications put together, which this absorbing controversy has called forth. In fact, they may be said to have settled at least the economical side of the question in the eyes of all reflecting men here, as well as in England, where the bitterest enemies of the North still quote Mr. OLMSTED's statements as conclusive proof.

abstract: The ill-luck of the  boat expedition to Fort Sumter on the night of the 8th inst., resulting in the capture and killing of nearly all concerned, shows with what tenacity the rebels hold on to the famous work which was knocked into a brick pile almost a month ago, and whose defence will go into history as, perhaps, the most obstinate on record.
lead_paragraph: -- The ill-luck of the boat expedition to Fort Sumter on the night of the 8th inst., resulting in the capture and killing of nearly all concerned, shows with what tenacity the rebels hold on to the famous work which was knocked into a brick pile almost a month ago, and whose defence will go into history as, perhaps, the most obstinate on record. The expedition seems to have been very badly planned and very incautiously executed. Indeed, the story of the affair reads like a skylark of a set of boys. A hundred and fifty men row up to Sumter, as if on a frolic. They land, and attempt an entrance into the fort, when they are fired upon by musketry, and, on the signal, all the batteries bearing on the fort open fire. The result is that the party is badly repulsed, and a hundred and thirteen men, including thirteen officers, are taken prisoners. It is a wonder any of them escaped at all. It was surely unwise in Admiral DAHLGREN to have sanctioned so senseless an enterprise. Fort Sumter is perfectly useless to us until the batteries opposite are reduced. Gen. GILLMORE is steadily preparing to do this; when he has his batteries ready, he will pound Johnston, Moultrie, Beauregard and Bee into surrender, just as he has already done with Sumter, Wagner and Gregg. The navy, meanwhile, can find legitimate employment enough without undertaking any such foolish and fool hardy schemes.

abstract: AN EXTENSIVE CONFIDENCE OPERATOR IN CUSTODY,--THOMAS ALLEN, an individual well known to the police, was taken into custody yesterday, by Officer WILLIAMS, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, on charge of having swindled Mr. SENECA EVERETT, of Wayne County, Michigan, out of $180 in greenbacks. EVERETT was about proceeding to California, and was stopping at the Pacific Hotel, intending to take passage in the steamer to-day.
lead_paragraph: AN EXTENSIVE CONFIDENCE OPERATOR IN CUSTODY. -- THOMAS ALLEN, an individual well known to the police, was taken into custody yesterday, by Officer WILLIAMS, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, on charge of having swindled Mr. SENECA EVERETT, of Wayne County, Michigan, out of $180 in greenbacks. EVERETT was about proceeding to California, and was stopping at the Pacific Hotel, intending to take passage in the steamer to-day. ALLEN cultivated his acquaintance, and discovered his destination, and forthwith said he also was going the same way. EVERETT was a little shy of him at first, but gradually let him into his confidence and became his friend. ALLEN showed his victim a check, signed S.P. STEINWERT & Co., drawn on the American Exchange Bank, and made payable in gold, to the amount of $350. The two computed the number of "greenbacks" this check would bring, and EVERETT thought he had found a pleasant companion for the voyage. On one of their walks about town, ALLEN stated he desired to buy a harness to take to California for his brother, and, as they were near a harness-shop, he thought he would then do it, providing EVERETT would lend him $180 on his check, which he did, and ALLEN passed into the building by one door and out at another, leaving his comrade to find him. This, of course, he did not succeed in doing. The police were more fortunate, however, and on Saturday the operator was taken. He was brought up before Justice DOWLING yesterday, and committed for examination. ALLEN is a rather good-looking young man, of good address, and well calculated to gain the confidence of a stranger. It is stated that he has obtained $350 at one time, and $150 at another, in a similar manner, from unsuspecting countrymen, who could not stay on[???] enough to prosecute him. Mr. EVERETT, however, will remain to appear against him.

abstract: The Army of
lead_paragraph: It has appeared for a week or ten days past that some sort of movement was going on in the army of Gen. LEE, which ever since the retreat from Maryland, two months ago, has been lying sprawling, in gigantic length, along the banks of the Rappahannock and Rapidan Rivers. The intricate and interesting question has been: Was the movement forward or backward? Had LEE been reinforced from BRAGG and JOHNSTON, who could do nothing whatever in the Southwest; and was this army of LEE, with strengthened columns, consisting in fact of nearly the whole military force of the Confederacy, about to seize the opportunity to strike at the Army of the Potomac, and strike again for Washington? Or was LEE's army about to adopt the policy rendered classical by BRAGG and JOHNSTON -- the policy of retreat?

abstract: An important pamphlet, ascribed to an official organ, had been published, entitled "France, Mexico, and the Confederates." It sets forth the interest which France has in recognizing the Confederate States, and the impossibility of the reestablishment of the American Union; maintaining that an American war would be useful to France, if separation between the North and South be definitively pronounced; for the Confederate States would be the allies of France, and would guarantee her from attack from the North, would fulfill her hopes, and her manufacturers would obtain cotton, which is absolutely necessary for them.

abstract: His Diplomatic Circular
lead_paragraph: The circular of the Secretary of State to our representatives abroad is a masterly summing up of the progress of the Union arms during the last twelvemonth, and cannot fail to make a strong impression upon foreign Governments. The rebel agents will find it impossible to impeach the accuracy of any part of it. It is perfectly free not only from any statement which can be disputed or doubted, but from all that grouping and coloring which, if it be skillfully done, is quite as potent as any misstatement, to "make out a case." Throughout, there is a singular air of strict judicial fidelity. The facts are set forth with extraordinary clearness, and exactly as they are. There is no attempt to increase their effect by argument. They are left to force their own conclusion; and to every fair European mind they make the conclusion unavoidable, that the quickest and surest way for European nations to obtain a peace in this country is "to withdraw support and favor from the insurgents, and to leave the adjustment of our domestic controversies exclusively with the people of the United States."

abstract: The Patrie publishes letters from St. Petersburgh stating that a report was current there that a Russian ambassador was about to be sent to Paris, with the mission of preparing the French Government for the resolutions which the Russian Government is about to take in reference to Poland. He would also explain the scheme of a separate constitution for Poland, which would place that kingdom under exceptional conditions going beyond the claims of the Powers. The same letters announce that the presence of the Prince HOUENZOTTERN at Chalons, is considered to indicate an endeavor on the part of the King of Prussia, who exercises great influence over the decisions of the Czar, to establish more intimate relations between the French and Russian Cabinets. La France says: "If Russia, by granting concessions to Poland, gave satisfaction to the Poles and the guarantees demanded by the Powers, France would only have cause for congratulation." The same journal states that it has information from Moscow relative to the scheme of a Constitution, according to which the Russian Government would become constitutional. There would be a Senate of 300 members, and an Elective Chamber of 450.
lead_paragraph: The Patrie publishes letters from St. Petersburgh stating that a report was current there that a Russian ambassador was about to be sent to Paris, with the mission of preparing the French Government for the resolutions which the Russian Government is about to take in reference to Poland. The same letters announce that the presence of the Prince HOUENZOTTERN at Chalons, is considered to indicate an endeavor on the part of the King of Prussia, who exercises great influence over the decisions of the Czar, to establish more intimate relations between the French and Russian Cabinets. La France says: "If Russia, by granting concessions to Poland, gave satisfaction to the Poles and the guarantees demanded by the Powers, France would only have cause for congratulation." The same journal states that it has information from Moscow relative to the scheme of a Constitution, according to which the Russian Government would become constitutional. abstract: There is now very little doubt or at least as little as there can ever be about anything in a war of this magnitude that all the efforts of the rebels will be henceforward devoted to a policy of delay and obstruction, for the purpose, if possible, of protracting the war until the expiration of the term of enlistment of the three years' men of our army.
lead_paragraph: There is now very little doubt -- or at least as little as there can ever be about anything in a war of this magnitude -- that all the efforts of the rebels will be henceforward devoted to a policy of delay and obstruction, for the purpose, if possible, of protracting the war until the expiration of the term of enlistment of the three years' men of our army. The difference between our mode of raising troops and theirs, has formed for some time past a prominent element in their calculations. They have watched closely the expiration of our short terms of enlistment, and endeavored to strike heavy blows after the discharge of large bodies of our troops. LEE's last invasion was carefully planned and prepared so as to take place alter the discharge of the two years' men of HOOKER's army. It failed, mainly because our loss from that cause, great as it undoubtedly was, was very much smaller than was supposed at Richmond, and the terrible series of disasters which have followed it would unquestionably cause much greater despondency than even that which exists at the South, if the leaders did not cherish the hope of being able to hold out until next May, when we shall lose at one stroke all the men in our army, except those who are being raised under the present draft, and the few who have voluntarily entered during the past Winter. They will, therefore, now probably concentrate the remnant of their forces, which together will constitute at least one tolerably formidable army, and play a strictly defensive game, offering every possible obstruction to our advance, obstinately defending all defensible positions, and using the spade vigorously, but carefully avoiding all actions likely to he decisive in their result.

abstract: By the Hansa at this port, and the Arabia off Cape Race, we have our European mails to the 2d inst., and a telegraphic summary of news to the 5th, three days later. Earl RUSSELL has written a reply to the memorial of the Emancipation Society relative to the steam rams in the Mersey, in which he asserts that his attention has long been anxiously directed to these vessels, but in the absence of positive proof that they are designed to commit hostilities against the Government of the United States, he is powerless to interfere. He regrets that the evidence has not been furnished. The Paris Moniteur justifies the welcome given to the pirate Florida at Brest, on the plea that it is the duty of neutrals to permit belligerent vessels to procure means for navigation, and the Florida entered the French harbor to repair damages. A pamphlet, entitled "France, Mexico and the Confederates," has been issued in Paris, which is generally looked upon as expressing the opinions of LOUIS NAPOLEON, and a speedy recognition of the Confederacy by the French Government is anticipated. Russia has signified her intention to grant a liberal Constitution to Poland. The Liverpool Cotton Market was easier; Breadstuffs were steady, and Consols were quoted at 93 3/8@93 3/4. The Confederate loan had further declined on account of our successes at Charleston.
lead_paragraph: By the Hansa at this port, and the Arabia off Cape Race, we have our European mails to the 2d inst., and a telegraphic summary of news to the 5th, three days later. Earl RUSSELL has written a reply to the memorial of the Emancipation Society relative to the steam rams in the Mersey, in which he asserts that his attention has long been anxiously directed to these vessels, but in the absence of positive proof that they are designed to commit hostilities against the Government of the United States, he is powerless to interfere. He regrets that the evidence has not been furnished. The Paris Moniteur justifies the welcome given to the pirate Florida at Brest, on the plea that it is the duty of neutrals to permit belligerent vessels to procure means for navigation, and the Florida entered the French harbor to repair damages. A pamphlet, entitled "France, Mexico and the Confederates," has been issued in Paris, which is generally looked upon as expressing the opinions of LOUIS NAPOLEON, and a speedy recognition of the Confederacy by the French Government is anticipated. Russia has signified her intention to grant a liberal Constitution to Poland. The Liverpool Cotton Market was easier; Breadstuffs were steady, and Consols were quoted at 93 3/8@93 3/4. The Confederate loan had further declined on account of our successes at Charleston.

abstract: THE PARK THEATRE -- FIRST NIGHT OF MR. HARRISON's COMPANY. -- This charming little theatre, the first attempt of our sister city in the dramatic line proper, was opened last night to the fullest house we have ever seen. Long before the rise of the curtain the cheerful placard of "standing room only, left," was placed conspicuously at the door, and hundreds were compelled to go away disappointed. We have already given a detailed description of the house, which for atness and elegance of finish is a credit to the city, and an exception even in the long list of Metropolitan theatres. The bill for the night included "Married Life" and the "Loan of a Lover." The company includes but few well-known names, prominent among which are Mr. G.H. ANDREWS, an "Old Park" favorite, and Miss MARY SHAW, sister to Mrs. HOEY and Mrs. WATKINS. It would not be fair to criticise closely the initial performances of an opening night, and yet it affords us pleasure to state that Mr. HARRISON's cast, scenery and appointments are by no means inferior even to those which at WALACK's last season we so pleasantly remember.

abstract: There was an alarm or fire Sunday afternoon about 4 o'clock, and after it Engine Companies Number Nine and Number Twenty-one came in riotous collision on Second-avenue, between Twenty-first and Twenty-second streets. They had a savage fight, in which knives, stones &c. were freely used. The fight continued so tar as Fourteenth-street, Number Nine being driven. A number of men were severely hurt, and one stabbed, it is thought, fatally. This fight was originated by the runners of the different Companies, the members subsequently participating. The avenue was full of men, women and children, who had to flee for their lives.

abstract: The advance of Gen. PLEASANTON's cavalry, which was commenced on Sunday morning, and resulted in pushing the enemy south of Culpepper, was continued yesterday. Our dispatches state that these troopers had pressed forward to the Rapidan, finding the rebels (probably the corps of EWELL and HILL) massed there in force to dispute their passage. No engagement occurred. Our casualties in Sunday's fighting were three killed and forty wounded -- Gen. CURTER being among the latter, but his injury is slight. We captured five pieces of artillery and forty-three prisoners.

abstract: The ship Snow Squall, Capt. DILLINGHAM, ninety-four days from Penang, arrived at this port yesterday. June 20, lat. 5° 29' north, lon. 93° 25' east, spoke ship Living Age, of Bucksport, from Akyab, for Falmouth, forty days out. July 28, lat. 33° 05 south, lon. 15° 45' east Cape of Good Hope, bearing southeast by east, one-half east, distant 160 miles; 3 1/4 o'clock P.M., made a sail ahead, with which we same up very rapidly. Soon made her out to be a bark standing the same course as ourselves, under whole topsails, we having royal and topmast stun-sails set. Set our ensign, which was answered by the American ensign. We ran under her lee to speak her. As we approached her we observed no name on her stern, which aroused our suspicions. We were soon hailed, "Where from and bound;" which having answered, we asked "What ship?" and received for reply, "Heave to, and I'll send a boat alongide of you." To which we promptly replied, "Aye, aye." At this moment her three starboard ports were opened and as many guns run out, and upon us, we being about a ship's length from her.

abstract: Proclamation Suspending the Writ of Habeas Corpus Throughout the U. S., except in Certain Cases
snippet: Proclamation Suspending the Writ of Habeas Corpus Throughout the U. S., except in Certain Cases
lead_paragraph: Whereas, The Constitution of the United States has ordained that "The privilege of the writ of habeas corpus shall not be suspended, unless, when in cases of rebellion or invasion, the public safety may require it; and, whereas, a rebellion was existing on the 3d day of March, 1863, which rebellion is still existing; and, whereas, by a statute which was approved on that day, it was enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States, in Congress assembled, that during the present insurrection the President of the United States, whenever, in his judgment, the public safety may require, is authorized to suspend the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus in any case throughout the United States or any part thereof; and, whereas, in the judgment of the President the public safety does require that the privilege of the said writ shall now be suspended throughout the United States in cases where, by the authority of the President of the United States, military, naval and civil officers of the United States, or any of them, hold persons under their command or in their custody, either as prisoners of war, spies or aiders or abettors of the enemy, or officers, soldiers or seamen enrolled, drafted or mustered or enlisted in or belonging to the land or naval forces of the United States, or as deserters therefrom, or otherwise amenable to military law, or to the rules and articles of war, or the rules and regulations prescribed for the military or naval services by the authority of the President of the United States, or for resisting a draft, or for any other offence against the military or naval service; now, therefore, I, ABRAHAM LINCOLN, President of the United States, do hereby proclaim and make known to all whom it may concern, that the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus is suspended throughout the United States, in the several; cases before-mentioned, and that this suspension will continue throughout the duration of the said rebellion, or until this Proclamation shall, by a subsequent one, to be issued by the President of the United States, be modified and revoked. And I do hereby require all magistrates, attornies and other civil officers within the United States, and all officers and others in the military and naval services of the United States, to take distinct notice of this suspension and give it full effect, and all citizens of the United States to conduct and govern themselves accordingly, and in conformity with the Constitution of the United States, and the laws of Congress in such cases made and provided.

abstract: Democratic State Convention and the Crittenden Resolutions
snippet: Democratic State Convention and the Crittenden Resolutions
lead_paragraph: A public journal that has not character enough to invoke rebuke, may yet have absurdity enough to excite a laugh. The World yesterday, in an article extolling the platform of the Democratic State Convention, declares that "the Republicans must face the responsibility of having brought on the war." Yet the very platform it so praises embraces a resolution "that the present deplorable civil war has been forced upon the country by the Disunionists of the Southern States now in arms against the constitutional Government." Stultification like that is always ridiculous.

abstract: the Private Schools
lead_paragraph: The TIMES for the last few weeks has contained daily from one hundred to one hundred and fifty advertisements announcing the opening of the fall and Winter terms of the various educational institutions in this City and its vicinity. It is not our purpose in these columns to single out, or call special attention to any one or any class of these schools, academies, or colleges; for we doubt not that in the tens of thousands of households, in City and country to which the TIMES is a daily and welcome visitor, the announcements have been and will be carefully read, and the merits and character of each of the institutions, as set forth in the advertisement, or as implied in its title, or as learned by experience, duly weighed, and a decision arrived at as to which of them is best adapted for the nurture and well-being of the hopeful "olive branches."

abstract: A fertile genius in the Virginia rebel Senate was shamefully snubbed lately in what was supposed to be an attempt to secure the peaceable dissolution of the United States. He offered a resolution in that body proposing that each Confederate State send three Commissioners to each of the loyal States of the Union, charged to say to the Governors thereof that they demanded that the people ...
lead_paragraph: -- A fertile genius in the Virginia rebel Senate was shamefully snubbed lately in what was supposed to be an attempt to secure the peaceable dissolution of the United States. He offered a resolution in that body proposing that each Confederate State send three Commissioners to each of the loyal States of the Union, charged to say to the Governors thereof that they demanded that the people of the loyal States decide by the ballot-box in favor of the separation of the South from the North in peace! After two and a half years vain endeavor by war to get the Northern approbation for the sundering the Union, this noble Virginia Senator thought it not unwise to try the virtues of oysters and champaigne plied by skillful Peace Commissioners, who would, of course, be received with all the honors at the capitals of the Northern Slates. But the stern pride of the Virginia Senate would not condescend to the means proposed, and tabled the resolution, 38 to 1.

abstract: The Supervisors' Committee to investigate the riot damages, claims are very busy in the performance of the delicate and responsible duty intrusted to them. They sit daily from 2 to 7 o'clock P.M. Each member of the Committee has a desk and a clerk, and makes separate examinations, but all in one room. When any doubtful point arises, all members are called to consult upon it. The Committee intend reporting a number of claims for payment at the meeting of the Board to-day.

abstract: Gov. Vance on Discontent with the Confederacy
snippet: Gov. Vance on Discontent with the Confederacy
lead_paragraph: The popular dissatisfaction with the Confederacy has become so widespread in North Carolina, and the manner of giving expression to it grown so open and violent, that Gov. VANCE has been compelled to take public notice of the matter, and employ the prerogatives of his office to enforce the duty of domestic peace. Gov. VANCE is supposed to be no friend to the Administration of JEFF. DAVIS, and it is notorious that to the bold teachings of his own newspaper organ, the Raleigh Standard, are mainly due the insubordinate uprisings of the people now witnessed in North Carolina. Nevertheless, as the chief executive officer of the State, enjoined to see the laws enforced and peace maintained in its borders, he has felt bound to issue a proclamation solemnly warning the people against the excesses they are running in O. He regrets to hear of the meetings that have been held in various parts of the State, "in some of which threats have been made of combined resistance to the execution of the laws of the [Confederate] Congress in regard to Conscription and the collection of taxes." Gov. VANCE tells the people that these are "the laws of the land," and that combined resistance to them is "high treason." Until these laws are adjudged "unconstitutional" by the [Confederate] Supreme Court, he (Gov. V.) will see that they are "executed."

abstract: The cavalry and mounted infantry of the Sixteenth army corps, under the direction of Gen. CARR, at Corinth, have been active during the past week, going as far south as the Tallahatchie, and stampeding the rebel cavalry into Grenada and Okalona. Gen. CARR also scattered the rebel RHODDY'S forces, in the vicinity of Jacinto and Rienzi.

abstract: REMARKABLE  ESCAPE OF SEVEN CHILDREN.--Betwen 7 and 8 o'clock, on Monday night, a wagon, containing six little girls, being driven by a boy 13 years old, along the embankment of the New Jersey Railroad, a short distance west of the Bergen iron bridge, was suddenly precipitated down the deep cut, a distance of about fifty feet, to the railway track below.
lead_paragraph: -- REMARKABLE ESCAPE OF SEVEN CHILDREN. -- Betwen 7 and 8 o'clock, on Monday night, a wagon, containing six little girls, being driven by a boy 13 years old, along the embankment of the New Jersey Railroad, a short distance west of the Bergen iron bridge, was suddenly precipitated down the deep cut, a distance of about fifty feet, to the railway track below. An alarm being immediately given in the neighborhood, parties with lights hastened to the scene of the disaster, and succeeded in rescuing the unfortunate children from their perilous position just in time to escape a passing train, which a few seconds later swept over the spot upon which the helpless little ones were lying prostrate and insensible. The whole party were borne to a house near by, where they received every care and attention that their bruised and breeding state demanded. Medical aid was procured, and upon examination, it was thought that none of them were fatally injured. When fully restored, the children were removed to their homes in Brunswick-street, Jersey City. The boy driver proved to be in a state of complete intoxication. Apparently fearful of punishment for the injuries he had occasioned, he refused to give his name or furnish any particulars whatever of the affair. The other children stated that he had been sent with the horse and wagon for grain from some brewery, where the men had given him beer until he became drunk. The wagon was smashed, but the horse escaped with but slight injury.

abstract: -- The regular dramatic season opened at this establishment Monday afternoon, and was greeted by an attendance that literally overflowed the establishment. An extraordinary play called "Brunhilda." was produced. It is said to be from the German, and is certainly mysterious enough for any paternity. The characters are drawn from the grave, and sent to it with a celerity that is truly astonishing. We see more of them in the other world than this, and hence the "spectral illusion of the ghost" shines to great advantage. The few characters that are represented find able interpreters in Messrs. J.E. NAGLE, JOHN FLOOD, HADAWAY, HAVILAND, HOLLAND. Mesdames J.J. PRIOR. OLIVE YARDLEY C. ALLFORD, EMMA LE BRUN, JULIA BROWN. &c. The performances concluded with the farce of "Marriage at any Price." Between the pieces the Indians gave one of their characteristic performances.

abstract: The result of the election that has just taken place in Maine is gratifying, but so little surprising that it has arrested not half the attention it deserves. The returns show that the Union ticket has succeeded by a greatly increased majority over the Copperhead nominations headed by BION BRADBURY. Thus in one State after another do the masses of loyal people, of all political parties, unite and render their crushing verdict against the domestic traitors who would lower the dignity and power of the republic before a pestilent set of rebels in arms. The friends of the Union who conducted the late canvass in Maine, deserve credit for their zealous labors; but it is most true, nevertheless, that the gallant soldiers of the Union army who fought at Gettysburgh and Vicksburgh, took all the life, if not all the poison, out of the Copperheads of the North. The vision of the Union restored has become too vivid to the eyes of all true patriots for them to allow any "flaunting lie," representing its division, to be hung out anywhere in the North. It is VALLANDIGHAM's turn to be scotched next.

abstract: There is little additional information from the Army of the Potomac. Our special correspondent telegraphs that Gen. PLEASANTON's command on Monday reached the Rapidan at Raccoon Ford, finding a considerable force of infantry posted to dispute his further advance. An engagement was the result, but details have not been received. Gen. FOSTER telegraphs from Fortress Monroe [???] LEE's headquarters are now at Richmond, whither the bulk of the rebel army is also to be found.

abstract: -- The Swiss Shooting Festival, which has been got up on a grand scale in this City, for the benefit of the widows and orphans of the Swiss who have fallen dining the present war in the service of the Union, commences at Jones' Wood this morning, and will continue for four days in succession. The riflemen and amateurs who are to take part in the contest for prizes will assemble with their friends at MULLER's, on the corner of Elizabeth and Grand streets, and thence proceed along Broadway, Park-row, Chatham-street, Bowery and Houston-street, to the Second-avenue [???] in the following order: The Societies with their [???] the markers, corps of riflemen and un[???] marksmen in [???] headed and followed by music. At Jones' Wood they will be received with a salute of six pieces, [???] which the [???] will take place at the grant [???], where the President of the Society of Swiss Ma [???] Mr. [???] deliver a welcoming [???] The shooting for prizes will begin a'[???]noon [???] and the dancing commence at 2 and last [???] 9 P.M. On the second day, the shooting will open at 7 A.M., and the festivities of the of the day continue until 9. The third day will be like the second. The fourth or Friday, the 19th, will open with shooting for prizes at 7 A.M., continuing until 3 P.M. At 3, will commence a vocal concert by the celebrated singing club. "The A[???]on," who have kindly volunteered their agreeble and artistic aid. The prizes will so far as possible, be distributed at 6 P.M. A table [???] served with all the delicacies of the season, is another advantage which host SOMERS offers, and the dancing music will be furnished by H[???]RSCHMANN's delightful Central Park Band. There will, no doubt, be plenty of so song, sentiment and oratory, but speakers are particularly requested by the Committee not to touch upon American politics. This is the first attempt to establish in this country on a grand scale the great Shooting Festivals of Switzerland, and the charitable and patriotic purposes for which it has been organized will render the affair a memorable one not only to our Swiss and German, but to our native population. Moreover, the scene and the weather other manifold attractions to the tired citizen in search of amusement and novelty beyond the busy streets of the Metropolis.

abstract: When the Missouri Slaveholders began, seven years ago, the practice of making raids into an adjoining territory for the purpose of murdering and plundering everybody who happened to object to the extension of Slavery, and its introduction among them, the groans and lamentations of the Kansas people furnished a good deal of amusement to the very same men at the North who are now horror-stricken by the threats of Gen. JIM LANE.
lead_paragraph: When the Missouri Slaveholders began, seven years ago, the practice of making raids into an adjoining territory for the purpose of murdering and plundering everybody who happened to object to the extension of Slavery, and its introduction among them, the groans and lamentations of the Kansas people furnished a good deal of amusement to the very same men at the North who are now horror-stricken by the threats of Gen. JIM LANE. When Lawrence was sacked in 1856, by ruffians from all parts of the South, the general verdict of our Copperheads was, that it served it right, for what was it but a nest of horrible Abolitionists. Providence, however, sometimes so arranges matters that crime shall, even in this world, bring on its own punishments, and the present condition of Slavedom is, perhaps, the most awful example the world ever saw of retributive justice. Feriocity on one side of the line naturally produced a desire for vengeance on the other. The "Red-Legs," who now propose to invade Missouri, and lay waste a whole "tier of counties," by way of retaliation, are the moral offspring of the Missouri "Red-Shirts" of 1856. If there be anything fanatical and ferocious about them, the Missourians have themselves to thank for it. If you treat men as wild animals, they acquire at last the fiercest passions in self-defence, and Northern Copperheads have to-day no more right to be astonished or horrified by the threats of LANE than to be shocked because a dog, pursued with a red-hot poker, bites his assailant.
