abstract: We lately expressed our conviction that no great results would be achieved by our navy, until it was distinctly realized that Charleston harbor had to be besieged, as it ...
lead_paragraph: -- We lately expressed our conviction that no great results would be achieved by our navy, until it was distinctly realized that Charleston harbor had to be besieged, as it could not, according to the precedents of naval warfare, be bombarded and assaulted; and that the essence of such a siege consisted in reconnoitering the obstructions and subaqueous defences under water, and removing them by judicious, well-planned work, also under water -- work which could be well done only when the true nature of these obstacles and defences was thoroughly known.

abstract: RESULT OF THE CORONER's INVESTIGATION. -- Coroner, WILDER last evening concluded the inquest in the case of WM. FINLEY, who was stabbed on the night of the 8th inst., by some person unknown, in Second-avenue, near Sixteenth-street -- an account of which has been published in the TIMES. The jury rendered the following verdict, viz.: "That the deceased came to his death from exhaustion produced by hemorrhage, the result of a stab-wound received at the hands of some person to the jury unknown." There is very little prospect that the mystery attaching to this homicide will be cleared up at present.

abstract: Orders have been received by the officers superintending the construction of the iron-clad vessels Puritan and Dictator, at this port, to have them finished as soon as circumstances will permit. The Onondaga, the Quintard battery now at Greenpoint, is also to be hurried up with all convenient speed, and the four navy iron-clads are to be put in readiness for service without delay. Rumors in naval circles say, that a whole fleet of ocean iron-clads is to be completed at the different Navy-yards immediately.

abstract: The arrival at this port of the United States dispatch boat Mary Sanford, from Charleston bar on the evening of Saturday, the 14th, effectually disposes of the recent rumors that Fort Moultrie had displayed the white flag, and that the half of James Island was in our possession. Neither of these desirable events has, as yet, occurred. Our forces on Morris Island, when the Sanford left, were hard at work constructing batteries, and Ports Moultrie and Johnson were delivering a lively but ineffectual fire at them. The author of the white-flag report was, doubtless, deceived by the fact that the rebel colors are almost entirely white, and at a moderately short distance a person ignorant thereof would pronounce them to be a flag of truce. Our special correspondent writes from the New-Ironsides an interesting letter describing the recent failure of the naval attack on Sumter, and other topics connected with operations in that quarter.

abstract: Stumping the North
lead_paragraph: It would appear from the Richmond Enquirer, that fraternal feeling has so far revived at the South that Southern politicians are anxious to act once more with their old allies, the Northern Democrats, at the approaching election. We have always doubted the statements made by FERNANDO WOOD and others of his way of thinking, as to the willingness of any considerable portion of the Secessionists to cooperate with their old associates in winning victories at the polls, but the article to which we have referred so strongly confirms the view of the matter taken by these gentlemen, that we cannot permit ourselves to doubt any longer. The Enquirer expresses the greatest anxiety for the success of the "Northern Democratic party," which it appears is already so nearly on a par with its antagonist, that "the least advantage thrown in its favor will insure its success." The mode in which the writer proposes that the South should lend its aid in the matter, will probably be pronounced by some captious persons somewhat irregular; and there is no denying that it does seem a little singular. But the eccentricity can easily be accounted for by ascribing it to the warmth of the Southern temperament, and the extreme violence which has of late characterized the proceedings of the Abolitionists. The Enquirer suggests, in short, that the South should aid the Democratic party by deputing LEE "to advance once more on MEADE." "Let him," says it, "drive MEADE into Washington, and he will again raise the spirits of the Democrats, confirm their timid, and give confidence to their wavering." And it adds:

abstract: The Committee on the Riot Damage Claims presented a report stating that as many of the claimants are in impoverished circumstances, a rule had been adopted to act upon claims of $500 and under first. Four hundred claims of this class have been examined in the order in which they were filed with the Comptroller. Nearly 2,000 claims have been referred to the Committee. The main facts upon which they require proof are ownership of property, its validation, and the precise time of the loss. The Committee say that some curious questions, unknown to the Courts, have arisen in the course of their investigations. They reported 118 claims for payment, at an aggregate sum of about $12,000, and unfavorably upon 36 cases, amounting to a total of about $2,500. Those reported favorably the Board directed to be paid by the Comptroller as fixed upon by by the Committee. The claims denied are for loss of wages of workmen, and for rents lost by vacation of premises. The Committee follow the law of 1855 in arriving at their decisions. They recommend the waiving of the legal limitation of three months as the time in which suits for damages must be commenced, as required by the law of 1855, and directing their counsel to act accordingly, for the reason that parties are setting up suits in view of a possible enforcement of this right to non-suit them.

abstract: The investigation in this case will be resumed this morning, at 9 o'clock, before Justice DOWLING, at the Tombs. The affair is creating considerable interest among all parties concerned. Mr. WILSON and his friends assert that the whole thing is a deep laid conspiracy on the part of certain persons to extort money or to injure him in his business. The charge pending against Mr. WILSON, the proprietor, ALEXANDER SIMPSON, the foreman, GEO. A. CAMERON, WM. CAMERON, Mrs. J[???]ANNETTE CAMERON, Mrs. MARY WELSH, LIZZIE WELSH and DAVID H. BROWN is that of arson in the first degree. The fact that a man, who was in the habit of sleeping in the building, was burned to death, would make it this grade of crime if any. Our readers will remember that several other large buildings on Gold and Fulton streets were burned at the time of this conflagration, and over $100,000 worth of property was destroyed. Mrs. LAR[???]IN, the principal witness in the case thus far, is reported to have suffered very severely since this bakery was destroyed. A few months ago Mrs. LARKIN and her son TERENCE were badly injured from the effects of an explosion which took place at a bakery in Cherry-street. Young LARKIN has since died of the injuries then received. More recently a younger son was injured in an affray and died from the effects.

abstract: We earnestly hope it is intended to hold military possession of East Tennessee, as well as of the other parts of the State. This is, above all, important on military grounds, as we have explained very often, and as is obvious to every one who comprehends the first principles of military operation. It is also important on moral and political grounds.
lead_paragraph: We earnestly hope it is intended to hold military possession of East Tennessee, as well as of the other parts of the State. This is, above all, important on military grounds, as we have explained very often, and as is obvious to every one who comprehends the first principles of military operation. It is also important on moral and political grounds. We have had nothing in the course of the war so touching and cheering as the glorious reception accorded to Gen. BURNSIDE and his gallant army by the people of East Tennessee. It is a bright and beautiful picture that attracts and fascinates us, and elevates our hopes and feelings, so long depressed by gazing upon the dark and lurid war-scenes hung all around in the galleries of the nation. The welcome given to our troops -- the joy of the exiles on returning to the homes from which they had fed, and to which they returned as soldiers of the Union -- the relief brought to those of deathless loyalty who crawled forth from the caves and hiding-places in the mountains -- the patriotic bursts of women, children and old men, as they brought forth and flung from their house-tops the flag of the stars which they had so long concealed with pious care and affection -- the joyous shouts from a hundred hill-tops that echoed through the valleys as our advancing banners were descried, -- events such as these stir up every soul possessed of feeling or love of country. We have had a few such examples of the same kind before during the war, but of very limited extent -- as when, twenty months ago, our gunboats ascended the Tennessee River to Florence, and as when our troops advanced into some parts of Western Arkansas.

abstract: The frigate Roanoke which, after the Monitor and Merrimac battle in Hampton Roads, was brought to this City, and here razeed, heavily ...
lead_paragraph: -- The frigate Roanoke which, after the Monitor and Merrimac battle in Hampton Roads, was brought to this City, and here razeed, heavily plated with iron and furnished with a seven feet iron horn, was to be kept, it was popularly supposed, in the harbor of New-York for the City's defence against a sudden attack from the rebel iron-clad rams, or from any other enemy. In July last, when these alterations upon her were completed, she was sent on a trial-trip to Fortress Monroe, but the fact that she was so imperatively demanded here led everybody to believe that she would be hastened back as soon as possible. For over two months past, however, she has lain idly at the mouth of the James River. She is supposed to be watching for the descent of the rebel war-vessels that are lying in the immediate vicinity of Richmond. She cannot now be needed for this purpose, as the frigate Minnesota, with an armament of sixty guns, composed of nine 11-inch pieces, and four 200-pounder Parrots -- being in fact, about the heaviest armed ship afloat -- is on this duty; and moreover, the Minnesota has for consort the monitor Sangamon and six or seven stout gunboats.

abstract: A few days since Coroner NAUMAN held an ante-mortem examination at Bellvue Hospital, in the case of a domestic, named GERTRUDE WEBER, who had been beaten so badly that she was not expected to recover. The testimony then given went to show that GERTRUDE had been in the employ of Mrs. MARGARET ROMING, or REHMANN, a German woman, living at No. 311 Fifth-street. Mrs. R. for some cause discharged the girl, and the latter, a day or two after her discharge, went back to the house for the purpose of obtaining her trunk. Mrs. R. tried to prevent her from taking the trunk, whereupon a quarrel ensued. The gir[???]testified that during the mel[???]e she was badly beaten by Mrs. R., who tried to put her out of the house. Being unable to do this alone, she called to her assistance a brother of hers, who was living in the same house. The two finally put GERTRUDE into the street, but not until she had been severely bruised and maltreated. The testimony of the physicians showed that several of her ribs were broken, and she was otherwise much injured. The jury, upon the ante-mortem, rendered a verdict that the girl came to her injuries from blows received at the hands of Mrs. R. and her brother. The two were thereupon arrested and held to bail. Yesterday a notice was received by the Coroner that GERTRUDE had died at the Hospital. A post-mortem examination of the body was made, when the physicians found that in addition to her broken bones, there were indications of a positive character going to show that an abortion had been effected upon her very recently. This state of the case has rendered it necessary for the Coroner to adjourn the inquest for the purpose of obtaining testimony which will enable him to sift the matter, and, if possible, to bring all the guilty parties to punishment.

abstract: The first  of a series of discourses was delivered Sunday evening, on the above subject, at the Tabernacle of the Christian Allfance, by the Pastor, Rev. C.C. Goss. It was somewhat introductory, showing the importance of great cities as centres of great influences. Corinth, Antioch, Athens, Rome, Paris and London were cited as exerting a vast influence upon the surrounding region. Reforms had their origin in large cities.
lead_paragraph: -- The first of a series of discourses was delivered Sunday evening, on the above subject, at the Tabernacle of the Christian Allfance, by the Pastor, Rev. C.C. Goss. It was somewhat introductory, showing the importance of great cities as centres of great influences. Corinth, Antioch, Athens, Rome, Paris and London were cited as exerting a vast influence upon the surrounding region. Reforms had their origin in large cities. Our own City is the metropolis of the nation. The statistics of trade, banking, production, consumption and population were given, showing the rapid and increasing growth of wealth and influence. No city had ever grown to such dimensions in so short a time. When it was seized by the English, it contained only 1,500 inhabitants. In 1700, at the taking of the first Federal census, it had increased to 33,131. The following table shows the average increase for each ten years from this period to 1860.

abstract: The Northern Bee, of St. Petersburgh, in its issue of Aug. 27, has this editorial paragraph: "The intelligence that the United States will declare war against France and England, if those Powers engage in hostilities with Russia, appears to us extremely doubtful. It is possible that a treaty may have been signed between Russia and the Northern States, but its stipulations assuredly do not make any such obligation incumbent upon America. Our relations with the Washington Government have always been excellent, but have never yet led to similar engagements."

abstract: The County Substitute and Relief Committee yesterday acted upon about eighty applications, and sent out seventy-one substitutes. Several applicants were denied aid, either for the reason that they were entitled to exemption under the National law for alienage, support of aged parents, &c., or because they were unable to satisfy the Committee of the condition of indigence necessary to secure them the benefits of the ordinance. Of the seventy-one substitutes sent out, five were rejected upon medical examination.

abstract: Paris correspondents of the London papers declare that the publication of a recent pamphlet in Paris on Mexican and Confederate affairs, "heralds unmistakably the prompt if not immediate recognition of the Southern Confederacy by the Emperor." All we need to say in this connection is, that if NAPOLEON entertains any such purpose as is indicated, every day's delay is a day lost. His recognition should be prompt, even "immediate," unless he wishes to become the laughing-stock of nations by acknowledging the existence of a Power only after it had ceased absolutely to exist.

abstract: The notorious guerrilla, Capt. RUCKER, has at length been recaptured. He was, it will be remembered, confined in Gratiot-street Prison, last Winter, and effected his escape by digging out. Since his escape he has cooperated with JACKMAN in robbing and scattering terror among loyal men. It was RUCKER who captured Gen. BARTHOLOW, at his house, in the dead of night, pretending that he was a messenger from GUITAR.

abstract: There has been but little doing at Quarantine the past week. The reports received there are to the effect that yellow fever in all infected ports is losing its epidemic character, and is purely sporadic. In Havana, Matanzas, Nassau and Vera Cruz this is its character now. Not a vessel the past week has arrived with a case of lever on board, and there is not a case in the hospital.

abstract: Between 4 and 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, the large four-story building known as Nos. 71, 73 and 75 East Twenty-second-street, took fire, and before the flames could be extinguished the entire structure was destroyed. The first floor was occupied by Mr. W.H. PERRY as a marble factory. The loss on this establishment will not fall much short of $20,000. Mr. PERRY is insured in the Park and Brevoort Insurance Companies for $5,000. The second, third and fourth floors were occupied by Messrs. DOMER & LANSBURGH as a piano manufactory. Their damage will amount to over $10,000. The insurance could not be ascertained. No. 6[???], owned and occupied by Mr. CARNEY as a stable, was entirely destroyed. His loss is about $4,000; insurance not ascertained. The flames extended to the dwelling-house No. 10 Lexington-avenue, owned and occupied by Mr. GEORGE DUBAL. This building was damaged about $500; loss on furniture about $300. The origin of the fire is at present unknown.

abstract: Observations in
lead_paragraph: During the past twelve months of the war, it has been seriously doubted by many persons whether the people of the seceded States would ever willingly return to their duty as citizens of the United States -- and out of this conviction has sprung, as a necessity, the theory lately promulgated, of remitting all the seceded States to the condition of Territories, to be thus held until a new population occupying them should seek admission, with possibly new State lines, into the National Union. The restoration of the Union, however, to the living form it had when traitor hands were raised against it, "with not a star dimmed nor a stripe erased," is the cherished idea of the great majority of the American people; and not until all hope is lost of the return of the seceded States to the Union, with their old names and under loyal organizations, will they consider any new mode of dealing with them. It is gratifying to us to say that we are in possession of information that gives the strongest assurance of returning loyally in one of the late insurgent States, (Tennessee,) and that the work of reconstruction there and return to the Union is likely to be both rapid and easy.
headline: {'main': 'Observations in Tennessee.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Observations in Tennessee.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Decision in the Baldinger Habeas Corpus Case; Proclamation, the; the Baldinger Case; Views for the Times
snippet: Decision in the Baldinger Habeas Corpus Case; Proclamation, the; the Baldinger Case; Views for the Times
lead_paragraph: We publish, this morning, an extended report of the proceedings before Judge BETTS in a habeas corpus case, with the decision of the Judge in full. It is highly important as being the first decision reported upon the effect of the recent habeas corpus Proclamation. Judge CLERKE, in the Supreme Court, made similar decisions in two cases, but his opinion in the matter has not been published. Judge BETTS, as will be seen, holds that the effect of the Proclamation is such as not only to prevent the issuing of the writ of habeas corpus in the cases which it specifies, but also to stop all proceedings in such cases in which the writ has been already issued, and he accordingly leaves the man whose case was brought before him in the hands of the military authorities, to be tried by them for the crime of desertion, with which he was charged. His argument, in brief, is as follows: The Government has the right to defend its national existence, and in order to do this it has the right to call for the services of every man, whether he be under age or not. And it has the further right to say, if it deems it to be necessary, that in the proceedings which it thus takes to defend itself, it will not have the military interfered with by the civil Courts, but will have any questions which arise as to the payment of this military service by the citizen, passed upon by the military tribunals, to whom the decision of such cases belongs. This is effected by suspending the writ of habeas corpus in such cases as the President has the power thus to suspend it; if not from his position as the head of the Government, then by virtue of the act of Congress. This power he has seen fit to exercise, and the civil Courts accordingly must take no further action in such cases.

abstract: It has been ascertained that among those killed at Gettysburgh was WILLIAM MITCHEL, a son of JOHN MITCHEL, now well known to be connected with the editorial department of the Richmond Enquirer. He was a private in the First Virginia regiment, and had fought most gallantly in all the battles in Virginia. He was about eighteen years old -- just in the dawn of manhood -- and had given bright promise of future usefulness as a soldier and as a citizen. Two brothers of the deceased are in the service.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports, items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met yesterday, and concurred in overruling the Mayor's veto on the resolution granting the right of the streets for laying mains, for a period of fifty years, to the "Anthracite Gas-Lighting and Heating Company." The vote was 12 to 3, Messrs, FROMENT, MASTERSON  and JEREMIAH voting in the negative.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met yesterday, and concurred in overruling the Mayor's veto on the resolution granting the right of the streets for laying mains, for a period of fifty years, to the "Anthracite Gas-Lighting and Heating Company." The vote was 12 to 3, Messrs, FROMENT, MASTERSON and JEREMIAH voting in the negative. The old ordinance against bell-ringing in the streets having recently been enforced by the Police, the junk men (rag-gathers) petitioned for protection. An ordinance was offered by Mr. MITCHELL, and adopted, permitting them to use bells as heretofore. In accordance with a recommendation of the Mayor, resolutions were adopted to extend Municipal courtesies to the officers of the Russian war-frigate Osliabo, Capt. J. BOUTAKOFF, now lying in the harbor. A communication was received from the City Inspector, recommending the prohibition of fat and bone boiling and skinning of dead animals within the City limits. An accompanying draft of an ordinance for the purpose was laid over. A resolution reported by the Railroad Committee was adopted, directing the Corporation Counsel to proceed against all the parties who have laid rails in the streets without the authority of the Common Council, for the recovery of penalties and damages, and also directing the Croton Board to remove all such rails. Adjourned to 1 o'clock P.M. next Monday.

abstract: Unconditional Union Committee on Slavery
lead_paragraph: The Unconditional Union Committee of Maryland advise the people of that State, in the address which we published Wednesday, to abolish the institution of Slavery at the earliest possible period. "The substance of Slavery," they say, "is gone, and they are of opinion that the sooner the skeleton is removed the better will it be for the true interests of the State and of the nation." In Delaware the disappearance of the slave population has been almost as rapid as in Maryland, and the people seem to manage to get along very comfortably without them. In Tennessee the military operations have almost completely destroyed this species of property: something similar has taken place in Virginia, and Louisiana and Missouri, and we may safely predict that at the close of the war nothing but "the skeletons" will be left in any of these States, and we may be sure it will not be long permitted to remain.

abstract: Io triumphe! The day of deliverance has dawned at last, and the chains are riven from the limbs of the noblest peope that ever breathed God's air. Free at last! Free as their own mountain air, they stand erect in all their manhood. Freed, too, without the loss of a single one of their deliverers by battle--their oppressors fled as much from the moral power of their loyalty as from the bayonets of Gen. BURNSIDE.

abstract: We publish a highly important letter from our Paris correspondent. It opens up and explains the recent and extraordinary diplomacy of NAPOLEON in Europe, and shows that the Emperor has been and is rather hardly pushed by fortune. "NAPOLEON's position of European dictator is at an end, and hereafter he will have enough to do to take care of himself." So, at least, "Malakoff" assorts and shows. We give, also, an interesting abstract of the foreign news, taken from our foreign files by the Arabia, which arrived yesterday at Boston.

abstract: is going to die when all is lost
snippet: is going to die when all is lost
lead_paragraph: -- Senator TOOMBS, of Georgia, so far from being an advocate of reconstruction, has announced his intention, "when all is lost, of uniting with the thousands of his countrymen who have found honorable deaths, if not graves, on the battle-field." His announcement is highly characteristic. It proves that TOOMBS is as great an enemy of the useful and practical as he ever was. Nothing can be plainer than that now is the time for him to die. To wait till "all is lost" is simply to throw his life away. If he wants to turn his existence to some account, the plan is to place himself at the service of the Confederacy while there is yet hope, and when soldiers of any age are so much needed. If the rest of the Southern people were to follow his example, and stay at home, saving themselves for the sacrifice until all sacrifice was in vain, there would soon be an end to the rebel armies. So we hope he will reconsider his decision. We think we are but speaking the sentiments of most Northern people, when we invite him earnestly and affectionately to expose his person to our fire at once. We make this appeal as much for his own sake as that of the Confederacy. Little as we value him, we should surely prefer hearing of his having fallen on the battle-field, to hearing that he had been reduced to the painful necessity of making away with himself after the fighting was all over.

abstract: The great Swiss Shooting Festival was continued yesterday, but not with the large attendance which had been expected, and which the noble object involved certainly would seem sufficient to invite. The shooting at the main targets "Liberty" and "Switzerland" did not take any considerable range, but they wiil probably be the favorites on Saturday, the last and great day of the fete. The marksmanship at the two smaller ...
lead_paragraph: The great Swiss Shooting Festival was continued yesterday, but not with the large attendance which had been expected, and which the noble object involved certainly would seem sufficient to invite. The shooting at the main targets "Liberty" and "Switzerland" did not take any considerable range, but they wiil probably be the favorites on Saturday, the last and great day of the fete. The marksmanship at the two smaller targets was very fine, and continued from early in the morning until sundown, the varied costume of the markets of the game and the riflemen giving the scene the appearance of an assault upon the outworks of some embankment defending the approaches of a fortress. Among the costumes yesterday were some representing ancient and modern historical characters of Switzerland, the Three Men of Grutli, ARNOLD WINKELREID.
headline: {'main': 'The Swiss Schuetzenfest Second Day.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Swiss Schuetzenfest Second Day.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A very able address has just been delivered before the Cadets of the Virginia Military Institute by Mai.-Gen. FRANCIS H. SMITH, its Superintendent, on "The Li[???]e and Character of Lieut.-Gen. THOMAS J. JACKSON, late Professor of Natural and Experimental Philosophy" there. A perusal of it will well repay for the time spent, giving as it does many new facts in relation to the character of the great hero who has gone. It is an interesting fact that when the Board of Visitors of the Institute was looking for a suitable person to till the vacant chair to which JACKSON was chosen, the Faculty of West point submitted to them the names of Gens. MCCLELLAN, ROSECRANS, RENO and G[???]STAVUS W. SMITH, besides that of JACKSON. The lecture-room of the great professor is still draped in mourning for his death.
lead_paragraph: A very able address has just been delivered before the Cadets of the Virginia Military Institute by Mai.-Gen. FRANCIS H. SMITH, its Superintendent, on "The Li[???]e and Character of Lieut.-Gen. THOMAS J. JACKSON, late Professor of Natural and Experimental Philosophy" there. A perusal of it will well repay for the time spent, giving as it does many new facts in relation to the character of the great hero who has gone. It is an interesting fact that when the Board of Visitors of the Institute was looking for a suitable person to till the vacant chair to which JACKSON was chosen, the Faculty of West point submitted to them the names of Gens. MCCLELLAN, ROSECRANS, RENO and G[???]STAVUS W. SMITH, besides that of JACKSON. The lecture-room of the great professor is still draped in mourning for his death.

abstract: TRAVELERS' CLUB. A number of gentlemen met at the Debating Room, Cooper Institute, on Wednesday evening last, for the purpose of taking preliminary measures to organize a Travelers' Club in this City. There were present traveled gentlemen residing in this City; also, several from California, Arizona, Spanish America and other distant localities. EDWARD E. DUNBAR was chosen Chairman, and WM. B. ...
lead_paragraph: TRAVELERS' CLUB. -- A number of gentlemen met at the Debating Room, Cooper Institute, on Wednesday evening last, for the purpose of taking preliminary measures to organize a Travelers' Club in this City. There were present traveled gentlemen residing in this City; also, several from California, Arizona, Spanish America and other distant localities. EDWARD E. DUNBAR was chosen Chairman, and WM. B. HARTLEY Secretary. The Chairman gave an outline of a plan upon which to establish the Club, and explained the objects of the institution. The subject was discussed with much enthusiasm and entire harmony. It was resolved that the Travelers' Club should be thoroughly cosmopolitan in its character, and far-reaching in its benefits. Matter of great import touching vast undeveloped resources of our country and continent was elicited in the discussion, and if this preliminary meeting is any indication of the social and intellectual enjoyment that would be realized under a perfected organization, then the Travelers' Club is destined to speedily become a most attractive and useful institution. "The Chairman was authorized to appoint a Committee to draw up a prospectus, setting forth the objects of the Club, and perfect a plan of organization. Mr. DUNBAR was invited to deliver a public address under the auspices of the organization, early in October. The meeting adjourned, subject to the call of the Chairman.

lead_paragraph: -- We took occasion, last Spring, to caution the farmers of Southern Illinois against too extravagant expenditures in the experiment of cultivating cotton on their home lands. But, notwithstanding, a very large outlay was incurred, tons of seed were bought and brought to Cairo for distribution and hundreds of acres of land along the line of the Illinois Central Railroad were devoted to prospective cotton crops.

abstract: At an early hour this morning the cavalry corps again moved forward. But a little distance had been made when skirmishing commenced. Several other charges were made, and the enemy were finally driven across the river.

abstract: Notwithstanding the frightful ravages of war in the States of Arkansas, Tennessee, Mississippi and Louisiana, that have been recovered from the rebellion, the injuries inflicted are not without their compensations. Houses may have been burned and slaves may have been demoralized or fully emancipated, but the soil remains unharmed, and it is still capable of yielding in undiminished quantities that staple which the world clamors for, and cannot do without.
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the frightful ravages of war in the States of Arkansas, Tennessee, Mississippi and Louisiana, that have been recovered from the rebellion, the injuries inflicted are not without their compensations. Houses may have been burned and slaves may have been demoralized or fully emancipated, but the soil remains unharmed, and it is still capable of yielding in undiminished quantities that staple which the world clamors for, and cannot do without. And it is encouraging to know that amid all the derangements and confusion of the war, and in presence of marching and fighting armies, there has still been a steady and persistent effort of the non-combatant portion of the Southern people to grow as much as possible of that product that has hitherto sustained and enriched them. When we read of an army's march through a State -- say Mississippi -- and consider the story of desolation in its pathways and on the right and on the left, we are apt to think that a universal ruin has been inflicted. But the fact is that in those immense States the breadth of an army's march is but a line, and the farms wasted bear a small proportion of the myriad farms that remain unvisited and unharmed. And on all these latter, patient industry is doing its work and striving to accumulate supplies that shall keep the owners from the widespread want that is befalling other sections.

abstract: A yankee Lieutenant and seventeen men were captured yesterday morning by the militia on Walker's Mountain, twelve miles from Marion, in Smythe County. They were making their way to the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad, with the intention to arrive these in time to catch a train after dark. They were armed only with navy revolvers. They say there are 800 more in Abbs's Valley, in Tazewell County.

abstract: Sixty-two substitutes were sent out by this Committee yesterday; eight of them were rejected. The Committee having been informed that some persons designed defrauding the County by falsely representing themselves to be in an indigent condition, they have taken the strongest precautions to thwart any such purpose. Each application must undergo thorough scrutiny before it is passed upon, and under the searching inquiries made by the vigilant acting Chairman, Supervisor BLUNT, coupled with other careful guards against deception, which it would be improper to mention here, it will be difficult for any one to deceive the Committee. If it shall be discovered that any dishonest applicant has succeeded in imposing upon them, the Committee will make quick work in bringing him to punishment. It has been discovered that some militia officers, whose names will soon be ferreted out, are offering for a "consideration," to admit conscripts to their corps, and to certify to their membership as having existed before the ordinance was passed. Conscripted m???tlamen are, therefore, examined with special care, and under oath, as to the time when they joined the militia and how much military duty they have performed for the past two months. These inquiries were too close for two parties yesterday, and they were turned away without aid. In one case, a man declined to be sworn for examination, and hastily backed out, when he found that he could not pass without this formality.

abstract: The news from the Army of the Potomac looks as if there were likely to be action on the Rapidan soon. We learn from Philadelphia that the body of Gen. MEADE's army advanced to the line of the Rapidan on Thursday, and the rebel force there is believed to consist of the two corps of EWELL and HILL -- or about two-thirds of LEE's army. There has been some brisk skirmishing and a number of casualties. Our army is reported to he in the highest condition, and prepared once more to give a noble account of itself.

abstract: The remains of the gallant Col. M.K. BRYAN, of the One Hundred and Seventy-fifth New-York Volunteers, arrived here yesterday, from New-Orleans. They were taken charge of by Mr. CARROLL, the undertaker, and will be laid in state at the Governor's Room, City Hall, this afternoon at 2 o'clock, remaining until 2 P.M., Monday, when, with appropriate honors, they will be escorted to the Albany boat, and delivered to the officials of that city, of which deceased was a resident. The honors paid here are under the supervision of the Committee on National Affairs, Alderman FARLEY, Chairman, and will be such as are due to one of the most gallant and thorough officers this State has furnished the country. Col. BRYAN's regiment was largely enlisted from this City; it was engaged at the assault on Port Hudson, and it was there that Col. BRYAN, while nobly leading on his men, was killed.
lead_paragraph: The remains of the gallant Col. M.K. BRYAN, of the One Hundred and Seventy-fifth New-York Volunteers, arrived here yesterday, from New-Orleans. The honors paid here are under the supervision of the Committee on National Affairs, Alderman FARLEY, Chairman, and will be such as are due to one of the most gallant and thorough officers this State has furnished the country. Col. BRYAN's regiment was largely enlisted from this City; it was engaged at the assault on Port Hudson, and it was there that Col. BRYAN, while nobly leading on his men, was killed.

abstract: -- Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest yesterday on the body of a man named JACOB RECTOR, who died at Bellevue Hospital from the result of injuries received by being beaten on the head by man named -- BOYLAN. RECTOR was quietly walking along Forty-  seventh-street, at a late hour of the evening, when BOYLAN suddenly came up behind him, struck him several blows on the head, and knocked him down. For some time he lay in a senseless state, until finally he was picked up by the Police and conveyed to the hospital, where he died soon after. The jury rendered a verdict "that deceased came to his death from blows received on the head, at the hands of -- BOYLAN." The deceased was 49 years of age, and resided at No. 245 West-street. For the last two years he has been out of his mind, but he was regarded by all who knew him as being a very harmless man. BOYLAN made his escape immediately after committing the assault. The Police of the Twenty-second Precinct are quite confident that they will be able to effect his arrest.
lead_paragraph: -- Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest yesterday on the body of a man named JACOB RECTOR, who died at Bellevue Hospital from the result of injuries received by being beaten on the head by man named -- BOYLAN. abstract: At an early hour this morning the cavalry corps again moved forward. But a little distance had been made when skirmishing commenced. The enemy were driven about three miles to the Rapidan River, where an infantry force was encountered. Gen. BUFORD ordered a charge, and the charging party was repulsed. Several other charges were made, and the enemy were finally driven across the river.

abstract: The Latins said that the mysterious, or the unknown, was always sublime omne ignotum pro magnifico; and if this be correct, the war and its campaigns must at this moment be characterized as altogether magnificent. We are quite at a loss as to the position of the two rebel armies which we have been accustomed to call their main armies.
lead_paragraph: The Latins said that the mysterious, or the unknown, was always sublime -- omne ignotum pro magnifico; and if this be correct, the war and its campaigns must at this moment be characterized as altogether magnificent. We are quite at a loss as to the position of the two rebel armies which we have been accustomed to call their main armies. We can get no clue as to what projects they may have on hand, what strategy they may be carrying out, or what is their condition and hopes. LEE -- where is he? BRAGG -- whither has he fled? We know some places where they are not. We know that LEE has lately abandoned his lines on the Rappahannock, for we have reconnoitered them. We know that BRAGG has evacuated his great stronghold at Chattanooga, for we occupy it. But beyond, we are in the dark. Good authority places the bulk of LEE's army around Richmond; better authority places at least two of its three corps on the Rapidan; and highly reliable authority has hurled at least a half of it down between the ranges of the Alleghanies to overwhelm Gen. BURNSIDE. Gen. BRAGG, again, performed the last of the series of masterly retreats that carried him out of Tennessee by flying from Chattanooga in the first two days of this month; and we know that his retreat was in a southerly direction. But where did he stop? Has he got as far down as Atlanta, as some say, or is he resting his legions at Rome, or is he still hovering in the mountains near Chattanooga, preparing to retrieve his fortunes, and to start with a reinforced army upon some startling venture? If LEE is at Richmond, what then? Has he gone there to stay till we make another call upon him? If he has but one corps at Richmond, and two on the Rapidan, will he expose the latter to assault from the Army of the Potomac, which has now advanced to the Rapidan? In regard to dispatching troops to East Tennessee, would JEFF. DAVIS have dared to deplete the Virginia army at such a critical moment as this? On all these points our readers, probably, know as much as ourselves, and quite as much as is known to the military authorities.
headline: {'main': 'The Mysteries of the War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Mysteries of the War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- The butchers, at their adjourned meeting, were united in their opposition to Inspector BOOLE's plan for removing slaughter houses, but they did nothing beyond appointing a Committee to keep an eye on the proposed ordinance, and when it shows itself to make war upon it. Perhaps a quiet, dispassionate discussion of the merits and demerits of the proposition of the Inspector may convince them that it is not so unjust and arbitrary as they now imagine, and that in this, as in all sanitary measures which he has adopted, he has sought the greatest good for the greatest number, and at the same time at no time ignoring minority interests, unless they be in direct conflict with his sense of duty.
lead_paragraph: -- The butchers, at their adjourned meeting, were united in their opposition to Inspector BOOLE's plan for removing slaughter houses, but they did nothing beyond appointing a Committee to keep an eye on the proposed ordinance, and when it shows itself to make war upon it. abstract: -- The aspect of affairs is very different from what it was a year ago. Then we were on the tenter-hooks of anxiety about the first invasion of Maryland. The battles of Bull Run Second, and Chantilly, had resulted unfavorably for us; our troops had been drawn in toward Washington while LEE's army crossed the Potomac, and we were reading every morning of the raids here and there of his cavalry, of the occupation of town after town by his forces, of the investing of Harper's Ferry and its disgraceful surrender, the marching of our forces, and all the gathering of the storm which, till it broke at Antietam, filled the hearts of the people with uncertainty and fear. In the West, too, Kentucky was suffering from a rebel invasion, and the citizens of Cincinnati, en masse, were hastily fortifying to meet a rebel attack. Loyal men everywhere were cast down; Copperheads everywhere were loud-mouthed and impudent.
lead_paragraph: -- The aspect of affairs is very different from what it was a year ago. Then we were on the tenter-hooks of anxiety about the first invasion of Maryland. abstract: The highly important letter from our Paris correspondent, which we published yesterday, revealed the latest diplomatic manoeuvrings of the Imperial juggler of France, who for some time has controlled the destinies of Europe, and who has lately been attempting to grasp and guide the helm of the world.
lead_paragraph: -- The highly important letter from our Paris correspondent, which we published yesterday, revealed the latest diplomatic manoeuvrings of the Imperial juggler of France, who for some time has controlled the destinies of Europe, and who has lately been attempting to grasp and guide the helm of the world. Having failed in his efforts to bully Russia, to wheedle Austria, to use England -- to bring about a general European war that would enable him to extend French boundaries, magnify his own power, and dazzle mankind with his glory -- he now, after having swallowed the insult administered to him by GORTSCHAKOFF, makes friendly advances to Russia, tries to put a check on the federative schemes of Austria, and treats England with his most "distinguished consideration." It is a feat of legerdemain worthy of the third NAPOLEON. The object of it all is, that, having just made an unsuccessful exhibition of his art before Europe, he might get into position to try his hand on this continent -- to carry out his scheme in Mexico, the "grand scheme of his reign," as he himself is credibly reported to have characterized it.

abstract: The exercises of the great Swiss shooting festival recommenced yesterday at the usual hour, but were attended by few, owing to the unfavorable weather. The shooting -- which was, as usual, excellent -- was interrupted at different times during the day by the rain, which also greatly interfered with the dancing and other festivities. Distinguished guests who were expected did not come, but various drawbacks did; and in fact, Friday may be considered the dies nor of the festival.
lead_paragraph: The exercises of the great Swiss shooting festival recommenced yesterday at the usual hour, but were attended by few, owing to the unfavorable weather. The shooting -- which was, as usual, excellent -- was interrupted at different times during the day by the rain, which also greatly interfered with the dancing and other festivities. Distinguished guests who were expected did not come, but various drawbacks did; and in fact, Friday may be considered the dies nor of the festival.

abstract: The St. Louis Democrat states that guerrillas are growing much more numerous and bolder. A band has recently been ranging south of St. Louis in the country east of the Iron Mountain Railroad. It is said to have captured Fredericktown, and retained possession for one whole day. It next entered and committed extensive robberies at Irondale, on the Iron Mountain Railroad, and from thence moved off to the west of Pilot Knob, stealing horses, and occasionally shooting at Union men. Pilot Knob is thought not to be free from danger, and some Union men in that section are bringing their most valuable effects to St. Louis for safety.

abstract: By the arrival at this port yesterday afternoon of the steamship City of Cork, from Liverpool Sept. 5 and Queenstown Sept. 7, we have Cork papers to the 7th inst. -- two days later. The news is not important. The question of the recognition of the rebels by France was still a topic of newspaper discussion, and the victualling of the Florida at Brest was considered a still more explicit declaration of NAPOLEON's intentions in this regard than the late pamphlet on "France, Mexico and the Confederate States." The [???] from Mexico to offer the crown to the Archduke MAXIMILIAN had arrived, and it was considered positive that he would accept it. The insurgents in Poland on the 3d inst. drove 300 Russian troops across the Gallician frontier. Consols after official hours, closed at 93 5/8 to 93 3/4.

abstract: We are in expectation of stirring news from the Department of Gen. ROSECRANS. The combined and rapid advance of this chief and Gen. BURNSIDE evidently took Gen. BRAGG by surprise, and compelled the abandonment of Chattanooga. The evacuation of this place was not intended by the Confederates. Since the first of this year they have been at work upon it, steadily increasing its fortifications, and trying to make it impregnable.
lead_paragraph: We are in expectation of stirring news from the Department of Gen. ROSECRANS. The combined and rapid advance of this chief and Gen. BURNSIDE evidently took Gen. BRAGG by surprise, and compelled the abandonment of Chattanooga. The evacuation of this place was not intended by the Confederates. Since the first of this year they have been at work upon it, steadily increasing its fortifications, and trying to make it impregnable. They meant to hold it to the last, and were sure they could do so. But, as in the case of Columbus, Fort Pillow, Memphis, Corinth, Vicksburgh and Port Hudson, they only spent their labor for the benefit of Nationals. As soon as their work was done at Chattanooga, they quietly gave up the place to Gen. ROSECRANS.

abstract: The Richmond Examiner brings to light the most astounding facts in regard to the destitution of Government officials in Richmond. It appears that the Confederate office-holders, instead of "fattening out of the public crib," as they are proverbially and metaphorically supposed to do, ar[???] actually supporting existence only through[???] the charity of their friends. Says the Examiner: "The ladies who are employed as note-signers receive $75 per month. It is a matter of favor alone if they can get their board for that sum. Their clothing, washing, medical attendance if sick, and other necessary expenses, have to be contributed by their friends." Now, the question arises, if such is the condition of persons who have salaries of $900 a year, what must be the fate of those who have no salaries at all? If "friends" support the best paid officers of the Government by contributions, who is able to support the friends? And what is the case of those unhappy mortals, office-holders or not, who have no friends at all? With shoes at $30 and $50 per pair, as quoted by the Examiner, and everything else in proportion, it is obvious that somebody must pay. In the name of DE BOW, MEMMINGER, and all the financiers of the South, we ask who feeds and clothes the people of the Confederacy?

abstract: COUNTY SUBSTITUTE AND RELIEF COMMITTEE.  At the session yesterday there were 63 applicants for relief, all of whom were sent, as usual, to the Enrolling Boards of their respective districts. Seven of the number were rejected, thus leaving 56 men for whose substitutes the Relief Committee are to pay $300 each, being in all $16,800. The Committee's work his required uncommon industry on the part of...
lead_paragraph: COUNTY SUBSTITUTE AND RELIEF COMMITTEE. -- At the session yesterday there were 63 applicants for relief, all of whom were sent, as usual, to the Enrolling Boards of their respective districts. Seven of the number were rejected, thus leaving 56 men for whose substitutes the Relief Committee are to pay $300 each, being in all $16,800. The Committee's work his required uncommon industry on the part of the clerks, who found it impossible to post up close to the close of the session of yesterday, but at a late hour yesterday afternoon they courteously rendered the following figures, which are all that are material. Of the 650 substitutes thus far provided, 350 are for indigent citizens, 150 for militiamen, 100 for firemen and 50 for policemen. This number is regarded with complacency by Comptroller BRENNAN, Supervisor BLUNT, and others of the Committee, as an assurance that there can be no need of the entire $2,000,000 which was voted by the Supervisors, and that the sum which has been subscribed -- nearly a million -- will cover the ground contemplated by the Board of Supervisors. The amount thus far paid to substitutes, and to the few conscripts who chose to accept the Treasury notes and go themselves into camp, is, as nearly as can be estimated, $185,000 only.

abstract: -- Rev. Dr. Pease, of Rochester, whose death was announced a few days since, was born in Connecticut on the 12th of September, 1813, and was therefore 50 years of age at his death. While yet a boy his father removed to Vermont. At an early age he graduated at the University at Burlington. Soon after receiving his degree he became a teacher in Montpelier, and was not long after elected to a Professorship in the University. After discharging the duties of his Professorship for some time, he was at length called to the Presidential chair -- a position which he occupied for several years -- and continued to hold, with great credit to himself and advantage to the University, up to November, 1861, when he was called to the pastorate of the church in Rochester.
lead_paragraph: -- Rev. Dr. Pease, of Rochester, whose death was announced a few days since, was born in Connecticut on the 12th of September, 1813, and was therefore 50 years of age at his death. abstract: Mr. SCHOLEFIELD, the member for Birmingham dined with the Birmingham [???] Brew[???] Protection Society a few days ago, and acknowledged the toast of "The Borough Members." He [???] that the prine p[???] point on which he and his [???] representation (Mr. BRIGHT) differed was with respect to the American civil war, Mr. BRIGHT looking upon it probably as a war for the [???] of the slaves. He thought that when an impartial history came to be written of that contact, it must be stated to be, on the part of the North, as against the South, the most cruel and causeless war that was ever waged by a powerful against a weaker nation. He believed when men talked of emancipating the slaves by [???] of arms, they talked of that which was the most difficult measure if emancipation that could possibly be. He was as favorably disposed toward emancipation as Mr. BRIGHT. He [???]ated Slavery as much as any man in the world could hate it, but he believed from the bottom of his heart that Slavery was not to be abolished by force of arms. It must be abolished by the same means which we in this country employed in our own colonies, by remonstrances and by putting our hands in our pockets to compensate those whom we had induced by our own laws to consider slaves as their property.

abstract: Frankfort Congress, the Close of the
snippet: Frankfort Congress, the Close of the
lead_paragraph: The Frankfort Congress have closed their labors, and dispersed. The propositions of FRANCIS JOSEPH underwent little or no modification, and his Majesty professes to be perfectly satisfied with the result, which he thinks will prove most beneficial to Germany. That the Kaiser is satisfied with the issue we may well believe, since it places him at the head of the Confederacy, gives him a right to German aid in defence of his non-German possessions, and authorizes the employment of Federal troops in the suppression of State revolutionary movements. But whether it will prove as beneficial to Fatherland as the Kaiser imagines, or afford as much satisfaction to the people at large as it does to himself and his brother sovereigns, may be fairly doubted. How, for instance, can a scheme prove beneficial to Germany, to which the must enlightened and the most powerful, save one, of the Teutonic States, is wholly opposed, and the forcible carrying out of which may lead to the creation of two hostile confederacies instead of national unity? Or how can a scheme prove beneficial to Germany which will oblige her, in the event of a Hungarian or Venetian insurrection, to send forth her sons to sustain, beyond the Danube or the Alps, the schemes and cause of Austria? But if the Austrian scheme is little calculated to prove beneficial to Germany, still less is it calculated to give satisfaction to her people. Neither the Kaiser nor his colleagues condescended even to notice[???] the suggestions of the deputies simultaneously assembled at Frankfort; consequently the proposition touching the election of the Lower Chamber remains unaltered, and the choice of its members is vested in the Legislatures of the several States. Yet it is expected that the people should be satisfied with a system which allows them no representation in the Federal Diet -- no control over the Federal Government -- and which denies them as Germans a right that as Prussians, Saxons, Bavarians, Wurtembergers, &c., they have long enjoyed.

abstract: Aggression from Abroad--its powers
lead_paragraph: What is the aggressive power of France against this country, whether in invading our territory, supporting the Confederacy, or holding its own in Mexico? The London Times, always prepared to belittle our power and exaggerate that of our adversary, whoever he may be, asserts that "there is a general conviction that the protest" of the United States Government "will now be feeble and be wholly unattended with any threats," and considers that "the first really offensive threat against NAPOLEON would be the signal for the deliverance of the Confederates." We see reason to take quite a different view of the case.

abstract: The newspapers of our sister city are rather lively at the present moment. The advent of the new paper, the Union, has proved to be quite an event in local history. It his stirred up its cotemporaries to great energy, and has already attained a large circulation. Both the Union and the Eagle depend in great measure on local news for their interest and success, as the people of Brooklyn look to the leading journals of this City, and particularly to the TIMES, for discussions of military and political movements, war correspondence, and telegraphic intelligence. There is enough of local news and local gossip in Brooklyn to fill the columns of both papers daily. Both of these journals have had the good fortune to secure the services of writers and reporters until lately connected with the TIMES. Mr. MOORE's faithful and careful labors have appeared in each issue of the Union; and Mr. HOWARD, formerly in charge of our City department, gives animation and vivacity to the local columns of the Eagle. In its political principles, and in its patriotic position, the Union has a vast advantage over the Eagle, and even with the greatest local enterprise on the part of the latter, the Union is likely soon to take the lead in the Brooklyn Press, for it certainly reflects the principles of the people of the City of Churches more truly than the Copperheaded Eagle.

abstract: Officer MCDOUGALL, of the Detective force, yesterday arrested EDWIN NOYES, of Waterville, Me., upon the charge of being a defaulter. Mr. NOYES was stopping at the Astor House, and from the best information which could be obtained, was to take the steamer at 12 o'clock for Europe. He is charged with being a fugitive from justice from the State of Maine, where for several years he was Superintendent and General Manager of the Maine Central Railroad, -- formerly the Androscoggin and Kennebec and Penobscot Railroads. The Directors of the road some months since discovered that there were defalcations to the amount of over $10,000 in their cash account. After a great deal of time spent in making an examination of their affairs, they finally came to the conclusion that NOYES was the defaulter. A further inquiry showed that Mr. NOYES had invested very largely in United States Securities and Western Railway Bonds. The testimony against him was so overwhelming that the Director determined to cause his arrest, and for that purpose caused the necessary steps to be taken. When the Sheriff went for him, it was found that he had just left for New-York. A telegraph dispatch to Police Headquarters, however, had the effect to stop Mr. NOYES as he was about embarking for Europe. Detective MCDOUGALL took him to Police Headquarters, and soon thereafter a requisition arrived from Maine, and the accused, in charge of an officer, started last evening for Augusta. Mr. NOYES is a middle-aged man, a lawyer by profession, and is known to be a man of much talent and executive ability. Up to a very recent period he had the entire confidence of the Board of Directors, whose business he managed for many years to their satisfaction.

abstract: Houston, Gen. Sam., Ex-Governor of Texas
snippet: Houston, Gen. Sam., Ex-Governor of Texas
lead_paragraph: -- The Richmond papers record the death of Gen. Sam Houston, of Texas. His decease has been so often reported that its present announcement will be received with many doubts. The event is stated to have occurred at his residence in Texas, on the 25th of July last. It is a little singular that this intelligence was not received long since. Still the report may be correct. The life of Gen. Houston has been a most eventful one, full of strange and stirring incidents. He was born in Rockbridge County. Va., in 1793. His father, an officer in the war of the Revolution, died in 1807, leaving a widow and nine children. Soon after, Mrs. Houston and all her children crossed the Alleghany Mountains and took up their residence near the Tennessee River, then the boundary between white men and the Cherokee Indians. Sam was soon placed in a country store; but was thus employed only a few weeks when he ran off, and spent several months among the Cherokee Indians. When eighteen years of age he enlisted as a private in the United states Army, and was soon made an Ensign. He distinguished himself at the battle of the Horse Shoe, under Gen. Jackson, in 1814, and was dangerously wounded. After peace he was made a Lieutenant, but resigned, and studied law in Nashville. He was soon after elected District-Attorney of Davidson County, Tenn., and Major-General of the State, and in 1823 was sent to Congress. He was re-elected in 1825, and chosen Governor in 1827. This latter office, in consequence of u domestic affliction, he resigned in 1829, and again made his home among the Cherokee Indians, with whom he remained for three years, and became exceedingly popular with them. Subsequently he was elected a member of the State Convention which met at San Felipe de Austin in 1833, and after adopting a Constitution, addressed a memorial to the Government of Mexico setting forth the reasons why Texas should be recognized as one of the States of the Mexican Confederacy. The distinguished part Gen. Houston took in the war that followed this movement is well known. He was the first President of the new Republic in 1836, and was again elected to the same office in 1841. On the admission of Texas into the Union, in 18[???] he was elected to the United States [???], where is served several years, and on his final return to Texas he was again chosen Governor of the State. This office he held for a short time after the war broke out, but resigned at the demand of the Secessionists, and has ever since lived, in retirement.

abstract: Habeas Corpus Decision in Michael Cox Case
snippet: Habeas Corpus Decision in Michael Cox Case
lead_paragraph: We hope none of our readers who have taken an interest in the discussion of the authority of the State Courts over the Provost-Marshals and other officers of the United States, will fail to read the decision of Judge WHITE, of the Superior Court, in this City, in the case of the habeas corpus of MICHAEL COX. The conclusion to which the Judge came, viz., that the case was one which must be turned over to the decision of the Federal Courts, is well known to our readers. They will find the process by which he arrives at that result clearly stated and forcibly sustained.

abstract: Capt. SIMS, of the Fifty-first New-York Volunteers, attached to the Ninth army corps, has just returned to this City to endeavor to secure enough drafted men to fill up the regiment to its maximum strength. It went out from this City, under Col. FERRERO, 1,300 strong, and now, by its arduous services in North Caroliana, Kentucky and at Vicksburgh, it is reduced by the casualties of war to 68 effective men, who are at Camp Nelson, Kentucky, awaiting recruits to enable it to join Gen. BURNSIDE in East Tennessee. Capt. SIMS brings with him, as a testimonial to what the regiment has assisted in accomplishing, the following orders from Gens. GRANT and SMITH:

abstract: STATEMENT OF A REFUGEE FROM STAUNTON VA. -- We have had a conversation with a very intelligent young printer, who escaped from the forces of the rebel Maj.-Gen. SAMUEL JONES, now in Western Virginia (and who was previously in Richmond, employed in the office of the Whig, who made his escape into Maj.-Gen. KELLEY's lines, in West Virginia, a few days since. We publish the following as a statement of facts adduced from the young man's story. Gen. JONES' army is composed of men who are ragged, miserable and heartily tired of the war, and desired the terrible conflict to cease. They have heard the news of our splendid victories, and are depressed thereat.

abstract: We have one day's later advices from Charleston by the arrival of the steamship McClellan. Gen. GILLMORE is still sedulously engaged in mounting heavy guns at Fort Wagner and Cummings Point to bombard the city. The fire from the rebel works on James Island had proved somewhat annoying to the working parties, but casualties were few. The Columbia brought 100 rebel prisoners taken at Fort Wagner.

abstract: Congre ational Address to American Congregational Union
snippet: Congre ational Address to American Congregational Union
lead_paragraph: At the last meeting of the Congregational Union at Dundee, it was resolved to send the customary fraternal address to the members of the American Congregational Union. An address has accordingly been drawn up, and appeals in the Scottish Congregational Magazine for this month. The address is signed by Rev. ROBERT SPENCE, Mr. DAVID M'LAREN, Mr. JOHN LANG and Mr. WILLIAM J. COX. After noticing how closely the two countries are united "by the ties of common parentage, language and religion," and stating that they regard the present unexampled calamities which have overtaken America as God's judgments against national sin, and especially the sin of Slavery, the address expresses the hope that their American brethren may be enabled to look away from man, and say this evil is from the Lord, and that they may put away from them the sin of Slavery. The address then proceeds: "There are not wanting tokens that this will be the happy issue. Most heartily do we congratulate you on those recent measures of your Government which have tended so much in this direction. In the treaties spontaneously entered into for the effectual suppression of the African Slave trade: in the abolition of Slavery in the District of Colombia; in its prohibition 'in the Territories of the States;' in the facilities which other enactments give to the ultimate extinction of Slavery in all your States; and in the recognition of the free Governments of Liberia and Hayti, we see evident indications of a just perception of the great cause of your present troubles, and have hope that it will are long be taken out of the way. We know not what may be the political results of the unhappy conflict now raging. That in both sections into which your States are at present divided the ultimate issue will be the extinction of Slavery, we entertain not a doubt." The address concludes by trusting that it may please the Lord to has en the blessed day when the sword shall be bear a into the [???]share, and when the present previous affliction shall yield the peaceable fruits of righteousness.

abstract: A gentleman of St. Louis, on Monday received a letter from Quartermaster MARVIN, of the Sixtieth E.M.M. regiment, stating that on Saturday evening the commander of the post at Clinton, Henry County, Mo., received a letter from QUANTRELL, ordering him to remove the women and children, as he intended to attack the town on that evening. The St. Louis Democrat learns further that the soldiers of the Seventh M.S.M. are burning all the houses of rebel sympathizers all along the border, and the rebels in retaliation are firing the property of the Unionists remaining. A fearful state of things exists in all the border counties.
lead_paragraph: A gentleman of St. Louis, on Monday received a letter from Quartermaster MARVIN, of the Sixtieth E.M.M. regiment, stating that on Saturday evening the commander of the post at Clinton, Henry County, Mo., received a letter from QUANTRELL, ordering him to remove the women and children, as he intended to attack the town on that evening. abstract: At the Tabernacle, No. 446 Broadway, quite a large audience assembled last evening to hear the second discourse of Rev. C.C. Goss upon the above subject. The choir, consisted of some twenty young Misses, opened with singing "All hail! the power of Jesus' name." After the usual opening exercises, and the taking of a collection in behalf of the Poor Fund of the Christian Alliance, the speaker said that his object this evening was to show the numbers and relative influence of the various nationalities in our midst, and urge the diffusion of the Gospel as the only means to harmonize and blend them.

abstract: We publish this morning a decision of Judge NELSON, sitting in the United States Circuit Court, at Cooperstown, in a habeas corpus case, which is of interest and importance to all the Boards of Enrolling Officers, and to all who may appear before them. It seems that a drafted man was claimed to be exempt as the elected son of a widow, and on application to the Board of Enrollment the claim was allowed, and an endorsement to that effect was made on the papers, and the man was declared by the Board to be exempt. Some days after, however, they reconsidered the claim and disallowed it and held the man. The case was brought before Judge NELSON, and he decided that the Board having once made a decision in the case, had exhausted its powers and its further action was void. He accordingly discharged the man.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a decision of Judge NELSON, sitting in the United States Circuit Court, at Cooperstown, in a habeas corpus case, which is of interest and importance to all the Boards of Enrolling Officers, and to all who may appear before them. It seems that a drafted man was claimed to be exempt as the elected son of a widow, and on application to the Board of Enrollment the claim was allowed, and an endorsement to that effect was made on the papers, and the man was declared by the Board to be exempt. Some days after, however, they reconsidered the claim and disallowed it and held the man. The case was brought before Judge NELSON, and he decided that the Board having once made a decision in the case, had exhausted its powers and its further action was void. He accordingly discharged the man.

abstract: From the headquarters of the Army of the Cumberland, at Crawford Springs, Ga., we have a dispatch, dated on Saturday night, giving an account or a desperate fight which had raged that day between the rebels under JOHNSTON, POLK, HILL and LONGSTREET, and a part of Gen. ROSECRANS' army, under Gens. THOMAS, McCOOK, CRITTENPEN and VAN CLEVE.
lead_paragraph: From the headquarters of the Army of the Cumberland, at Crawford Springs, Ga., we have a dispatch, dated on Saturday night, giving an account or a desperate fight which had raged that day between the rebels under JOHNSTON, POLK, HILL and LONGSTREET, and a part of Gen. ROSECRANS' army, under Gens. THOMAS, McCOOK, CRITTENPEN and VAN CLEVE. The attack was made by the enemy, who threw a very heavy force against the corps of Gen. THOMAS, forming the left wing el cur army, and at the same time opened fire as a feint upon our right. The aim of the rebel commander was to get between Gen. ROSECRANS and Chattanooga, but his plan was quickly developed, and after seven hours' hard lighting, in which the advantage alternated with the opposing forces, the enemy was finally repulsed, and our lines reestablished as before the engagement. The fighting was entirely by the infantry, as the character of the country was such that artillery could not be effectively used. Our casualties in wounded were heavy, but exceedingly few in killed. We had no general officers injured. A dispatch from Gen. ROSRCRANS to the General-in-Chief states that the battle would probably be resumed yesterday.

abstract: On the morning of the 13th the cavalry division of Gen. KILPATRICK crossed the Rappahannock at Kelly's Ford, and marched in the direction of Culpepper by Brandy Station. No rebels in force were encountered until reaching Brandy Station, where the advance, consisting at the Harris Light, or Second New-York, met them in some force. A brisk skirmish ensued, the rebels, however, immediately falling back toward Culpepper.

abstract: "The Parochial Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the Diocese of New-York," to whose advertisement in another column we direct attention, is an object that will commend itself to all classes of churchmen, and indeed to many who are not churchmen. The purchase of glebes, and the building of parsonages for the hard-working country clergy, is an object so catholic, that few of the wealthy and generous will decline to aid it.

But, lacking both sense and patriotism, it adopted a "Copperhead" Platform, and was beaten.

abstract: Gen. ROSECRANS has again met the enemy, whom he fought and defeated at the opening of the year, and whom he has been pursuing for the past three months, for the purpose of fetching to the test of battle. It has been an unaccountable mystery why Gen. BRAGG should have executed such a series of retreats as he has carried his army through since it occupied Murfreesboro ...
lead_paragraph: Gen. ROSECRANS has again met the enemy, whom he fought and defeated at the opening of the year, and whom he has been pursuing for the past three months, for the purpose of fetching to the test of battle. It has been an unaccountable mystery why Gen. BRAGG should have executed such a series of retreats as he has carried his army through since it occupied Murfreesboro -- why he should have evacuated in succession points of such vast natural and artificial strength as Shelbyville, Tullahoma, and especially Chattanooga? The reason, however, was probably simply because, though his positions were very strong, his army was not of sufficient magnitude and courage to cope with the well-trained Western legions that Gen. ROSECRANS marched upon him. Had ROSECRANS attacked him in front of any of the positions named, BRAGG, with his advantages, might have had a show of success; but the flanking movement so skillfully executed by Gen. ROSECRANS in each instance, necessitated that BRAGG should come forth from his stronghold and give battle on ground where his acquired advantages availed him nothing.

abstract: The Texas Expedition will not be baulked for any length of time by the unfortunate repulse of our three gunboats at Sabine Pass. We are astonished, however, that a more accurate knowledge was not obtained of the ground in the vicinity of the mouth of the Sabine River before the troops, transports and gunboats were sent from New-Orleans. It is said that, "on arriving at the spot on which our troops were destined to land, it was found impossible to effect anything, owing to the marshy nature of the ground and the excessively shallow water." Now we have had blockading vessels cruising off the mouth of the Sabine River for two years, and we should think that during that time reconnoissances might have been made that would have established the depth of water and the nature of the soil in the vicinity. Not only have we had blockaders there, but Sabine Pass itself was held by our forces for a time last year, and all the needed knowledge must, or should, then have been acquired. This repulse has not only compelled Gen. FRANKLIN and his troops to put back to New-Orleans, but has given the enemy a knowledge of our plans, and of the point from which our forces were to operate, which had been kept so carefully secret prior to the departure of the expedition. The rebels will now, of course, go to work erecting earthworks and other defences at all the approaches to Sabine Pass and River, and we know by experience the labor and difficulty of overcoming well-devised, even though hastily constructed, earthworks. The fact, too, that the rebels have gained this initial success will greatly encourage them, and will procure them many recruits from Texas, which has yet a large fighting force within its borders. It is probable that this repulse will soon compel our army to find some other landing point from which to prosecute operations against Texas.

abstract: ROBBED IN THE STREET. -- Mr. ADAM SCHILLING, of No. 422 Ninth-avenue, yesterday appeared before Police Justice KELLY, and made complaint against WILLIAM DUFFY, whom he charges, in company with two others, with having knocked him down and robbed him of a watch and chain. The affair occurred about 12 o'clock on Saturday night, in Fortieth-street. SCHILLING was knocked down into a basement area, and was so stunned by the fall that the robbery was easily effected. Officer MOULIGAN, of the Twentieth Precinct, arrested DUFFY and found upon him the stolen chain. He was committed in default of $2,000 bail.

abstract: Our island has for the last two weeks undergone a period of unusual quietness and repose, resulting mainly from apprehension felt abroad concerning the health of the town, and more particularly as to yellow fever. Steamers pass by us both ways with no more of ceremony or notice than occasionally to stop at Sand Key and leave us a mail.
