abstract: TRICTS. -- We understand that the Hudson River Railroad Company intend to lay a third track from this City to Yonkers for the exclusive use of persons traveling between those two points. It is also designed to have trains run each way every half hour and to be drawn by dummy engines to Chambers-street. We cannot help thinking that both the Harlem and New-Haven roads would consult their own interest, as they would certainly promote that of the public, by adopting a similar system. Hitherto neither of these roads has; given any special attention to the development of that kind of local business which depends for its growth on a. close and constant connection with the City. Every railroad leading into London takes special pains to give every possible facility to persons who wish to live out of the City while doing business in it. They all run trains every half hour, and some of them at certain times of the day even oftener. The result is that the whole region for twenty or thirty miles around London is simply a suburb of the metropolis, and the roads reap the benefit of the enormous business they have thus created. To a certain extent the Hudson River Railroad has done the same thing. As the facilities it has afforded have increased year after year, the region traversed by it has become more and more densely settled, and the local business thus developed has increased in magnitude and in profit, To such an extent is this true, that more than three-fourths of the enormous increase in business which the road has experienced during the present season, has taken place' in its local traffic, -- and as this is never to any great degree affected by great questions of public policy, it is evidently by far the most stable and desirable portion of the business of any road. The section of country bordering the Sound and the region traversed by the Harlem road, though differing in the nature of their attractions from that upon the Hudson River, have a beauty of their own which meets the taste and the wants of many people even better still; and if the Railroad Companies would take equal pains with the Hudson River road to facilitate access to them, we do not see why they should not be built up and settled with equal rapidity.

abstract: The schooner Nelly Baker arrived here this morning from Labrador, with a party consisting of eighteen, who left this city eight weeks ago on a pleasure trip to Labrador. Capt. JOHN DODGE, of Hampton Falls, wag the leader of the expedition, and among the members of it are the well known artist, Mr. WM. BRADFORD, and Mr. CATCHERSON, the skilful photographer. Mr. BRADFORD -- from whom we have gathered a brief account of the voyage -- went, accompanied by Mr. CRITCHERSON, for the purpose of obtaining studies and photographic views of the icebergs and of the natural scenery along the coast. They called up the Northwest River, and as far up the coast as 55 deg. north latitude. They met a number of Esquimaux, by whom they were kindly treated.

abstract: Saturday, the fourth day of the Swiss Shooting Festival having proven extremely unfavorable, the distribution of prizes to successful marksmen and the grand vocal and instrumental concert of the Arion Singing Club have been postponed until this afternoon. Throughout the earlier part of the day shooting at the various minor targets will be open to all comers under the general rules, and as it is expected that a large concourse and several distinguished visitors will be present, special arrangements for the accommodation of passengers to Jones' Wood have been adopted by the Second and Third-avenue Railroads.

abstract: A special dispatch to the Chicago Times, under date of Memphis, Sept. 15, via Cairo, states, upon the authority of a reliable gentleman just from Arkansas, that a duel was fought at Bayou Metaire, Sunday, the 6th instant, between the Confederate Generals, MARMADUKE and MARSH WALKER, in which the latter was mortally wounded. The circumstances are these: MARMADUKE, until lately was the ranking officer of his, OWEN's and WALKER's divisions, stationed at Brownsville, but a commission of Major-General coming on for WALKER, he at once took command by virtue of his rank, and ordered his troops to fall back on Bayou Metaire, where PRICE was stationed. On falling back MARMADUKE accused WALKER of cowardice, whereupon WALKER challenged him, and they fought with pistols at eight races. A; the first fire Gen. WALKER was shot through the bowels. When our informant felt, on the Tuesday following, he was not dead, but it was thought he could survive but a short time. The Arkansas troops, with whom he was a great favorite, are in a terrible state of excitement, and threaten to clean out MARMADUKE and his Missouri troops. The chagrin of MARMADUKE at being ranked by WALKER is said to be the sole cause of the difficulty. I have known Gen. WALKER for years, and know that a braver or more courteous man never lived.

abstract: Mr. EDWIN BOOTH will commence an engagement at the Winter Garden to-night, appearing -- according to his usual custom -- as Hamlet. An excellent company has been secured for the purpose of landing due assistance to the young tragedian. Mr. J.H. DAVENPORT has been appointed stage manager -- a position which his energetic nature fits him for excellently. Mr. BOOTH's last engagement at this house was interrupted -- it will be remembered -- by a domestic affliction that compelled him at once to seek test and oblivion in retirement. His return to the stage will, we are persuaded, be hailed with satisfaction by all true lovers of the drama.

abstract: The Peace party at the North is constantly calling on the Government to suspend hostilities and open negotiations with the Confederate authorities for the termination of the war. President LINCOLN is constantly assailed for having repelled overtures of this sort from the rebel Government, although as a matter of fact no such overtures have ever been made.
lead_paragraph: The Peace party at the North is constantly calling on the Government to suspend hostilities and open negotiations with the Confederate authorities for the termination of the war. President LINCOLN is constantly assailed for having repelled overtures of this sort from the rebel Government, although as a matter of fact no such overtures have ever been made. But even if they had, it is not easy to see how they could have been accepted or entertained without surrendering the whole Question at issue.

abstract: Gen. Dan, E. Sickles and Staff arrived at the Brevoort House on Saturday at 10 o'clock A.M., from Lake George, where he has been spending a few days succeeding his departure from Saratoga. He retired to the quietness of his country seat for the purpose of spending the Sabbath. He will be in the City again to-day. His health is reported to be exceedingly good, and, although he is still obliged to use the crutches, rumor says he will visit Washington the latter part of this week with the intention of again assuming active command shortly after his arrival.

abstract: The disturbed condition
lead_paragraph: Gen. SCHOFIELD has just published a most stringent order in his Department, and it is to be hoped that he will have the nerve to execute it, and that the Administration will have the courage to suffer him to do so. The condition of Missouri is at present, and for months past has been, a disgrace to the American Government. It was the State the least struck, of all the Slaveholding States, with the madness of treason. It was the most quickly and easily rescued from the perils of rebellion. It was the most fully prepared for the abrogation of Slavery, and has been the first to abolish it, and thus remove forever the exciting cause of the existing war. But, notwithstanding these facts, Missouri is to-day more dangerously disturbed, if not more dangerously disloyal, than Mississippi. More contempt for the army and the Government is daily poured forth there -- more turbulence in talk and in action is indulged in -- and human life is less safe than anywhere else within all the military lines of the United States. In this latter respect, the condition of Missouri is fearful. Not a day passes that does not chronicle house-burnings and murders. The border between Missouri and Kansas is a scene of general terror and flight, resulting from threats of mutual slaughter by opposing parties, which threats are in process of execution. Two days since the North Missouri Railroad trains were fired into and driven back from their trip, and yesterday we were treated to the report of new plots to burn the City of St. Louis!
headline: {'main': 'Trouble in Missouri.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Trouble in Missouri.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Neutrality--Laird's Rams and the Foreign Enlistment Act
snippet: Neutrality--Laird's Rams and the Foreign Enlistment Act
lead_paragraph: The most important feature in our European news this morning is the semi-official announcement put forth by the London Morning Post that the two rams -- "powerful iron-plated steam rams," as Earl RUSSELL, described them -- which are lying in the Mersey, all but ready to start out in Confederate service, are to be detained by the British Government, under the terms of the Foreign Enlistment act. Their case will be brought before a Court of Law, which will be called upon to determine whether the detention is legal, or whether the owners can recover them from the hands of the Government. The allegation against them is that they are fitted out for the purpose of carrying on hostilities against this country; but, on the other hand, it is contended that they were built by order of a French house for the late Pasha of Egypt, whose successor has repudiated the contract. "Pasha of Egypt" is really, however, but the latest alias of Mr. JEFF, DAVIS, who, having become too well known to the police by his alias, "Emperor of China," has taken a new name under which to perpetrate his crimes. There is no doubt whatever that these rams were intended for the rebels. The English journals themselves give abundant proof of this, and all the quibbles that Pasha DAVIS' tools, the of Messrs. LAIRD, have raised for the purpose evading the law, as well as all the quibbles that Earl RUSSELL has raised about the construction of the law, have only served to establish more clearly the main facts in question. We have great hope, therefore, that if the rams are detained, and their case brought before a British court of law, that the decision will be such as not only to agree with the provisions of the Foreign Enlistment act, but with national comity and international justice. We have the more ground for this hope in the new spirit of fairness with which this case is treated by nearly all types of the British Press. The Daily News, the Star, the Spectator and other friendly organs, are energetic in their remonstrances, decided and bold in their tone, and persistent and powerful in their arguments; the Morning Post and so called neutral journals give a remarkably fair statement of the case; even the Times and Saturday Review, which heretofore have been ready to apologies for any breach of English or international law, if done in the interest of the Confederates, which have been anxious to damage the Union cause by fair blows or by foul, have come out vigorously against the present evasion of the law attempted by the rebel agents and the Messrs. LAIRD. The Times desires that the law on the subject, whatever it may be, should be enforced, and if the present law is not sufficient to secure the ends aimed at, "it concerns us (the English) more nearly than any other nation to get the laws thoroughly revised," it further makes this remark, which, if it be accurate, we consider one of the best signs of the day in England: "As things now stand, there seems to be a kind of moral obligation making itself felt in advance of the law." There is no doubt that, when once public sentiment in England attains a just standard and an unbiased expression on the questions at issue between our Government and theirs, we shall have an easy solution for all difficulties that may arise, and the best security for the maintenance of peaceful relations between the two countries.

abstract: PROGRESS OF UNIONISM IN TENNESSEE. -- The recent news we have given of the improved public feeling in Tennessee, and the readiness of the people of that State to return to the Union, is receiving confirmation in the "Western journals. A Cincinnati paper received yesterday contains notices of public meetings that have been held in the Counties of Bedford and Hardeman, in both of which resolutions of the most decided Union character were passed. Gov. JOHNSON was requested to order an election for State officers and members of the Legislature, and pledges were given that none but friends of the Union would be supported for office. Hardeman County was always Democratic in politics by nearly 1,000 majority, and went unanimously for secession. It has not had a Union soldier in it for months. Bedford County was generally Democratic, and went heavily for secession. Better exponents of Tennessee feeling than these two counties could not be chosen.

abstract: Gift of Constitution to Poland
lead_paragraph: La France has intelligence from Moscow, which, if authentic, will entitle the Czar to hold the first rank among the reformers and patriots of the present century. It is to the effect that the Emperor ALEXANDER has resolved not only to give a Constitution to Poland, but even to convert the whole of his vast empire into a constitutional State. Nor have we merely vague assertion in support of the rumor. The very outlines of the scheme have been likewise communicated. The contemplated polity is to be a species of federalism, of which our own is evidently the model. Every province is to have a Diet for the management of its municipal affairs, while a Pan-Slavonic Diet, consisting of a Senate of three hundred members, and a Lower Chamber of four hundred and fifty, is to represent and rule over the monarchy at large.

abstract: Additional particulars respecting the great battle near Chattanooga on Saturday, are given in yesterday's Cincinnati Commercial. Soon after the opening of the battle the fighting became general, and an impetuous dash of the enemy upon the well-known LOOMIS battery resulted in the capture of Capt. VAN PELT, its commanding ...
lead_paragraph: Additional particulars respecting the great battle near Chattanooga on Saturday, are given in yesterday's Cincinnati Commercial. Soon after the opening of the battle the fighting became general, and an impetuous dash of the enemy upon the well-known LOOMIS battery resulted in the capture of Capt. VAN PELT, its commanding officer, and five of the six guns which composed it. The musketry firing is described as having been at times terrific and almost deafening in its roar. The action continued until long alter dark, both armies fighting stubbornly and losing large numbers of men. We captured ten guns and lost seven. From a special dispatch to the Washington Chronicle, we learn that at Gen. GRANGER's headquarters, at Nashville, it was believed that the contest closed with no disadvantages to the Union arms. A telegram from Louisville, dated 12 3/4 A.M., Monday, states that the fight was renewed on Sunday morning, resulting in the defeat of Gen. ROSECRANS' army and its compulsory retreat to Chattanooga, but a later dispatch received by the Washington National Intelligencer, puts a more cheerful complexion upon the matter. This brings the news down to 8 P.M. on Sunday, when the advance of the rebel army is reported to have been driven back. The dispatch states that the battle was resumed on Sunday morning -- the rebels attacking with overwhelming numbers -- and the action continued furiously all day. The number of killed and wounded on both sides is estimated at thirty thousand.

abstract: We have two days later advices from Europe, and newspaper files to the 8th inst., by the arrival at this port yesterday of the Cunard screw steamer Hecla, from Liverpool and Queenstown. The question of the destination of the rebel rams, building in the Mersey, is still earnestly discussed by the English journals.
lead_paragraph: We have two days later advices from Europe, and newspaper files to the 8th inst., by the arrival at this port yesterday of the Cunard screw steamer Hecla, from Liverpool and Queenstown. The question of the destination of the rebel rams, building in the Mersey, is still earnestly discussed by the English journals. The Morning Post asserts that these vessels will be detained until a Court of law can determine whether, under the terms of the Foreign Enlistment act, the detention is legal. The Paris Constitutionnal repeats the assertion that the rams are constructed for the Egyptian Government. The report that JEFF, DAVIS intended to arm half a million of negroes was received with distrust in England; but presuming it to be true, some regarded it as a confession of weakness on the part of the rebels, and others treated it as a masterly stroke of policy, checkmating President LINCOLN's Emancipation scheme. It was again announced that MAXIMILIAN had determined upon the conditional acceptance of the Mexican crown Engagements between the insurgent Poles and the Russian troops were daily reported. There was considerable excitement in the Liverpool Cotton market, and prices were advancing. Consuls closed at 93 1/2 for money.

abstract: Prize Courts and English Complaints
lead_paragraph: The English have complained a good deal, from first to last, about the action of our Prize Courts. They have not been suited with the law by which our Courts have been governed, even though we showed them the best English authority for it. It is not unnatural, perhaps, for they looked at their own legal principles from a point of view to which they were not accustomed, and their aspect was entirely changed. The views which English Courts took of the cases of prizes captured by English vessels, seemed to be very different when it concerns English prizes and American Courts and captors. Nor have their complaints been confined to the general rules of law. The action of the Courts in different cases has been the subject of sharp animadversion. They have intimated pretty broadly that our Courts would not give them a fair hearing -- interposed delays of all kinds to their just claims -- imposed too heavy expenses upon them, and in various ways were guilty of practices which were very offensive to the sensibilities of the British Lion. The allegations of undue delay have been quite prominent. It is but a little while since we saw an article in the London Shipping Gazette, complaining, among other things, that in the case of the Labuan and the Empress, although the vessels had been restored, "no compensation has as yet been awarded to the claimants for the loss of time, damage, or other injuries incurred in the protection of their property." But it appeared by our law reports a few days ago that the reason why nothing has been done in the matter of the Labuan, at least, is that the claimants of the vessel have failed to move the proceedings before the Court, understanding, as they said, although mistakenly, that the matter was already before the Court for decision, -- so that the delay has been the consequence of their own blundering. We are confident that the same rule will hold good in other cases of delay.
headline: {'main': 'Delays in the Prize Courts.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Delays in the Prize Courts.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ARMY OF THE POTOMAC, Saturday, Sept. 19, 1863. A portion of this army, a portion, too, whose ranks are thinner because of that conflict, fitly celebrated the day.

abstract: The honors contemplated in this City to the late Col. M.K. BRYAN, of Albany, under the auspices of the Committee on National Affairs, were paid yesterday. The Governor's Room, where the body laid in state, was visited by throngs of citizens until 2 o'clock P.M., when, under escort of the Sixty-ninth regiment, the remains were taken to the Albany boat at the foot of Cortland-street, where they were formally delivered to Messrs. JAS. I. JOHNSON and L.W. RODGERS, a Committee on behalf of the citizens of Albany.

abstract: Another new fast steamer, besides that spoken of, is to be built at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. Orders have been received from the Navy Department to commence as soon as convenient, and yesterday active preparations were begun to fit a place for her keel.
lead_paragraph: Another new fast steamer, besides that spoken of, is to be built at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. Orders have been received from the Navy Department to commence as soon as convenient, and yesterday active preparations were begun to fit a place for her keel. That portion of the Navy-yard from which the United States steamer Mercury was launched last week is being enlarged, and the new launching ways are in course of construction to facilitate the building of the new vessels. The new ship will be larger than nine-tenths of the vessels at present in the navy. The Department is working hard to augment our swift steamers. Already the Wambanogue, an immense vessel, is under way at the Navy-yard, under the special surveillance of Mr. DELANO. Mr. STEERS' Ship, the Idaho, is also advancing steadily, and it is understood that instructions have been sent to the Navy-yards of Portsmouth, Philadelphia and Boston to begin, when convenient, new ships of war, of which great speed is to be the most prominent characteristic. The fast vessels at present in the service are nearly all loaded down with heavy batteries, which prevents them from going as quick as they might otherwise do; the Fort Jackson, for instance, was expected to make eighteen knots an hour, and our correspondent on board states that the weight of metal is so great that she cannot make more than ten or twelve.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. The returning engagements off Mr. EDWIN BOOTH have become so acceptable a feature of the Winter season, that it is fair to say they are looked forward to by the most intellectual part of the community with the greatest possible anticipations of delight.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- The returning engagements off Mr. EDWIN BOOTH have become so acceptable a feature of the Winter season, that it is fair to say they are looked forward to by the most intellectual part of the community with the greatest possible anticipations of delight. The gentleman belongs to a class that, so far as this City is concerned, begins and ends with himself. Treading on the heels of tradition in almost every part that he plays, he yet contrives, by a delicate and peculiar vein of thought, to infuse his own individuality into all that he impersonates. He is one of the freshest actors now before the public, and this, combined with rare mental car city for study, imparts to all his roles, well-known as they are, an ever-recurring degree of interest. Mr. BOOTH opened last evening in his favorite role of Hamlet -- the one in which he always makes his rentree before the public. He was received by a splendid audience, and with a degree of enthusiasm that testifies unmistakably to the favor in which he is held by Ms friends. The performance was a very fine one in all respects, and inaugurated Mr. JACKSON's Winter campaign with the greatest possible ec[???]at. Of Mr. BOOTH's performance of the metaphysical Dane we have but little to add to what we have already, and so often said. It is a thoroughly fine impersonation -- bold and picturesque

abstract: The Emperor NAPOLEON'S departure for Biarritz, first announced for the 7th, and then postponed till the 10th, may very possibly, it is now said, be still further delayed. Cabinet councils have been frequent since His Majesty's return from Chalons, and there seems to be a great deal going on in high places. It is not, I believe, any one great question that thus occupies the Government, but several of more or less interest.
lead_paragraph: Correspondence of the London Times.

abstract: Yesterday morning early an affray occurred at the corner of South Fourth and First streets, Brooklyn, E.D., by which a man named CONRAD FEISTER, lost his life. It appears that a party of men partially intoxicated, left the lager-beer saloon of THOMAS THOSA on the above corner, and while talking about the history of the Union army a dispute arose between them, and some odious epithets were used, and knives drawn. A man named REWLINGER, alias THING was in the party, and believing himself insulted, he procured a chair leg, with which, after further provocation, he hit FEISTER four or five blows on the head, one of which struck him on the left temple and felled him to the ground. Before he could be removed to the Station-house he died. The assailant and a man named VEIS were arrested. All were German and unmarried. Coroner BARRETT will hold an inquest on Thursday next, after the result of the postmortem shall have been announced.

abstract: As was anticipated by Gen. ROSECRANS, thegreat battle which opened on Saturday forenoon, and raged till after nightfall, was reopened on Sunday morning, and continued throughout the day.
lead_paragraph: As was anticipated by Gen. ROSECRANS, thegreat battle which opened on Saturday forenoon, and raged till after nightfall, was reopened on Sunday morning, and continued throughout the day. The aspect of the battle of Sunday is no better than was that of Saturday. On Saturday, the rebels first massed their troops on our right, then on our centre, then on our left, attacking each in succession, and gaining important advantages, and though at evening our army occupied the same ground as when the action commenced, it would appear that Gen. ROSECRANS suffered severely. On Sunday the enemy again advanced in force; but the only details of the battle given are, that it raged fiercely all day -- that two of ROSECRANS' divisions gave way in panic, but were subsequently rallied, while the remainder of the army stood its ground, and it is reported that at night we were driving back the rebel advance. The casualties were very heavy -- the dispatch asserting that the killed and wounded on both sides will not fall short of thirty thousand.

abstract: Whatever may prove to have been the facts and results of the late battle in the northwestern corner of Georgia, we may all find comfort in the reflection that although our winning a great battle just now might bring the Confederacy to the verge of dissolution, our losing one can do but little for its salvation.
lead_paragraph: Whatever may prove to have been the facts and results of the late battle in the northwestern corner of Georgia, we may all find comfort in the reflection that although our winning a great battle just now might bring the Confederacy to the verge of dissolution, our losing one can do but little for its salvation. We are long past that stage of the war in which a single defeat can stay our progress. The fact, for fact it seems to be that the rebel army of Virginia has been largely drawn upon to supply BRAGG with the means of striking the blow under which ROSECRANS is now reeling, proves that the surmise which gave them but one army remaining of the various hosts which they possessed, a year ago, is well founded. They have no longer an army of the East and an army of the West, an army in Virginia and an army in Tennessee. When they seek to accomplish great things at any one point, it has to be by forces drawn from all others. This is unquestionably a game in which great skill and judgment, celerity and audacity, may be displayed, and it would be childish to refuse the rebels the credit of displaying every one of these qualities. But, then, it is a desperate game -- a game which Generals play rather to save their honor than to retrieve their fortunes. It was probably never played so magnificently, and may never he played so magnificently, as in that brilliant campaign by which NAPOLEON sought to save Paris after the fatal field of Leipsic. There was something awful in the genius with which, during that terrible month, he shot small masses of raw levies up and down the chord of the arc, in the vain effort to stem the great tide which was gradually hemming him in. and under which he soon after sunk in the court-yard of Fontainebleau. But fortune was still on the side of the big battalions, and proved, for perhaps the hundredth time, that no amount of either energy or ability can, at the close of long wars, make up for the exhaustion of the supply of men.

abstract: Mr. MARKTZEK publishes his first official announcement of the coming season at the Academy of Music, in another column, to-day. The boxes are far more limited in number than those who wish to obtain them.

abstract: The steamship Etna arrived here yesterday noon, with one day's later news from Eurupe. The London Post announces, on undoubted authority, that the Government has ordered the two steam-rains which have been the subject of so much discussion, to be detained; and in relation...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Etna arrived here yesterday noon, with one day's later news from Eurupe. The London Post announces, on undoubted authority, that the Government has ordered the two steam-rains which have been the subject of so much discussion, to be detained; and in relation to the same matter the Times is of opinion that in view of the common belief that these vessels are for the service of the rebels, the Government would not be justified in letting them depart from the Mersey. The Herald refuses to believe that the Ministry will interfere, and in a characteristic editorial denounces such a monstrous piece of tyranny and placid acquiescence in the outrageous demands of the Federal Government. A French journal describes four suspicious steamers that are in process of construction at Nantez and Bordeaux, evidently designed for war-vessels, and states that they are to be delivered up at sea, twenty leagues from Belle Isle. The journal adds that it is believed the steamers are for the Confederates. The Paris correspondent of the London Herald repeats his assertion that both the recognition of the South and the defensive league between the Confederate, French, and Mexican Governments are decided upon. There was no change in the position of the Polish question. The Cotton Market still continued buoyant and somewhat excited. Breadstuffs were firm and Provisions steady. Consols closed at 93 1/2@93 5/8 for money.

abstract: Important details respecting the battle of Sunday near Chattanooga, reached us yesterday morning, but at so late an hour that we could publish it only in a small portion of our morning issue.
lead_paragraph: Important details respecting the battle of Sunday near Chattanooga, reached us yesterday morning, but at so late an hour that we could publish it only in a small portion of our morning issue. The information entirely disproves the brief dispatch from Louisville on Sunday night announcing that Gen. ROSECRANS had been badly beaten. The battle on Saturday ended in a clear advantage to our army, we having captured most of the artillery and sustained less loss in men than the enemy. On Sunday, at 9 o'clock, the engagement was renewed by the rebels, who massed their forces and attempted to carry the left of our position by a series of fierce onslaughts. These assaults were gallantly and successively repelled, and the carnage on both sides was appalling. Foiled in their object, the enemy a few hours later threw themselves against our right and centre, and succeeded in piercing our line, exposing Gen. THOMAS on the left to a terrible flank attack. This advantage was not long held, however, as reinforcements under Gen. GRANGER opportunely arrived, and our broken columns again rallying, with united front they dashed upon the enemy, driving them back, and punishing them severely. Throughout the day Gen. THOMAS' corps gallantly held its ground, repulsing the enemy in every attack, but at 5 o'clock, in order to reestablish our lines in a new position, he fell back to Rossville, in the direction of Chattanooga. Our losses in prisoners and wounded are estimated at 3,000. Gen. ROSECRANS has determined to concentrate his entire army at Chattanooga. There were indications that the fight would be renewed on Monday-night, the date of our last dispatch.

abstract: The steamboat Kentucky arrived last evening from Helena, with news of interest from Arkansas. The news we have had of the evacuation of Little Rock was correct.
lead_paragraph: The steamboat Kentucky arrived last evening from Helena, with news of interest from Arkansas. The news we have had of the evacuation of Little Rock was correct. The National troops hold the country from Duvall's Bluff on White River, to Little Rock on the Arkansas. Arkansas people have said for the la6t six weeks that Little Rock would be given up as soon as seriously threatened; they also said the Confederate troops in the State would all be marched to Texas. The result has justified these statements. Arkansas is now more in the power of the legitimate authorities than any other conquered State. She is left exhausted and prostrate, and will probably readily become good, loyal ground. The enemy's "trans-Mississippi Department," which includes Missouri, is getting small by degrees and beautifully less. The giving up of Little Rock is the surrender of Arkansas. We now turn to Texas; thither the struggle must retire, and there it can have no opportunity of distinct military existence. The possession of a few posts in that sparcely populated State will hold the whole.

abstract: The causes which produce the diseases that result in Deafness, cannot be anything but interesting to a sufferer, as well as useful.
lead_paragraph: The causes which produce the diseases that result in Deafness, cannot be anything but interesting to a sufferer, as well as useful. It were impossible to give an accurate estimate. I will, however, endeavor to lay before my readers such as commonly come under the notice of an Aurist daily. It is natural to believe that the derangement of the nervous apparatus is the cause in most instances of these diseases.

abstract: What does the World mean by saying that the TIMES described the "desperate conflict" near Chattanooga as a "magnificent victory for the army of the Union?" It is absolutely certain that the TIMES did nothing of the kind. In our article of Monday, to which we suppose the World refers, we tried to make a just estimate of the results and bearings of the battle of Saturday -- which was the only day's engagement of which we then had news; but we were particularly careful to make no claims that were not justified by the facts that had reached us, or by our previous knowledge of the situation of affairs. While, assuredly, on the one hand, we did not characterize the late battle as a "magnificent victory," neither on the other hand, can we, in accordance with facts, describe it as a "crushing defeat." ROSECRANS' army fought a great battle, and fought it bravely. It did not crush the enemy nor was it crushed by the enemy. Gen. ROSECRANS held his ground on Saturday night, alter the first day's battle, and at the close of Sunday's battle also, he held his ground. If, failing to win a " magnificent victory," he then fell back a short distance to a stronger position, he will probably only remain there until he receives such reinforcements as will enable him to achieve a victory that even a Copperhead will be reluctantly compelled to own as "magnificent."

abstract: Recognition, The Effect of
lead_paragraph: The whole importance of French recognition of the Confederacy, or of a French alliance with it, lies in its probable effect upon the fortunes of the war, and it is safe to say that this is greatly exaggerated even by those who are least apprehensive of any danger from that quarter. Recognition has been so much talked of, and so often threatened, that a large portion of the public have come to look upon it as something inexpressibly horrible -- so much so, that there is hardly a doubt that a well-authenticated announcement that France had recognized the rebel Government would spread a panic through the whole country. People cannot, therefore, be too often reminded that it is a mere piece of etiquette, whose significance is entirely conventional. If we choose to consider it important, it is important; if we choose to consider it of no moment, it is of no moment. It is on our own nerves that it would be intended to produce all its effect. The position of the Confederates would not be changed by it in anything but the name. Their Minister in Paris would not in consequence of it enjoy a single advantage that he does not now enjoy. He already has access to the Emperor and to the Minister of Foreign Affairs just as readily as Mr. DAYTON, or any other Ambassador. What he says is listened to, and treated with just as much consideration as if he were in full possession of all the honors of the Plenipotentiary of an acknowledged Power. All that he would gain by "recognition" would be the privilege of bowing to the Emperor on New-Year's Day, and wishing him the compliments of the season.

abstract: We learn from a gentleman who has lately traversed the State of Ohio leisurely, from one side to the other, that Copperheadism is more completely dead and "laid out" than ever was a political heresy in any State, before actual election had consigned it to sepulture. War Democrats are declaring themselves by hundreds and thousands. Shrewd men, who have hopes of future life, do not think it safe to show the white feather in time of war. So that, between patriotism and selfishness, the hopes of the Copperheads are utterly blasted. But the most striking fact in the Ohio canvass is the extraordinary unanimity and enthusiasm of the women and children for JOHN BROUGH, the opponent of VALLANDIGHAM. While thousands of these persons were seen and heard, in cities and at depots of railroads, waving handkerchiefs and shouting for BROUGH, never a one had a word for VALLANDIGHAM. Judging by the popular manifestations by the wayside, our informant is confident VALLANDIGHAM will not be beaten by less than 100,000 majority.

abstract: The fifth heat of the Butler and Prince trotting match came off yesterday, and terminated in favor of Butler. An even start was effected, and Prince led round the turn a length in front of Butler, who broke at the quarter-pole, and fell off a couple of lengths before he recovered again; he was soon lapped on Prince, and was neck and neck at the half-mile, and just headed Prince as they were approaching the new stand, when the latter broke up and Butler led three lengths before Prince caught again, Butler breaking badly and yawing across the track as he entered the three-quarter turn, but recovering in time to prevent HORACE JONES from passing him with Prince, and kept his lead to the score, with Prince breaking again as he approached the distance-stand. Butler won the heat and race in 2:29 1/2.
lead_paragraph: The fifth heat of the Butler and Prince trotting match came off yesterday, and terminated in favor of Butler. Butler won the heat and race in 2:29 1/2.

abstract: It has been much doubted lately whether the Democratic party is a war party. No further doubt on the subject need be entertained. Let any one read what its organs are saying of each other, in view of the beating the party has got in Maine, and the conclusion will be irresistible that a violent state of hostilities characterizes at this time the Democratic party. It is emphatically a war party.

abstract: We enter  tain not a shadow of doubt, that prior to the Georgia battle, the army of Gen. BRAGG was reinforced from the army of Gen. LEE in Virginia; but we do not believe the news officially telegraphed to us this morning, that the corps of LONGSTREET and the corps of EWELL were both sent from Virginia to Georgia.
lead_paragraph: -- We entertain not a shadow of doubt, that prior to the Georgia battle, the army of Gen. BRAGG was reinforced from the army of Gen. LEE in Virginia; but we do not believe the news officially telegraphed to us this morning, that the corps of LONGSTREET and the corps of EWELL were both sent from Virginia to Georgia. This would leave but the corps of Gen. HILL, or some twenty or twenty-five thousand men, under Gen. LEE, for the defence of Richmond. The rebels would not thus strip their capital while Gen. MEADE, with thrice twenty thousand or more men, was menacing it. If they had done so, it would have been known to Gen. MEADE, who would most certainly have acted upon his knowledge. There is a persistent effort in certain quarters at present, to make it appear that the rebels have very few troops in Virginia, and the object of it is to depreciate the sagacity, policy and strategy of the soldier of Gettysburgh. No proof is furnished of the assertion -- no plausible reason for such a movement is given; but the bare reiteration is made that the whole, or nearly the whole of the Army of Virginia, has been put under Gen. BRAGG in Georgia -- or, as the semi-official telegram of this morning phrases it, that the "whole Confederacy waa concentrated against ROSECRANS."

abstract: Yesterday morning about two hundred and eighty rebels, who had been captured at the battle of Gettysburgh, and subsequently confined in Fort Delaware, arrived at Arch-street wharf direct from the fort, having been conveyed thither in the steame Reybold.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning about two hundred and eighty rebels, who had been captured at the battle of Gettysburgh, and subsequently confined in Fort Delaware, arrived at Arch-street wharf direct from the fort, having been conveyed thither in the steame Reybold. They marched through several streets, an were finally entertained at the Cooper Shop refreshment saloon, at the foot of Washington-street. The were originally captured rebels who took the oath o allegiance, and were then received into the United States service. They look happy, and as though they had been well cared for since their sojourn at the fort.

abstract: A mass meeting of the loyal young men of New-York, without distinction of party, was held at Cooper Institute last evening, to indorse the nominations of the Union Convention lately held at Syracuse. Col. ELLIOTT F. SHEPARD occupied ...
lead_paragraph: A mass meeting of the loyal young men of New-York, without distinction of party, was held at Cooper Institute last evening, to indorse the nominations of the Union Convention lately held at Syracuse. Col. ELLIOTT F. SHEPARD occupied the chair, and speeches were delivered by Judge HIERSTAND, of New-Orleans; Hon. LORENZO SHERWOOD, of Texas; Hon. HENRY B. STANTON, CHAS. A. SPENCER, Esq., and others. The meeting was large, and exceedingly enthusiastic. A full report will be found in another column.

abstract: Speech Loyal Young Men's Meeting in New-York; Loyal Young Men's Mass Meeting in New-York
snippet: Speech Loyal Young Men's Meeting in New-York; Loyal Young Men's Mass Meeting in New-York
lead_paragraph: The Fall politicalc ampaign was inaugurated last eveing by the Loyal Young Men of the City, who, without reference to past political preferences, assembled at the Cooper Institute to indorse the nominations of the the Union Convention lately held at Syracuse. The audience was not as large as has sometimes been seen in that building, and as will doubtless often again be seen before the campaign is ended; it was, however, highly respectable in point of numbers, and rarely equalled in character and intelligence. It contained a fair sprinkling of ladies -- a thing not usually seen at political meetings. A large number of our prominent citizens occupied the stage, among whom we noticed the venerable founder of the institution, Peter Cooper, Collector Barney, Chas. A. Spencer, William Laimbeer, Jr., John Austin Stevens, Judge Hogeboom, Hon. Lorenzo Sherwood, of Texas; Judge Hierstand, of New-Orleans, and many others. Over the platform were suspended banners with the following inscriptions:

abstract: We are now enabled, by telegraphic reports, to obtain a clearer idea of the action fought on Saturday and Sunday last in Northwestern Georgia.
lead_paragraph: We are now enabled, by telegraphic reports, to obtain a clearer idea of the action fought on Saturday and Sunday last in Northwestern Georgia. The battle was neither a "crushing defeat" nor a "magnificent victory" for the army of Gen. ROSECRANS, or for the army of the rebels. After two days of very severe fighting and of various fortune, Gen. ROSECRANS still held his ground, but his prospects, his losses and the necessities of the situation were such, that on Sunday night he ordered his army to fall back from its advance lines to Chattanooga, at which point, we judge, the whole of it arrived yesterday. What may be the further development of events, we must wait to see.

abstract: The United States school-ship Macedonia sailed from the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday to Newport, to land her Midshipmen, her Summer cruise having expired; those of the Marion were taken ashore some time since, so that nearly all the Middles connected with the institution are now ready for the examination.
lead_paragraph: The United States school-ship Macedonia sailed from the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday to Newport, to land her Midshipmen, her Summer cruise having expired; those of the Marion were taken ashore some time since, so that nearly all the Middles connected with the institution are now ready for the examination. The Macedonia is in excellent condition, and will require very little overhauling this Fall. The following is a list of her officers: Lieutenant Commanding, S.B. LUCE; Lieutenant and Executive Officer, A.T. Mayhew; Lieutenants. T.L. Swann, W.T. Sampson, H.F. Picking; Ensigns, P.H. Cooper, P. D'Orleans; Chaplain, W.A. Hitchcock; Assistant Surgeon, D.F. Ricketts; Assistant Paymasters, N.P. Tuttle, G.A. Osborne; Commandant's Clerk, C.L. Harris; Boat-swain, E.B. Bell; Gunner, G. Fouse; Carpenter, J.G. Myers; Sailmaker, S. Seaman.

abstract: The Russian frigate Osliaba, which has lain at anchor in our harbor for several days past, and has been an object of so much interest to our citizens, is about to be reinforced by a fleet of four or five vessels of the same nationality. The English steamer which arrired yesterday reports having signated the fleet a short distance outside of Sandy Hook.

abstract: A temporary check to the Union arms in Northern Georgia, if such shall be the final result of the struggle there, will be the more painfully felt because of the late unbroken chain of signal victories of the National cause in all parts of the country.
lead_paragraph: A temporary check to the Union arms in Northern Georgia, if such shall be the final result of the struggle there, will be the more painfully felt because of the late unbroken chain of signal victories of the National cause in all parts of the country. But rightly considered, the subject is not one for depression at all. Alternations of victory and defeat mark all human enterprises; and reverses, so far from making success impossible, are often the needed and essential preparations for ft. If the rebels were determined to concentrate their forces and make one desperate effort to win a battle, it is well that the blow fell when and where it did. No other Union army was so well prepared by long rest and thorough discipline and equipment, for a fierce and prolonged contest, as that of Gen. ROSECRANS. Since the battle of Stones River, nearly nine months ago, this army has fought no battles and made but one fatiguing march. Its time has been spent in a salubrious climate, its provisions have been wholesome and bountiful, and no care has been spared to render its equipment perfect and effective. In the meantime, it has learned to know, love, and trust its leaders, and is prepared to follow them to the death on any field. The composition of the army has remained unchanged. It has become more homogeneous and harmonious than any other army of the country. It is in splendid condition for battle.

abstract: The case of JOSEPH R. LOWENSTEIN, who has been on trial in the Court of Sessions, before Judge MCCUNN for three days past, was concluded yesterday by a verdict of guilty. The jury was out only ten minutes. This is the first conviction that has taken place on the charge of receiving stolen goods for some time past. LOWKNSTEIN's establishment was kept at No. 38 Grand-street, and was ostensibly a dry goads store. The prisoner was remanded for sentence on Saturday. Establishments such as this man has been found guilty of keeping, make thieves faster than aught else. It is here where inducements are held out to the young, and it is to be hoped that the arrest and conviction of LOWENSTEIN will be followed up by that of others.

abstract: Very suddenly and unexpectedly Gen. GILLMORE, giving himself a short leave of absence from his headquarters at Morris Island, arrived here on Friday morning, last week. After visiting the General Hospital, and taking kindly by the hand the wounded soldiers and speaking to them words of encouragement and comfort, inquiring into their wants and treatment, he made a flying visit to Beaufort, where he was received with a salute and oilier appropriate honors. While there he visited all the hospitals in the town, and had a general word of comfort for every patient. His visit had a good effect on the patients. Their eyes grew brighter; their spirits, cramped and low, seemed to have imparted to them some of the glow and vivacity of their visitor. Everyone seemed to have gained a new hold on life, and all signs of depression and despair passed quickly away.

abstract: MORE'S success in battering down with his 200-pounder Parrott guns the walls of Fort Sumter, seems to have produced more excitement and discussion in Europe than any event of the war. Such feats of artillery practice amaze and confound them, and have already given them more of respect for us than any other of our achievements.
lead_paragraph: MORE's success in battering down with his 200-pounder Parrott guns the walls of Fort Sumter, seems to have produced more excitement and discussion in Europe than any event of the war. Such feats of artillery practice amaze and confound them, and have already given them more of respect for us than any other of our achievements. The London Army and Navy Gazette 8ays that the Americans have constructed and put to service at Charleston cannon of calibres which to the English are known only as of theoretical and probable attainment. "Before such projectiles as these guns carry, the breaching of masonry, whether of brick or stone, is but a question of short time." "Had such guns been available in the trenches before Sebastopol, the Allies would have made short work, not only of the Redan and Malakoff, and bastion du mat, but of the shipping and of the forts on the other side of the harbor." "It is undeniable," continues Mr. RUSSELL, " that the establishment of a few of Brig.-Gen. GILLMORE's batteries before Sebastopol, on the 17th of October, 1854, instead of the 'tremendous armament' of which Lord GRANVILLE boasted, would have 'knocked the place into a cocked hat' in twenty-four hours." Even that terrible ship the Warrior would not be safe against the new American artillery, they are beginning to suspect; for the same authority says: "Unquestionably the Admiralty would be rather nervous about the result of firing a 450-pound shot against the side of the Warrior, at the distance of 200 yards, notwithstanding the experiments," &c. The question then arises, Have the English any such guns? And they are forced to a loud negative. "In face of these facts, we are obliged to record that our scientific officers are of opinion that the best English gun for breaching purposes is the old 68-pounder!" It is a lamentable confession, but it seems to have an excellent effect upon the soul; for the Army and Navy Gazette deduces the following remarkable bit of philosophy from the startling facts which have been revealed, to it: "Do not let us pooh-pooh the Americans. If we are wise, it is the last thing we ought to do." Yes. yes.

abstract: Mr. CYRUS W. FIELD is among the passengers by the China. Prior to Mr. FIELD's departure from England everything had been put in train to secure the laying of the Atlantic Telegraph Cable between Ireland and Newfoundland during the Summer of 1864. Messrs. GLASS, ELLIOT & Co., as already stated, had contracted to carry out the work, and had commenced the manufacture of the cable. They not only undertake to make the cable, but also to successfully lay it, thus showing implicit  confidence in the success of the undertaking. That this confidence is also shared by others, is shown from the fact that several of the leading Marine Insurance Companies in London had issued policies covering all risks, including even the transmission of messages, at comparatively moderate premiums.

abstract: There is important news from the Army of the Potomac, but it is better that nothing but the main feature should be published at present, which is that MEADE'S cavalry and a portion of his intantry are south of the Rapidan, and that our cavalry have penetrated as far as Orange Court-house, without meeting with any signs of ...
lead_paragraph: There is important news from the Army of the Potomac, but it is better that nothing but the main feature should be published at present, which is that MEADE'S cavalry and a portion of his intantry are south of the Rapidan, and that our cavalry have penetrated as far as Orange Court-house, without meeting with any signs of the rebels in force. If the rebels have retired upon Gordonsville, there must either be a battle there soon, or a retreat of one or other of the confronting armies.

abstract: This Committee sent off sixty-seven substitutes yesterday, of whom seven were rejected by the medical examiners. Among those passed acceptable was one for a Staten Islander, who belongs to our Seventy-first regiment. He had been at the war with his regiment each time it answered the call of the Government, and had served here during the riot. The Committee have deferred the cases of a number of applicants from a new militia regiment, commanded by Col. HALL, and yesterday they had a private session to consider and determine whether the conscripted men of this corps are entitled to relief under the ordinance. The Committee were unanimously of the opinion that Col. HALL's men were not active militiamen within the meaning of the ordinance, the regiment having organized since Aug. 1, but it was decided to defer deciding the matter until Col. HALL shall appear and be heard, and for the purpose of hearing him on behalf his men who are drafted, the Committee are to meet at 9 o'clock this morning.
lead_paragraph: This Committee sent off sixty-seven substitutes yesterday, of whom seven were rejected by the medical examiners. abstract: Southern Peace Men
lead_paragraph: The able article which we extracted last week from the Raleigh Standard, upon the propriety or necessity of making terms with the National Government, is a very good commentary upon the theory of the peace party at the North, which maintains the uselessness and wickedness of fighting, and insists upon a resort to negotiation, not only as the best means, but as the only means of bringing the South back to the Union. The Raleigh Standard and the party for which it speaks in North Carolina, are now ready to treat for peace, and are willing once more to return to the Union, not, according to their own account, because they love the Confederacy less, or love the old Government more, but for that most cogent of all cogent reasons -- because they cannot help it. The Standard frankly confesses that it is for peace, because a continuance of the war involves subjugation, and subjugation means ruin. It confesses that North Carolina went into the war unwillingly, but that once in, honor as well as interest required that she should spend in it "her last man and last dollar;" but says, that the last man and last dollar have been spent, and that therefore it is now time for her to make terms. There is through the whole article not a line or a phrase which indicates that the peace party are influenced in their action by any more sentimental motive than necessity, or that anything could possibly have induced them to think of compromise except the exhaustion of their physical strength.
headline: {'main': 'The Southern Peace Men.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Southern Peace Men.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The army of Gen. MEADE and the army of Gen. LEE are evidently engaged in some shrewd manoeuvering at the present moment. Up to a late day, LEE, on the South bank of the Rapidan, presented a strong front to the Army of the Potomac; but on Tuesday last our cavalry advanced across the Rapidan as far as Orange Court-house, and found no signs of rebels in any force.
lead_paragraph: The army of Gen. MEADE and the army of Gen. LEE are evidently engaged in some shrewd manoeuvering at the present moment. Up to a late day, LEE, on the South bank of the Rapidan, presented a strong front to the Army of the Potomac; but on Tuesday last our cavalry advanced across the Rapidan as far as Orange Court-house, and found no signs of rebels in any force. When they withdrew, in what direction, and with what object, is left to surmise. It may be that they retired to Gordonsville. It is not within the limits of probability that they moved down the Rapidan toward Fredericksburgh, or that LEE has devised any such stategical plan as to draw the Army of the Potomac to Gordonsville while he attempts a flank or rear movement against it. Nor is it within the limits of probability that he has moved up the Rapidan from his late position, although the fact that he has all along maintained a small force on the north bank of the river, higher than the position held by our army, and covering the important gaps of the Blue Ridge, through which the successive rebel invasions have poured, indicate either that Lee is anxious to keep us on the alert in that quarter, or that he has designs there. The most simple theory is, that the rebel army has fallen back to Gordonsville, but it may not on that account be the most accurate.

abstract: There have been detained at Quarantine, during the past week, the following vessels from Havana-cargoes sugar and tobacco: Steamer Eagle, barks Albertina, Mary, Grand Canary, schooner Cyclone, brigs Anna Maria, Clara Robbing and Judge Hathaway; all these are discharging at Upper Quarantine. Brig Ortolon and schooner Tropic Bird, from Matanzas, with sugar and molasses, after five days' detention, are permitted to be discharged at the Atlantic Docks by quarantine stevedores. Barks Holland and Express, and the ship Rangoon, from Cientuegos, with sugar, the Consul reporting cases of yellow fever there just before their sailing, after a detention of five days, will be permitted to discharge at Atlantic Docks. Of the above vessels, the following lost one man each from yellow fever on the passage: Brigs Ortolon, Judge Hathaway, schooner Cyclone and bark Mary.

abstract: The Clyde-built side-wheel steamer Jupiter, a noted blockade runner, 184 feet long, 19 feet beam, formerly a passenger boat on the Clyde, was captured by the United States steamer Cimarron (formerly spelled Cimerone) at 3 1/2 o'clock last Sunday morning, in attempting to run the blockade into Savannah, by the way of Warsaw Sound. She has a well assorted cargo of liquors and medicines, anions the latter a good quantity of quinine. She had for passengers four officers of the Royal Wavy, an agent of the Confederacy named WEAVER, and a commercial agent. Also Nassau and Savannah pilots.
lead_paragraph: The Clyde-built side-wheel steamer Jupiter, a noted blockade runner, 184 feet long, 19 feet beam, formerly a passenger boat on the Clyde, was captured by the United States steamer Cimarron (formerly spelled Cimerone) at 3 1/2 o'clock last Sunday morning, in attempting to run the blockade into Savannah, by the way of Warsaw Sound. abstract: Three days' later advices came to hand yesterday by the arrival of the steamship China, from Liverpool on the 12th inst., via Queenstown on the 13th. There now seems to be no doubt that the rams built by Mr. LAIRD will not be permitted to ...
lead_paragraph: Three days' later advices came to hand yesterday by the arrival of the steamship China, from Liverpool on the 12th inst., via Queenstown on the 13th. There now seems to be no doubt that the rams built by Mr. LAIRD will not be permitted to leave Liverpool -- the assertion being positively made that Earl RUSSELL, had given a positive written assurance to that effect to Mr. ADAMS, the United States Minister. Capt. MAFFIT, of the pirate Florida, had run his vessel into difficulty by taking her to Brest. She had been provisionally seized at the suit of a Frenchman named MEINER, who claims an indemnity of 100,000 francs for a vessel which the Florida had taken. The confidence in the success of the new plan for laying the Atlantic telegraph cable in the Summer of 1864 is so firm that Messrs. GLASS, ELLIOTT & CO. had not only contracted to make the cable, but to successfully submerge it. The Archduke MAXIMILIAN is said to have positively accepted the crown of Mexico. The Cotton Market had experienced a slight advance. Breadstuffs were inactive, and Provisions steady. Consols, 93 [???]@93 1/2 for money.

SHEPLEY, 'which we publish this morning, that three civil criminal tribunals have been reestablished in New-Orleans -- the First District Court, and a Recorder's Court in each section of the city above and below Canal-street. These Courts will take cognizance of offences the punishment of which does not exceed $100 fine or thirty days' imprisonment. All offenders of a higher grade will be tried by the First District or Criminal Court of the parish.

abstract: Allusion was briefly made yesterday to the suberb collection of pears and apples just received at the American Institute Fair from the far-famed nurseries of ANDEE LEROY, at Angers, in France.
lead_paragraph: Allusion was briefly made yesterday to the suberb collection of pears and apples just received at the American Institute Fair from the far-famed nurseries of ANDEE LEROY, at Angers, in France. So fine is the collection that it deserves more than mere passing notice. It is undoubtedly the richest assortment of foreign fruit ever received in this country, and its arrival is quite an event in our pomological annals. Some weeks since WM. S. CARPENTER, Esq., of Harrison, Westchester County, in this State, who is cultivating some 500 varieties of fruit on his own estate, and has charge of the rare collection now on exhibition at the Academy of Music, being desirous to procure, if possible, some specimens of the fina fruit of Europe to enhance the interest of his department in the Fair, wrote to LEROY, requesting the latter to send him such samples as he could spare. He heard nothing more about the matter until, a few days ago, there arrived by the City of Manchester a collection, in fine order, embracing no less than 250 varieties of pears, and about 150 of apples, from LEROY's own list. About 100 other varieties were destroyed by the sea voyage in hot weather. The others are displayed on large tables in the centre of the Fair, and are constantly surrounded by admiring groups of horticultural amateurs. For the gratification of our pomological friends some of the finest specimens are mentioned:

abstract: MEETING OF THE NEW-YORK COMPOSITORS. A numerously attended public meeting, of the NewYork Compositors was held yesterday at Tammany Hall, to consider what action should be taken in reference to an advanced scale of prices for book compositors, recently adopted by the Typographical Union No. 6.
lead_paragraph: MEETING OF THE NEW-YORK COMPOSITORS. -- A numerously attended public meeting, of the NewYork Compositors was held yesterday at Tammany Hall, to consider what action should be taken in reference to an advanced scale of prices for book compositors, recently adopted by the Typographical Union No. 6. The old prices paid were $11 per week and 32 and 34 cents per 1,000 ems for reprint and manuscript respectively, the new ones being $13 per week or 37 cents per 1.000 ems. Some employers were stated to have acceded to the new arrangement, while others refused or offered a compromise, and the men in many offices had consequently struck. The meeting resulted in the appointment of a Committee to enforce the new scale in all book offices. The following resolutions were passed:

abstract: The Sanitary Commission have been doing a glorious work in this Department. Each regiment on Morris Island has been supplied by them with tanks of ice water, the ice furnished regularly every day. Large quantities of tomatoes, onions and potatoes, (new crop,) limes, lemons, curried cabbage, (an excellent article to prevent scurvy,) and other articles not to be had of the Commissary, have been distributed among the regiments. Dr. MARSH, the active and humane Superintendentsent, North and procured 300 barrels of pure cider-vinegar. This is made into wholesome and invigorating drink by the addition of water, ice, white sugar and Jamaica Ginger, and all who require it are supplied.

abstract: It is understood that a new enrollment will be ordered in the Sixth District. This is one of the districts in which Gov. SEYMOUR alleged that the enrollment was in excess The President, in consequence, ordered less than half of the quota claimed to be drawn, the balance, if any, to await a reenrollment. It is thought it will commence on the 1st of next month. Meantime, would it not be well for Col. NUGENT to give his attention to the Sixth District office, and, if possible, remove the causes of complaint which have existed in regard to it. A more equal distribution of the authority of the Board would be well; the Provost-Marshal, it is alleged, assumes about all; this the law never coatemplated and does not intend; the powers of all the members are, as they should be, equal.

abstract: Chevalier, Michael; Pamphlet on Recognitionof the Confederacy
snippet: Chevalier, Michael; Pamphlet on Recognitionof the Confederacy
lead_paragraph: -- We have had translated for the TIMES, and publish in full this morning, the late remarkable pamphlet of M. CHEVALIER, discussing the French policy and programme in Mexico, and the question of the recognition of the Confederate States. None of the denials, either from Paris or Washington, that this pamphlet had Imperial inspiration, have succeeded in removing the idea. There is little doubt, at all events, that it foreshadows Louis NAPOLEON'S purposes, hopes and desires. Even without inspiration, however, its great ability and plausibility, render it of high value and interest. But we may say that this question of recognition has already been discussed for two years, and if the French and English Powers and pamphleteers will but keep on discussing it for one-half that period longer, we hope to present them with conclusive arguments why it should not be done.

abstract: From the Army of the Cumberland we have a dispatch, dated Wednesday evening, informing us that on that day there had been no fighting. Gen. ROSECRANS telegraphs to the War Department that he cannot be dislodged from his present position, and the inference is that he will act strictly on the defensive, at least for some time to come.
lead_paragraph: From the Army of the Cumberland we have a dispatch, dated Wednesday evening, informing us that on that day there had been no fighting. Gen. ROSECRANS telegraphs to the War Department that he cannot be dislodged from his present position, and the inference is that he will act strictly on the defensive, at least for some time to come. A dispatch from Cincinnati states, on the authority of a gentleman who left Chattanooga on Monday noon, that the published accounts of the three days' battles are for the most part devoid of truth. He assorts that our army suffered an unquestionable defeat, and that our losses, both in men and material, were enormous. Fifty pieces of cannon he states to be the number taken from us instead of twenty. He concurs in the general assertion that the salvation of the Army of the Cumberland is entirely due to the splendid behavior of Gen. THOMAS' corps. An impression prevailed on Sunday, at Chattanooga, that Gen. BURNSIDE'S army was in imminent peril of attack on its flank.

abstract: While returning from a small fire on Wednesday evening, the members of Hose Company No. 7, and Engine Company No. 11, of Greenpoint, had a general fight on Franklin-street, in which a number of both parties were damaged, and one member of the latter Company had his jaw broken. The Police finally restored order, and Officer KING had his shoulder badly injured by a projected brick....About the same hour, Engine Company No. 7, and Hook and Ladder Company No. 2, of Brooklyn, E.D., had a fight in Division-avenue. One man was badly wounded on the head by a blow from a trumpet.

abstract: -- This Committee sent out sixty-two substitutes, yesterday, of whom eight proved unfit for acceptance by the Provost-Marshals, on account of physical disability, and were rejected. The matter of Col. HALL'S regiment, noliced yesterday, is not disposed of, the Colonel failing to appear at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. The Committee meet again at 9 AM. to-day, to give him an opportunity to be heard in support of the claim of the drafted men of his corps to the exemption for members of the active militia, provided by the ordinance.

abstract: Fail Fashions; opening of millinery
lead_paragraph: September is usually one of those months of transition in which it is most difficult to speak with certainty of styles that will be adopted in the future. Even the semi-annual opening does not always reveal the choicest secrets of what is to be, the public exhibition being rather intended to suit the tastes and tempt the pockets of Peoria, than settle the vexed questions of taste and style for the fastidious Flora McFlimseys of Fifth-avenue and Madison-square.

abstract: Indian Allies of the Rebels
lead_paragraph: Mississippi rebel Governors -- three of them fugitives -- who have just held their dismal Convention in the wilds of Texas, say in their address: "Let our Eastern Confederates do their duty; these States and our Indian allies will do theirs" We imagine that the rebels will have to give up even their dependence on their Indian allies. The whole of the Indian Territory is now in our hands -- recovered by the gallant Gen. BLUNT. The Cherokees even now are our allies; and the Creeks, who have heretofore been the main support of the rebels west of Arkansas, gave up the Confederacy after the late fight, and nearly all their warriors have offered to come over to our side. In regard to the Comanches, the news from Texas now-a-days is pretty much like what it used to be of old; and we should hardly think, from their ceaseless assaults upon the whites, that the rebels could very confidently count upon them as "allies." The fact, however, that the aid of the Indian is now looked for with anxiety, shows the desperate straits of the rebels west of the Mississippi.

abstract: About 5 o'clock Wednesday afternoon, a collision occurred on the Morris and Essex Railroad, near Waterloo station, about forty miles from Jersey City, between the 12 o'clock freight train from New-York for Hacketstown and an excursion train belonging to the Sussex Railroad, bound for Stanhope.
lead_paragraph: -- About 5 o'clock Wednesday afternoon, a collision occurred on the Morris and Essex Railroad, near Waterloo station, about forty miles from Jersey City, between the 12 o'clock freight train from New-York for Hacketstown and an excursion train belonging to the Sussex Railroad, bound for Stanhope. The collision resulted in badly damaging one of the locomotives and the complete wreck of four of the rear cars, injuring thirteen persons, two of whom subsequently died.

abstract: Yesterday was a great day among the wearers of crinoline and artificial flowers. The Fall fashions are in, and what could be more exciting? What woman is not interested in the event? What man? -- what married man, what bachelor, young or old? What purse is not interested in it? We give all the news about it, and all the facts concerning the new fashions this morning, and we have no doubt it will be perused with absorbing interest by the ladies and tremulous interest by the men. Money, however, it seems, is very abundant; and our reporter, who is au fail in the matter, says that "the most costly fabrics, the richest garments find a ready sale, and the question is not so much what is new, what is in the best taste, as what costs the most money."

abstract: As a matter of great interest, we translate in full the pamphlet of MICHEL CHEVALIER, lately published in Paris, under the above title, and which has caused some stir both in Europe and this country, from the fact that on its first appearance it was currently reported to have been "inspired" by the Emperor NAPOLEON, and to be indicative of his policy on this continent.
lead_paragraph: As a matter of great interest, we translate in full the pamphlet of MICHEL CHEVALIER, lately published in Paris, under the above title, and which has caused some stir both in Europe and this country, from the fact that on its first appearance it was currently reported to have been "inspired" by the Emperor NAPOLEON, and to be indicative of his policy on this continent. The fact of "inspiration" has been semi-officially denied in Paris, and ostentatiously denied in this country from Washington; but those who fully comprehend all the mysteries of Imperial "inspiration" are still of the opinion that the brochure has some degree of it, and that it was thrown out with the Emperor's sanction, to subserve a purpose. M. CHEVALIER, it will be remembered it was, who threw out the hint, or had the hint thrown out to him, concerning the "supremacy of the Latin race in Mexico," which the Emperor made the chief pretext for the Mexican expedition. There is no doubt that the present pamphlet is, at all events, an Imperial "feeler."
headline: {'main': 'FRANCE IN AMERICA.; THE QUESTION OF RECOGNITION The New French Pamphlet "France, Mexico and the Confederate Sates."', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'FRANCE IN AMERICA.; THE QUESTION OF RECOGNITION The New French Pamphlet "France, Mexico and the Confederate Sates."', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The fugitive rebel  Governors of the Trans-Mississippi States, Messrs. REYNOLDS, of Missouri, FLANNAGAN, of Arkansas, MOORE, of Louisiana, and LUBBOCK,  of Texas, (the latter not yet a fugitive,) have just met in convention at Marshall, Texas to consider the present aspect of affairs in that region.
lead_paragraph: -- The fugitive rebel Governors of the Trans-Mississippi States, Messrs. REYNOLDS, of Missouri, FLANNAGAN, of Arkansas, MOORE, of Louisiana, and LUBBOCK, of Texas, (the latter not yet a fugitive,) have just met in convention at Marshall, Texas to consider the present aspect of affairs in that region. They have issued an address reviewing their misfortunes, setting forth their bright prospects, urging renewed efforts, and announcing that the Western section of the Confederacy will seek no destiny separate, from that of the rebel States east of the Mississippi. They have also established themselves as a Committee of Public Safety for the purpose of helping the fortunes of the Confederacy.
headline: {'main': 'A HOPELESS PROSPECT.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A HOPELESS PROSPECT.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The inefficiency of the engineers in the navy is causing serious embarrassment to the Government. We recently published a general order of the Navy Department, dismissing the Chief Engineer of the Sonoma for neglecting the engines of his vessel. Since that time the steamer Fort Jackson has been also disabled by the negligence of the engineer on watch, and to-day we have to record another general order of the Navy Department, announcing the dismissal of two more officers for similar dereliction of duty.

abstract: The batch of news from Chattanooga given by us in exienso, this morning, from the Richmond papers of the 23d, confirm our conjectures as to the presence of LONGSTREET with BRAGG in the recent great battles.
lead_paragraph: The batch of news from Chattanooga given by us in exienso, this morning, from the Richmond papers of the 23d, confirm our conjectures as to the presence of LONGSTREET with BRAGG in the recent great battles. They participated in the action of Saturday, and opened the assault on Monday. The rebels claim to have captured up to Tuesday last 4,000 prisoners and 30 pieces of artillery, besides compelling Gen. ROSECRANS to destroy large quantities of bag-page and stores. They acknowledge, however, terrible losses on their side, particularly in officers, and admit that the battles up to the 22d had not proved decisive.
headline: {'main': 'GENERAL NEWS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'GENERAL NEWS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The rebel papers now admit that they sent large reinforcements, both of men and Generals, to BRAGG in Georgia, prior to the late battle. The Richmond Dispatch says that "heavy reinforcements" were sent to BRAGG, and a rebel telegram from the battle-field says that LONG-STREET and HILL (D.H.) attacked the Yankees. (This last-mentioned General, it will be observed, is not the officer who commands one of the three corps of the rebel army of Virginia.) The Marietta (Ga.) Rebel says that Gen. BRAGG was "surrounded by a galaxy of higher military talent, and backed by a larger army, than he ever before commanded during his whole military career." It also gives an exclamation of JEFF. DAVIS, that he would "snatch Tennessee from the clutches of the Abolitionists, if it took the united armies of the South to accomplish it." We perceive no mention in any of the rebel papers of Gen. Jo. JOHNSTON having been on the field with BRAGG, though there is little doubt that he sent up reinforcements.

abstract: Reception at New-York Chamber of Commerce
snippet: Reception at New-York Chamber of Commerce
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon the merchants and Bankers of New-York assembled en masse, at the hall of the Chamber of Commerce, to accord a befitting reception to Admiral FARRAGUT, who has recently come among us from his long, arduous and glorious campaigns in the South, where he has so gallantly borne the National flag through hostile broadsides to ever-recurring triumphs. By 1 P.M. the apartments were densely packed with our most prominent citizens, among whom were; Mayor OPDYKE, CYRUS W. FIELD, PETER COOPER, Col. SHEPARD, and a host of others equally well known. Shortly afterward the distinguished guest appeared in the escort of CHARLES GOULD, Esq., who formally introduced him to an assemblage larger than any that has been seen in that hall since the great patriotic meeting held there at the outbreak of the rebellion, in the Spring of 1S6I. The Admiral was greeted with loud and enthusiastic cheering, which he modestly acknowledged.
