abstract: We were shown yesterday a letter from Charleston, S. C, to a gentleman in this city, asking him to purchase a lot of goods, to be sent to JOHN B. LAPITTE, Nassau, and, through him, to the party in Charleston. The letter reads as follows: "Dear Friend -- I would be much obliged to you to spend for me in Philadelphia from $100 to $500. I cannot send you any money, as the kind I have you could not use, and, if I had gold, I could not send it with safety; therefore, you will be obliged to wait on me until the blockade is raised, and if I have no gold then, I will have cotton. You can ship any box or package by way of New-York to Nassau, you having no vessels running to that port from Philadelphia." -- Philadelphia Ledger, Sept. 24.

abstract: Our London correspondent, referring to the seizure of the Florida at Brest, to answer some claims for property destroyed by her, adds that that will probably be the last of her. abstract: A letter from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac, received to-day, says Gen. BUFORD with a portion of his division drove the rebel pickets, on Tuesday, through Madison Court-house. Three miles beyond, he encountered a strong force of the enemy's cavalry. After a spirited fight, he forced them to retreat, and drove them across the Rapidan at a point where the Gordonsville pike reaches the river.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Thursday, Sept. 24.

abstract: On Snatching Tennessee
lead_paragraph: -- The Marietta (Ga.)Rebel says that "President DAVIS was heard to exclaim in a circle of friends at the capital, that he would snatch Tennessee from the clutches of the Abolitionists if it took the united armies of the South to accomplish it." And to this the Rebel adds that "from the signs of the times it begins to look very much as if that obstinate man meant what he said." JEFF. DAVIS has just made a desperate and obstinate effort to snatch Tennessee, but it looks as if he had undertaken too big a job, even with the united armies of the South. His object was to overwhelm ROSECRANS at the first onset, and while the Army of the Potomac was inactive, and its ranks depleted. But BRAGG and his "brilliant galaxy" did not succeed even in setting their foot on Tennessee soil; and ROSECRANS now telegraphs that Tennessee's gateway, Chattanooga, is impregnable; while the menacing advance of Gen. MEADE will prevent JEFF. DAVIS from sending any more reinforcements from Richmond.
headline: {'main': 'JEFF. DAVIS ON SNATCHING.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'JEFF. DAVIS ON SNATCHING.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: By Special Order, No. 408, dated Washington, Sept. 11, a new Commission has been appointed to investigate the causes and circumstances attending the burning of the steamer Ruth. The Commission will sit in St. Louis, and is composed as follows: Maj.-Gen. DAVID HUNTER, United States Volunteers; Brig. Gen. W.K. STRONG, United States Volunteers; and Maj. F.D. CALLENDER, of the Ordnance Department -- the latter to act as Recorder of the Commission. A former Commission, appointed by order of Maj.-Gen. SCHOFIELD, some weeks since -- consisting of Maj. JONES, of the Pay Department; Maj. BARNES, and Capt. DWIGHT, of Gen. SCHOFIELD'S Staff -- adjourned a few days since. What the result of their investigation was, is not vet publicly known. -- Washington Intelligencer.

abstract: There has been a good deal of speculation as to who was the real commander at the late battle of Chickamauga, as we suppose it may be called, in Northern Georgia.
lead_paragraph: There has been a good deal of speculation as to who was the real commander at the late battle of Chickamauga, as we suppose it may be called, in Northern Georgia. Military men doubted whether Gen. BRAGG was in command, as the tactics displayed were so unlike those that Gen. BRAGG had practiced in all his previous battles; and, we may say, the result was so unlike that which has followed all of Gen. BRAGG'S previous efforts. Surmise has placed Gen. JOE JOHNSTON in command; it has assigned the position to LONG-STREET, and even Gen. LEE has been suspected of being on the field. The massing of troops in solid body and hurling them with rapidity from one part of the field to another, engaging in succession the different corps of an enemy, is a feat which so few Generals have shown themselves capable of, in this or any other war, that we have been wont, in this instance, to assign it to such Generals as have been previously associated with it.
headline: {'main': 'THE REBEL COMMANDER AT THE BATTLE.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE REBEL COMMANDER AT THE BATTLE.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The conquering game of the home and home match between these Clubs, took place yesterday on the St. George's cricket ground, Hoboken, the charge for admission being ten cents; and there were more persons present on the occasion than there have been during the entire season on the St. George's, NewYork and Manhattan cricket grounds combined.
lead_paragraph: The conquering game of the home and home match between these Clubs, took place yesterday on the St. George's cricket ground, Hoboken, the charge for admission being ten cents; and there were more persons present on the occasion than there have been during the entire season on the St. George's, NewYork and Manhattan cricket grounds combined. This shows that cricket has been almost obliterated by base ball, which, but ten years since, was in its infancy and could only count a corporal's guard to witness a match, while a cricket match would be attended for a couple of days together by from 8,000 to 10,000 persons. The main cause of this is, that a few cricketers -- who have become stale in the opinion of the public -- play pretty much in all the matches (or the few Clubs (except St. George) that exist only in name; while Bass Ball Clubs play their matches with their bona fide members, and consequently their medium players always have a prospect before them of being chosen to play in either first-class or second-class matches with other Clubs, or in matches between the members of their own Clubs, provided they can acquire the least practical knowledge of the game. The base-ball match, yesterday, was hardly up to the mark, or equal to the great reputation of the two Clubs; a great deal of money changed hands on the result. It must be said, in mitigation, that the Mutuals were short of some of their regular first nine, and that the conformation of the ground was very much against the fielding. The match was not by any means as evenly played as was the great match on Monday between the first nines of the compositors of the NEW-YORK TIMES and Sunday Mercury.

abstract: The Copperhead Press will never be done clamoring it into the ears of the country that the "conscription is a failure," that "the draft has produced no men," and that the Government must, at last, rely on volunteering, stimulated by bounties, to fill up the ranks of our armies. But it is not altogether true we apprehend, that the draft is a failure. It is not a failure, either in a moral or material sense. It has afforded the opportunity of establishing beyond all question the supremacy of the National Government, the devotion of the people to it, and their determination to uphold it against secret foes and open enemies. Certain political schemers thought they held in their hands a veto on the National Government -- and that they only needed a[???]ukase from the Executive Chamber at Albany or Trenton, or even from the "Pewter Mug" of this City, to bring the Administration to its knees before a local faction, or on its back before the rebels at Richmond. This delusion is past, and the country is infinitely stronger and better for it.

abstract: Rebel Bad Faith in Using Paroled Men
snippet: Rebel Bad Faith in Using Paroled Men
lead_paragraph: The action of Gen. GRANT in paroling the 30,000 rebel soldiers captured by him at Vicksburgh was universally commended at the time as a humane, generous and economical disposition of them. It spared the rebel prisoners the hardships of a protracted confinement in the North; it was a tribute to the fortitude with which the enemy had borne the siege; and it relieved the Government from the necessity of detailing a large guard to accompany and hold the prisoners, when the army was needed for immediate operations against Gen. Jo. JOHNSTON, and also from the expense of transportation and subsistence for so large a body of men for so long a time, and for so great a distance as they would have had to travel, before delivered up in exchange.

abstract: The presence of a Russian fleet in the harbor of New York is welcomed by all prisons with the greatest pleasure. Five splendid men-of-war, fully manned and in perfect trim, are now [???]ing at anchor in the North River, in full view of our noble harbor -- the frigates Alexander News[???]y, the Feresret, the Dsl[???]aba, and the corvettes Vitiaze and the Variag. They will soon be joined by the clippers Almos, Q[???]urnroud and the Ja[???]ont. The Imperial flag of Russia -- a piece of wh[???]e quadrangular bunting, with broad diagonal bars of sky [???] -- loafs from the foretop of each vessel. The attention or gazers is also attracted by the band striking up occasionally a Russian air, which sounds very melodious to an American ear. At present the newly-arrived vessels present a busy scene, in preparing for the reception of their American friends.

abstract: Wollenhaupt, Herman J., a noted Pianist
snippet: Wollenhaupt, Herman J., a noted Pianist
lead_paragraph: DEATH OF HERMANN A. WOLLENHAUPT, THE PIANIST AND COMPOSER. -- The sudden death of Mr. HERMANN A. WOLLENHAUPT has created a profound feeling of regret in the public mind, and a sentiment of sincere sorrow among a large circle of our citizens. Mr. WOLLENHAUPT was universally respected for his brilliant musical abilities, and beloved for the noble and generous qualities which adorned his character. These endeared him to all who knew him, but though his well merited successes may have caused some a jealous pang, it is probable that he had not one enemy in the world. HERMANN A. WOLLENHAUPT was born at Schkenditz, Province of Saxony, Prussia, in 1827. His rare musical talents brought him early before the public, and he achieved signal successes wherever he appeared. In 1845 he came to New-York, where his piano performances at the Philharmonic, and other concerts, rapidly gained for him a brilliant teaching connection, so that in two years he was enabled to send for his parents and his brother and sisters. These he educated and maintained, devoting all his energies and means to their comfort and advancement. Observing great talent in his brother BRUNO, he sent him to Germany to study, keeping him there seven years, until he had achieved the position of a first-class artist. During the years of his residence in this City, HERMANN WOLLENHAUPT produced a large number of brilliant piano compositions, which have become famous, not only in this country, but throughout all Europe. They have become standard works, and have made his name respected wherever they are known. The art has lost much by his sudden and untimely death, and no one can calculate the deep grief that follows him to his grave from his home circle and his hosts of friends. His life was one of utter devotion and self-sacrifice, and he has surely met his reward, where deeds and not words are considered in a life's account. He was buried in Cypress Hills Cemetery, and his funeral was attended by every musician of eminence in the City. On the day of his funeral all the principal music-stores and piano-stores were closed as a mark of respect to his memory.

abstract: -- The Russian steam frigate Osliaba, which came into our harbor ten days ago from Gadiz, and whose officers have been so cordially welcomed by our municipal authorities and by our citizens generally, was yesterday joined by four more Russian men-of-war, recently from Cronstadt, comprising two steam frigates -- the Alexander Newsky and the Perescet -- and two corvettes, the Vilia[???]e and the Variag. The squadron will be reinforced in a day or two by three clippers named Almas, Isamvond and Iahont. The Alexander Newsky is the flagship of the squadron, and the whole are under the command of Rear-Admiral LASOFSKY.

abstract: The fact that Gen. ROSECRANS is able to hold Chattanooga, is the most important and encouraging feature in the results of the late battle. The capture of that great strategic centre, and its permanent occupation by a large army, has been the main object of operations in the region stretching from the Ohio River to the mountains ever since the war began. We are there established in the centre of
lead_paragraph: The fact that Gen. ROSECRANS is able to hold Chattanooga, is the most important and encouraging feature in the results of the late battle. The capture of that great strategic centre, and its permanent occupation by a large army, has been the main object of operations in the region stretching from the Ohio River to the mountains ever since the war began. We are there established in the centre of the so-called Confederate territory, and from his lofty lines Gen. ROSECRANS not only defends Tennessee and Kentucky in his rear, but menaces the upper regions of Georgia and both Carolinas, and practically nullifies all rebel operations between the Coosa and the Mississippi. So long as Gen. ROSECRANS shall hold Chattanooga, we shall regard his Fall campaign through Middle Tennessee as a great success, even though, unfortunately, we cannot claim the late battle in Northern Georgia as a victory. We have reason to believe that the possession of this point was the sole immediate object of Gen. ROSECRANS. It was undoubtedly his purpose to fight BRAGG as soon as his strategy drew the latter out from Chattanooga, or while the rebel army was in course of getting out, but it was not his intention to pursue BRAGG down through Central Georgia until such time as he had secured his position and his line of communications, and established a secondary base on the Tennessee River. His advance southward of Chattanooga was not for the purpose of fighting the then escaped army of BRAGG, as the position and line of advance of the three corps of his army prove. BRAGG would have still been pursued, but it would have been when ROSECRANS had secured himself and had received such reinforcements as were necessary for the work, and which he had in vain attempted to obtain.

abstract: Record of; Erroneous Report of his Death
snippet: Record of; Erroneous Report of his Death
lead_paragraph: -The full accounts that are reaching us from the hard-contested field near Chickamauga Creek do justice to the services of one of the ablest and most successful Generals in the Union army -- Maj.-Gen. THOMAS. It appears that this gallant soldier bore the brunt of the rebel attack unharmed, on both days of the fight, though the onset in each case was impetuous and overwhelming. It is no discredit to the corps of Gens. MCCOOK and CRITTENDEN that they were broken by the outnumbering hosts of the enemy. The metal of these men had been tried before, and they are known and approved as among the bravest of our Union soldiers. But if a part of the gallant army of ROSECRANS could be driven back without disgrace, it must not be denied that unusual credit and renown are due to that portion which withstood every shock, and dealt horrible slaughter upon a foe so numerous as to be deemed invincible. This is the signal merit of the corps of Gen. THOMAS in the sanguinary battle in Northern Georgia. The stubborn fighting of this portion of the army is all that saved the fortunes of the day, as we understand the contest at this distance; and if the enemy fails to follow up his supposed advantages, it will be mainly because of the damaging blows inflicted by this heroic General.

abstract: Since the evacuation of Forts Wagner and Gregg by the rebels, and the occupation of the whole of Morris Island by our troops, twenty days ago, operations seem to have come to a complete stand-still in Charleston harbor. Gen. GILLMORE has not fired a she during these three weeks, and our iron-clad navy has not fired a shot that has done any service. It is said that Gen. GILLMORE considers his preliminary operations ended in reducing Fort Sumter and the works on Morris Island, and that he now expects the monitors to push their way inside of the harbor. It was certainly the understanding of the whole country that when these operations wore performed, the monitors would next set actively about their work, and it was even universally believed that they could then push directly up to Charleston itself. The plea put in for their inaction is that there are insurmountable obstructions in the harbor, and that until these are removed no progress can be made. We have not heard that any determined or intelligent efforts have been made to remove them. At this distance it simply seems as if the whole army and navy were -- stuck.

abstract: -- The Richmond Sentinel, of Sept. 22, says: "There was considerable frost in the neighborhood of Richmond yesterday morning. To what extent vegetation has been injured, we have not learned; but fear the effect on tender plants has been destructive. Yesterday the air was pure, skies bright, and, at noon, warm. The ladies have taken advantage of the pleasant weather and dust-laid streets, and graced the public thoroughfares with their presence in unusual numbers."

abstract: GERMAN OPERA. -- The members of Mr. ANSCHUTZ's company of German artists arrived here yesterday morning in the steamship Bavaria, after a long and tedious passage from Hamburg. They will make their first appearance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday next -- Mr. ANSCHUTZ having arranged a single performance at that establishment, in order that his artists may make a slight acquaintance with the public and the subscribers previous to their departure for Baltimore. It was found impossible to secure a house in New-York -- hence the necessity of reporting to the sister city.

abstract: THE MAIDEN'S BLUSH.--Incomparably the most beautiful of apples--the Queen Pomological--is the specimen of the Maiden's Blush, now on exhibition at the Agriculturist Office, No. 41 Park-row. It is a mooted point, and one which nothing but nothing will satifactorily settle, to the great majority of those seeing it, whether nature did the work at the exquisite skill of some cunning hand in wax.
lead_paragraph: THE MAIDEN's BLUSH. -- Incomparably the most beautiful of apples -- the Queen Pomological -- is the specimen of the Maiden's Blush, now on exhibition at the Agriculturist Office, No. 41 Park-row. It is a mooted point, and one which nothing but nothing will satifactorily settle, to the great majority of those seeing it, whether nature did the work at the exquisite skill of some cunning hand in wax. But it has the fruity odor, and there is the parole d'honneur of those attached to the office as to its genuine growth. 'Tis fitly named, for maiden's cheek never wore a more delicate or lovelier hue. The specimen is from Iowa; it is almost a shame to drop to the common-places and say that the Maiden's Blush is good for the table either "stewed, raw or roasted."

abstract: A DECISION BY JUDGE LUDLOW. -- On Saturday the effect of the suspension of the writ of habeas corpus was made the subject of discussion in the Quarter Sessions, before Judge LUDLOW. A writ had been issued, and served early in the week, and before the date of the President's Proclamation. It was directed to Dr. ISAAC HAYS, in charge of one of the Military Hospitals. On Saturday, when the case was called up, the United states District Attorney called attention to the President's Proclamation, and to Judge CADWALA[???]ER's decision that it suspended proceedings in cases where the writ had already issued. The counsel for the relator insisted that his client did not come within the term of the proclamation. The writ had, he said, been served upon "ISAAC HAYS, M.D.," and there was no allegation in the petition that the relator was held as a soldier.

abstract: It is understood that the regular Board of Stock Brokers have purchased the old Government stores, Nos. 10 and 12 Broad-street, and design converting them to the purposes of the Association. The price is stated to have been $200,000. A privilege of twelve feet wide to and on Wall-street, for the main entrance, has also been secured. Should these be the facts, the Board will be able to have rooms ample and properly arranged for their purposes. That portion of the building not appropriated by them will doubtless be converted into offices.

abstract: Liberal Sentiment of England
lead_paragraph: We commented recently upon the extent to which the scarcity of labor, combined with the rapid growth of trade in Europe, had lessened that abhorrence of Slavery which thirty years ago everybody either had, or affected to have. In fact, it is one of the lamentable results of the prodigious expansion of commerce and industry which this century has witnessed, that material progress has come to be looked on in almost all countries rather as a means of making money than as a means of improving the condition of the human race. Capital is somewhat outraged by the pretensions of labor, and unwillingness to labor to any extent that may be necessary to make "investments" profitable, has gradually come to be looked on as a crime. This is at the bottom of most of the furious denunciations that we so constantly hear of the Jamaica and Hayti negroes; and when one of the apostles of this new school of political philosophy shows you that fifty thousand dollars, put into a plantation, would bring thirty per cent. if he could get labor, he is scandalized by your doubts of the lawfulness of his seizing as many men and women as he can lay hands on and lashing them into industry. What is perhaps strangest and saddest in it all is, that the chief of this school should be THOMAS CARLYLE, who thirty years ago preached the young men and women into furious quest of the "better life," and made the welkin ring with his denunciations of fraud, injustice and all other species of Slavery.

abstract: A telegram from Gen. ROSECRANS, dated last night, says he made a reconnaisance in force along the enemy's lines yesterday afternoon and found him in force. The enemy did not resist for advance of our reconnoitering column, which returned to its quarters after having accomplished the object of the movement, which proved to be of considerable importance.

abstract: -- MICHAEL SEMONOFF, First Master of the Russian corvette Witzass, and NICHOLAS BOURAVENSKOFF, Second Master of the same vessel, appeared before Justice KELLY yesterday, and made complaint that they had been robbed at a disreputable house in Greene-street of twenty-nine pieces of Russian gold, worth $174 American money. Officer PALMER, of the Eighth Precinct, arrested three girls named KATE HAGAR, ELMIRA SINCLAIR and CLARA HALL, on the charge of having committed the robbery. Officer PALMER made a search of the room where the offence is said to have been committed, and found one of the gold pieces under a washstand. The prisoners were committed for examination.
lead_paragraph: -- MICHAEL SEMONOFF, First Master of the Russian corvette Witzass, and NICHOLAS BOURAVENSKOFF, Second Master of the same vessel, appeared before Justice KELLY yesterday, and made complaint that they had been robbed at a disreputable house in Greene-street of twenty-nine pieces of Russian gold, worth $174 American money. abstract: His Services at Chickamauga
lead_paragraph: Major-Gen. GEORGE HENRY THOMAS, whose corps appears to have borne the brunt of the recent battles in Northwestern Georgia, was born in Southampton County, Va., July 31, 1816. He was graduated at West Point in 1840, and commissioned Brevet Second Lieutenant in the Third artillery, and joined his regiment in Florida. For his services in the Florida war he was breveted First Lieutenant in 1841, served at Fort Brown during its bombardment by the Mexicans, won the brevets of Captain at Monterey and Major at Buena Vista, and in 1849 was again sent to Florida, to serve against the Indians. From 1851 to 1854 he was Instructor of Artillery and Cavalry in the Military Academy. He was then ordered to California, where he commanded Fort Yuma until 1855, when he was promoted to be Major of the Second cavalry. From 1856 to 1860 he was on duty in Texas, commanding his regiment for the last three years of that time against the Indians and on exploring expeditions. In 1861 he was ordered to Carlisle Barracks, Pennsylvania, was promoted to be Colonel of the Fifth cavalry May 3, and ordered to report to Gen. PATTERSON.

abstract: The Battle of; Particulars
lead_paragraph: In the course of the 17th, already unmistakable signs [???]cated that the enemy had discovered the week points [???] our position and were massing their forms in front of our left centre and left, for the [???] purpose of crushing those parts of our lines, or getting between them and Chattanooga. A corresponding movement by the left flank was thence made by the whole army further down the West Chickamauga, so that on Friday morning our extreme left rested at Gordon's [???] at the crossing of the Chickamauga by the Lafayette Pike, above 12 miles southwest of Chattanooga. On the morning of the 18th, (Friday,) a portion of the expected reinforcements, consisting of two brigades of the rese[???]e corps, respectively commanded by Cols. MCCOOK and MITCHELL, made their appearance near Chattanooga, and were immediately ordered to make a reconnoissance toward Ringgold, and develop the intentions of the enemy from that quarter.

abstract: The Hamburg steamer Bavaria, Capt. MEIER, arrived yesterday morning from Hamburg, via Southampton the 10th inst. She brings 42 cabin and 216 steerage passengers. Was detained one day at Southampton on account of heavy gales in the North Sea. She had adverse winds most of the passage, and was three days off Cape Race in a dense fog. In the channel when off Pentland, passed Bremen steamer Bremen, for Southampton. The Bavaria arrived off the Hook at 2 o'clock yesterday morning.

abstract: The New Policy of the King
snippet: The New Policy of the King
lead_paragraph: The reform project of the Austrian Kaiser has been at once a source of pleasure and of alarm to VON BISMARK and his master. Of alarm, lest it should result in reducing Prussia to a secondary rank in the Confederation; of plesure, as affording them so excellent an opportunity for appealing to the Nation, and attempting to turn its attention from domestic grievances to external dangers.

abstract: Letter to the War Democracy on the Political Situation

abstract: The country has never been in more need of clear heads and steady hands than now. The Summer successes of the National cause exalted our hearts and hopes beyond expression.
lead_paragraph: The country has never been in more need of clear heads and steady hands than now. The Summer successes of the National cause exalted our hearts and hopes beyond expression. It was thought the Union had well nigh thrown off that black nightmare of rebellion that for two years had been seated on its breast, and that it was about to rise refreshed, and, like the sun leaping up the horizon, "rejoicing as a giant to run his race."

lead_paragraph: Intense excitement was caused in Printing House-square and its vicinity yesterday afternoon, at 4 o'clock, by the killing on the street, in front of the "Pewter Mug," No. 162 Nassau-street, of WILLIAM N. BROWN, one of the proprietors of that well known saloon. JAMES H. NIXON, a discharged soldier, who lost a leg at Ball's Bluff, was the prepetrator.

abstract: JAQUES MONAISE, the Frenchman, who was convicted on Friday of rape, committed upon Miss MARGARET LYONS, at a disreputable house in Greenestreet, was to have been sentenced yesterday morning, but on the application of prisoner's counsel, sentence was deferred, with the consent of the prosecuting Attorney, to enable the Court to consider some questions of law arising in the case, on Which the prisoner's counsel propose to move for a new trial.

abstract: The time must come when we shall see the end of this rebellion, and the consequent disbanding of the greater portion of our armies now in the field, and it is not inopportune to look at the return of our soldiers, and the effect...
lead_paragraph: The time must come when we shall see the end of this rebellion, and the consequent disbanding of the greater portion of our armies now in the field, and it is not inopportune to look at the return of our soldiers, and the effect that they are destined to have on our general social condition. We had somewhat of an opportunity to test this upon the return of the two years' regiments, but not fully, from the fact that they were but a small portion of those in service: and, again, a large percentage reenlisted within a few weeks. At the close of this war the State of New-York alone will have over one hundred thousand men returning to their homes, once more to become citizens and an immense element for good or for evil. There is no disputing the fact that some of these will find it hard to settle into their old avocations, and will be a restless, non-laboring portion of the people, always ready for fillibustering, and hard to repress on that point. But it is of the main body who will become distributed through the people, of whom we speak. They have been taken from every grade of life, and from every trade, pursuit and profession, and upon each respective grade and profession they will bring to bear the results of the military education they have received. This education, extending over a period of nearly three years, is one based upon the very first principles of society, discipline, both mental and physical, and a recognition at once both of the sovereignty of the individual and the authority of the ruler. The man who has been taken from the plow and the workshop, without ever having felt the power that was invisibly over him, and always working to restrain his passions and to protect him, will come back with a knowledge of that unseen law or discipline which makes him either a good soldier or a good citizen. The one who was a ne'er-do-well in the past, has been taught the value of personal struggles, and the worth of personal pride, and, while forced to a life of temperance, and social consideration for his fellows, has had, if he was capable of reform, one worked upon him, that will last a life, time. The man who went away, leaving behind him money, or the love or pursuit of it, or leaving behind some petty, trifling, or dishonorable attachment to which he had devoted his life, will return, having forgotten the goddess of his idolatry, and become awakened to the real business of life. He who enlisted from absolute friendlessness at home, generated possibly by his own faults, has, by commencing a new life, made new associations, and placed himself in a regenerated phase with the old ones; has, while he has shaken off the past, learned from his experience that a man cannot live without ministering to the comfort or enjoyment of those with whom he comes in contact. The mechanic or laborer has been instructed in the value of time and punctuality, and will come back to the workshops and the fields, not only believing in the justice that should be rendered him, but in that which he should render. If their officers have done their duty, they will know that "cleanliness is next to godliness," and will understand the simple laws that govern health. They will have learned that, not only life but health can be supported without indulging every appetite suggested. They will know the meaning of manly, honorable pride, and indulge it, and that pride which will teach them to speak of their past, will keep them careful in the present and in the future. The soldier who would "shoulder his crutch, and show how fields were won," will be careful what, he does to blacken that reputation for which he served in peril, and of which he is so proud to speak. This education will be carried into their homes, and be transmitted to their children. The soldier who has for so long a time been debarred the society of women will be trebly appreciative, and whether he is beginning his matrimonial venture, or continuing it, will more thoroughly understand the importance of woman to every hour of his life, and the weight of his enhanced toils in her absence. The discipline he has been taught in the army he will insensibly introduce in his family, and his children will find a benefit from his education, which, like bread cast upon the waters, will be returned to him after many days. Last upon the list is the fact that the returned soldier, in most cases, is always in the midst of those who were once his military comrades. He has enlisted from a locality, and returns to it, and among those comrades he has a character to uphold that cannot be sacrificed lightly. He stands in the same relation that a man does to his family. They have passed through sunshine and storm together, and a fellowship has been created that must last, as long as life, and have an influence in the cultivation of those social qualities that bind them together, and break down the barriers continually built by men whose entire soul is absorbed in the one idea of gain.

abstract: The capture of this steamer, by Admiral WILKES, produced in England a degree of harsh commentary, which is likely to be softened, if not reversed, when the grounds of her recent condemnation by a United States Court shall have become known and understood. We have received a stenographic report of the trial, which is now being printed for transmission to Europe.
lead_paragraph: The capture of this steamer, by Admiral WILKES, produced in England a degree of harsh commentary, which is likely to be softened, if not reversed, when the grounds of her recent condemnation by a United States Court shall have become known and understood. We have received a stenographic report of the trial, which is now being printed for transmission to Europe. It appears that for the purpose of avoiding delay in the decision, Judge BETTS deferred for the present the preparation of a written opinion. But we find, in the report above mentioned, the argument of Mr. E. DELAFIELD SMITH, the United States District-Attorney, setting forth, in a clear and compressed style, the facts and principles upon which the Government relied in the prosecution of the case.

abstract: Particulars of Capture
lead_paragraph: A letter to the Chicago Journal, dated Little Rock, Ark., Sept. 10, gives interesting particulars of the occupation of that place. The Arkansas River was crossed upon a pontoon bride eight miles below Little Rock. Gen. DAVIDSON's column effected the passage after some opposition by the enemy, who destroyed two steamers to prevent their falling into the hands of our forces, and the column was formed by giving Col. RITTER's brigade, with STRONG's and LOVE[???]Y's mountain howitzers, the advance; Col. MERRILL's brigade, with HADLEY's battery, the centre; and Col RITTER's brigade, with CLARKSON's battery, the rear.

abstract: What he may do
lead_paragraph: Some of our Western exchanges took a gloomy view of the results that might follow a "bad defeat" of ROSECRANS near Chattanooga. They anticipated, in that case, a flank movement by BRAGG that would bring him immediately northward again through Tennessee into Kentucky. And ROSECRANS, if beaten in battle, would not be able to follow and head him off, as Gen. BUELL did so successfully on the former occasion.

abstract: -- The checks with forged indorsements, which were passed recently at the farmers and Mechanics' Bank, were stolen from letters going from and coming to the officers of the Camden and Amboy Railroad Company. The first check stolen was one of six which had been sent to a firm in New-York for dividends on railroad stock. The letter containing them was received by one of the firm, but not the person for whom they were intended, and without the letter being examined, though opened, it was laid on the desk of the other partner. When it came to be examined, it was found that instead of six the letter only contained five checks, and an inquiry was started as to what had become of the missing check. Suspicion fell upon persons in the establishment, but no trace of the check could be discovered. The letter sent by the New-York firm, informing of the loss of the check, contained two checks, and these were abstracted also, indorsements forged upon them and the money obtained from the Bank. An effort to discover the thief and forger was made by the New-York detectives, but without success, and it was not till after the arrest of TATE, the colored boy, in the office of the Company, on the charge of stealing railroad timekeepers, that Officer CALLAHAN discovered him to be the guilty agent. He obtained the two checks from the letter at the Post-office; the other check he got from a letter with which he was intrusted to take to the Post-office. -- Philadelphia Ledger, Sept. 25.
lead_paragraph: -- The checks with forged indorsements, which were passed recently at the farmers and Mechanics' Bank, were stolen from letters going from and coming to the officers of the Camden and Amboy Railroad Company. abstract: We learn that the break at HOFFMAN's is closed. Water was let in on Wednesday, and it is probable loaded boats passed that night. Yesterday morning boats were moving East and West This information we have from S.G. CHASE, Esq., of this city. abstract: Missouri is determined not to let President LINCOLN mismanage the great trust reposed by the people of the United States in his hands. After repented warnings to that eminent functionary as to the path of duty he should pursue -- after "line upon line and precept upon precept" -- "here a little and there a little" -- that State has at last invoked a mass meeting -- or a camp meeting -- to be held at Washington, for a prayerful consideration of his case. The St. Louis Democrat of Thursday says: "From seventy to eighty delegates, representing the Union men of nearly that number of counties in the State * * * left this city yesterday afternoon for Washington, by the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad. Some of the delegates from the northern part of the State have gone by way of Chicago. The President will hear the voice of ALL THE LOYALTY OF MISSOURI!" So that doubtless a round hundred of the most eloquent and loquacious of West ern political preachers will soon have our amiable but erring President by the ear. What will be his fate under the infliction we dare not think. Heaven forefend and deliver him!

abstract: Political matters are again exciting considerable attention. At our county elections this Fall, although there are nothing but county offices to fill, the probability is that party lines will be closely drawn, as between Unionists and Democrats or rather Copperheads.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Monday, Sept. 21, 1863.

abstract: The battles fought and won in the East and in the West, at the beginning of July, were followed by a period of eleven weeks in which no operations of greater importance were undertaken than those of Gen. GILLMORE in the harbor of Charleston. In that period the army of Gen. ...
lead_paragraph: The battles fought and won in the East and in the West, at the beginning of July, were followed by a period of eleven weeks in which no operations of greater importance were undertaken than those of Gen. GILLMORE in the harbor of Charleston. In that period the army of Gen. MEADE moved from Pennsylvania to the Rapidan; the army of Gen. GRANT was cut up, and detachments of it sent from Vicksburgh down and up the Mississippi; the army of Gen. ROSECRANS moved from Murfreesboro to the Tennessee River; but none of these movements were interrupted by the rebels. Our lesser armies, too, had successes and reverses, but no serious actions, if we except one. Gen. STEELE seized the capital of Arkansas; Gen. FRANKLIN was repulsed from Texas; Gen. BURNSIDE captured Knoxville and Cumberland Gap; Gen. GILLMORE, after a brisk struggle, reduced Fort Sumter and the two works on Morris Island. During these months of comparative repose, everything military looked bright and hopeful. Rebel armies defeated, strongholds captured, territory occupied, rebel lines contracted, rebel forces demoralized, and the rebel Confederacy apparently in the throes of dissolution. Our armies all strong, well planted, well led, filled with the spirit of victory, and needing only to deal a few more blows upon the enemy, and then fold up their battle-flags and contemplate the glories of the triumph achieved. The thought of defeat, the possibility of retreat, the idea that the rebellious storm, so nigh quelled, would again gather force and break in devastation over the land, entered into no man's mind, or, at all events, found no expression. Public confidence has never been as high during the war as in July, August and September of the current year; and there never was such good ground for it. It seemed as if we could almost descry the dawning of the morning of peace over a Union reconstructed, and a nation braced up and made stronger by the bloody hurricane under which it had passed. In common with all others, we saw the brightening prospect, and gave expression to the universal hope. From time to time we earnestly warned the public not to give way to over-confidence -- not to consider the struggle as over while the rebels had hundreds of thousands of men in the field and gave vent only to expressions of defiance. But as things stood a fortnight ago, we certainly considered that, if only our good fortune were maintained, the Confederacy must speedily totter to its fall.

abstract: The sale of boxes and season tickets for the coming season of Italian opera prospers so well, that it is confidently expected there will be from this source a regular subscription of several hundred dollars for each night of the first series of performances, The probable amount varies according to the particular individual connected with the Academy of Music that one happens to speak to, and his degree of hopefulness at the moment of estimating it, but there is no doubt that the subscription will be exceptional in its largeness. The boxes are eagerly subscribed for, and we hear already of parties who have procured their season seats in the balcony and parquette. The manager's golden vision of a subscription of fifteen hundred dollars a night, will, it is more than expected, be realized under Mr. MARETZEK's management, in which case we may expect to hear of a halo round that gentleman's pocket, if not of a nimbus over his head. In fact there is no reason why a large subscription should not always be secured. A good, reliable and energetic management is all that the public demands; with this and the certainty that the season will be carried out, there is no doubt that subscribers would always flock in, simply because they have the pick of the house, and are thereby greatly favored without having to pay anything extra for it. There is much confidence in Mr. MARETZEK, and although he has hardly made any stir in the way of advertising, and has only just opened his box sheet, we are not surprised to hear that the rush of subscribers is greater than was ever known before, and that from this source alone the season will be insured from disaster, and rendered one of the most brilliant on record. "Roberto Devereux" is selected for the opening night, and as the American Institute has elosed its Fair, the rehearsals will be commenced at once. We are glad to learn that Miss CLARA LOUISE KELLOGG has entirely recovered from her recent severe attack of indisposition, and will make her rentree early in the season.

abstract: The Southern Confederacy is in very much the condition of the Metropolitan theatres, under their present popular administration. There is a ghost that haunts every play, and stalks across the boards at most inopportune moments, freezing the blood of spectators, and making "each particular hair" even of the wigs in the house stand on end.
lead_paragraph: The Southern Confederacy is in very much the condition of the Metropolitan theatres, under their present popular administration. There is a ghost that haunts every play, and stalks across the boards at most inopportune moments, freezing the blood of spectators, and making "each particular hair" even of the wigs in the house stand on end. The ghost that besets the Confederacy is the "domestic traitor." He has left the graveyard for good it seems, and has been showing himself in all parts of the land, to the terror of Confederates. Corporals in conscripting meet and fear him. Generals in the field issue orders against him. Governors in council hurl anathemas upon him. Editors in poetic frenzy consign him to infernal torments. The President in his palace trembles to hear of him as he would to hear of Lucifer at large.

abstract: An immense throng assembled last evening in the Broadway Tabernacle, on the corner of Sixthavenue and Thirty-fourth street, to hear the Farewell Address of Rev. J. W. MASSIE, D.D., LL. D., of London, who, in company with Rev, Mr: RYLANOE, ...
lead_paragraph: An immense throng assembled last evening in the Broadway Tabernacle, on the corner of Sixthavenue and Thirty-fourth street, to hear the Farewell Address of Rev. J. W. MASSIE, D.D., LL. D., of London, who, in company with Rev, Mr: RYLANCE, came over to this country some months ago in the character of a special deputation, intrusted with the charge of conveying to the people of the North an address signed by more than three thousand of the Protestant clergymen of the British Islands, and by 750 of those of France, expressing their sympathy in our great struggle against the slaveholders' rebellion, and protesting against its recognition as a Government by England. At the time of Dr. MASSIE's arrival here, the papers teemed with notices of his cordial reception on all sides. Since then, he has made a very extensive tour through the Northern States with a view to judge for himself of the character of our people and their feelings in reference to the great issue now at stake. The expectation that he would, in bidding adieu, refer particularly to this journey and the impressions thence derived lent additional interest to the occasion, and long before 7 P.M., the hour fixed for the opening of the church service, the whole edifice was densely crowded, with the exception of pews upon the main aisles, some of whose occupants appeared totally indisposed to accommodate strangers -- very many aged and decrepit persons of both sexes being obliged to depart or stand during the entire service of nearly three hours' continuation, although there were seats under their gaze the access to which was inexorably closed. This, however, was the only unpleasant feature of a memorable gathering.

abstract: Gen. BURNSIDE was at Knoxville yesterday. Military authorities here say that BURNSIDE did not know of the impending battle between ROSECRANS and BRAGG, and could not have reinforced ROSECRANS if he had. The battle had been long concluded before the news reached BURNSIDE.

abstract: The steamship North Star, from Aspinwall Sept. 17, with $277,651 in treasure on board, arrived Saturday. The feud which has been existing for some time at Panama between the clergy and the Government, because of the refusal of the former to take the oath of allegiance to the new Constitution, has been settled, the priests having complied with what was demanded of them, and all the churches, which were closed while the difficulty existed, are now opened for religious services. A good deal of interest is taken in Panama in the cultivation of cotton, and tinder the fostering care of the Government it is hoped that before long the Isthmus cotton will be quoted in the markets of the United States and Europe.
lead_paragraph: The steamship North Star, from Aspinwall Sept. 17, with $277,651 in treasure on board, arrived Saturday. abstract: We are in the habit of priding ourselves upon being the people of all others in the world the most eager in pursuit of all kinds of material improvement, the readiest to adopt every new contrivance or invention or regulation which promises in the smallest degree either to promote comfort or to save labor.
lead_paragraph: We are in the habit of priding ourselves upon being the people of all others in the world the most eager in pursuit of all kinds of material improvement, the readiest to adopt every new contrivance or invention or regulation which promises in the smallest degree either to promote comfort or to save labor. And in everything which is dependent upon individual energy there is abundant evidence that our boasting is well founded. But anybody who had no better proof of it than is afforded by the management of some of our public enterprizes would be greatly amused by these pretensions. Our Post-office, for instance, as compared with that of either France or England, has been in most particulars, and is still in some, almost mediaeval in its clumsiness, slowness and uncertainty. It was the rule in the Post-office of both those countries that an unpaid letter should be forwarded to its destination in the regular course, and delivered on payment of double postage, for thirty years before this simple and effective expedient was adopted here. Until this Spring, the practice of our Post- office was the truly Turkish one of retaining the letter in the office in which it was first dropped, writing another letter to the person to whom it was addressed, requesting him to send on a stamp, waiting till his reply came, and then, having secured the stamp, and protected the revenue against all risk, forwarding the letter at last. This was in every way worthy of the Duchy of Potztausend. But there was another arrangement which was even more brilliant, and which also survived till the present year -- that by which the postage to be prepaid on all City letters was one cent, and the carrier was condemned to collect one cent more on its delivery. By this means we suppose the Government undertook to see that the expense of intramural correspondence was equally divided between the senders and receivers, but one result of it was that the carriers passed two-thirds of their time on door-steps waiting for a cent. Some genius, however, discovered that after all a great deal of labor might be saved by making the prepaid postage on City letters two cents, and as so many years passed before this contrivance was hit upon, and it must have been pretty difficult to devise, the Post-office ought to honor him with at least a bust.

abstract: There are now about nine thousand rebel prisoners at Fort Delaware. Comfortable barracks have been erected, which are used by the prisoners as well as our own men. These barracks are yellow-washed without, and whitewashed within, and are kept clean and sweet. Lime and chloride of lime are freely sprinkled about them, and there is a constant supply of fresh water from the Brandywine Creek, and steam condensers introduced lately. The hospital for prisoners and our own men contains six hundred beds. It cost the Government about $37,000, and has been occupied but a couple of weeks. An hotel and several boarding-houses will shortly be erected on the island. The chapel will be dedicated in about three weeks. It is nearly ready to be put together, and a large gang of men are at work upon it. It is thought that Bishop POTTER will officiate at the dedication. -- Philadelphia Ledger, Sept. 25.
lead_paragraph: There are now about nine thousand rebel prisoners at Fort Delaware. Comfortable barracks have been erected, which are used by the prisoners as well as our own men. These barracks are yellow-washed without, and whitewashed within, and are kept clean and sweet. Lime and chloride of lime are freely sprinkled about them, and there is a constant supply of fresh water from the Brandywine Creek, and steam condensers introduced lately. The hospital for prisoners and our own men contains six hundred beds. It cost the Government about $37,000, and has been occupied but a couple of weeks. An hotel and several boarding-houses will shortly be erected on the island. The chapel will be dedicated in about three weeks. It is nearly ready to be put together, and a large gang of men are at work upon it. It is thought that Bishop POTTER will officiate at the dedication. -- Philadelphia Ledger, Sept. 25.

abstract: The steamship Anglia, from Galway on the 15th inst., arrived at Boston on Saturday. Her news is two days later, but we are without our usual telegraphic summary, in consequence of the disarrangement of the line at St. Johns, N. F., where the Associated Press dispatches were left.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Anglia, from Galway on the 15th inst., arrived at Boston on Saturday. Her news is two days later, but we are without our usual telegraphic summary, in consequence of the disarrangement of the line at St. Johns, N. F., where the Associated Press dispatches were left. The Courrier du Harre states that the rebel steamer Alabama would probably visit Cherbourg at an early day. The seizure of the pirate Florida, at Brest, had been opposed by the maritime Prefect at that port, with the object of preserving the inviolability of the harbor as a military port. Capt. MAFFIT has written a letter to the Patric, denying the assertion made by that journal that the Florida had been seized to satisfy an indemnity claim, and explaining that his vessel was not a privateer, but a regularly commissioned ship in the navy of the Confederate States. The rebel rams were still detained in the Mersey, pending further inquiries and until fresh instructions are given respecting them. The London Post is of opinion that the bona fide character of the original order for their construction will be established, and that eventually they will be released. The news from Japan via Hong Kong shows that the anti-foreign Damios still continue hostilities. In addition to the attack on the American steamer Pembroke, the French dispatch steamer Kiluchung had been assailed by batteries and two war vessels while at anchor, and was very nearly being sunk. One of the Damios also made an attack on the Dutch man-of- war Medusai, but that vessel silenced his forts and sunk an armed brig.

abstract: It is narrated in the Newcomes that Sir Barnes Newcome, having been grossly insulted by his uncle, Col. Newcome, repaired to Gen. Sir George Tufto, to whom he expressed so bitter a regret that his relationship to the Colonel forbade him to demand satisfaction, as to fill that worthy warrior with chagrin that so gallant and spirited a gentleman should be baulked of his desire.
lead_paragraph: It is narrated in the Newcomes that Sir Barnes Newcome, having been grossly insulted by his uncle, Col. Newcome, repaired to Gen. Sir George Tufto, to whom he expressed so bitter a regret that his relationship to the Colonel forbade him to demand satisfaction, as to fill that worthy warrior with chagrin that so gallant and spirited a gentleman should be baulked of his desire. It chanced, however, that Mr. Clive Newcome heard of the disappointment of Sir Barnes, and straightway addressed a note to that fiery baronet, offering to gratify him at once. But when Sir George hastened to congratulate Sir Barnes on this unexpected opportunity, he found that that gentleman's appetite for blood-letting had been suddenly appeased. After striving in vain to bring his man to the scratch, Sir George quitted him in disgust, and, repairing to Bay's Club, did not hesitate to express the conviction that Sir Barnes was afraid to fight -- an opinion in which all who heard his story readily concurred.

abstract: We have one day's later news from Europe by the arrival at this port, yesterday, of the steamship America. There is nothing particularly striking in the advices. For the Paris papers the presence of the Florida at Brest continued a theme of apparently absorbing interest. It is asserted by these journals that two Federal men-of-war are on their way to blockade the harbor and catch her as she goes out. In this very desirable object, however, they are likely to be failed, if the assertion be true that the wily Capt. MAFFIT intended to abandon his famous vessel at Brest and take command of another pirate at Liverpool, whither it was rumored the new craft had already been joined by the greater part of the Florida's crew. The French Government, it was understood, would not permit the seizure of the Florida to satisfy the [???] claims against her so long as she remained in the dockyard of the imperial navy. One of the rams built by the Messrs. LAIRD had been towed to the Morpeth Ironworks to receive her finishing touches, when she would be ready for a trial trip. The Russian Government had replied to the last French note concerning the Polish question in a very conciliatory tone -- Prince GORTSCHAKOFF confining himself simply to a discussion of the expediency or applying the measures claimed on behalf of Poland by the three great Powers. The statement that Prince METTERNICH had assured the French Government of Austria's unconditional alliance with France in the Polish question, even to the extent of war with Russia, had been semi-officially denied. The British Government has determined, in consequence of the recent troubles at Japan, to largely augment its military force in China. The Liverpool cotton market was excited, and long-stapled descriptions had advanced 1/2c.@1c. [???] lb. [???] had declined. Consols were quoted at [???] for money and 92[???] for Oct. 8.

abstract: Brig.-Gen. CHAS. K. GRAHAM, of whose military career as an officer of the Excelsior Brigade a detailed notice was given in yesterday's TIMES, arrived in this City yesterday, having left the Libby prison at ...
lead_paragraph: Brig.-Gen. CHAS. K. GRAHAM, of whose military career as an officer of the Excelsior Brigade a detailed notice was given in yesterday's TIMES, arrived in this City yesterday, having left the Libby prison at Richmond on Tuesday last. His numerous friends in this City being desirous of giving him a reception befitting his gallant services, and the sufferings he has endured in the cause of his country, arrangements were made for them to proceed in a steamboat to Amboy to receive him on the arrival of the train from Philadelphia, and convey him to the City. Surveyor ANDREWS, a warm personal friend of Gen. GRAHAM, on hearing of the proposed action, immediately tendered the use of the United States barge Addison F. Andrews, and at 11 o'clock yesterday morning a party of one hundred gentlemen, more or less, embarked for the trip, at the foot of Whitehall-street. The barge was under command of Capt. FAUNCE, formerly of the Harriet Lane. Among the party were Surveyor Andrews, James T. Brady, Judge Hilton, of the Common Pleas; Ex-Alderman Dayton, Judge Elias J. Beach, Alex. D. Munson, Chairman of the Committee of reception; Judge Van Cott, Judge Stewart, J.M. Motley, Gen. Thomas Francis Meagher, Col. Hamlin, of the Third regiment Regulars, son of the Vice President of the United States, Capt. Wm. H. Farrar and Lieut. George M. Dusenbury, of the Thirty-seventh New-York Volunteers; Capt. Woodward, of the Third army corps; Capt. Street, of the Twentieth Indian regiment; S.J. Strong, Assist. Postmaster; Alex. Isaacs, and Thos. J. Brown, Deputy Surveyors, and many others, of more or less note. Before leaving the wharf the Committee of arrangements ascertained by telegraph that Gen. GRAHAM was coming by the New-Jersey Railroad, and would arrive in Jersey City instead of Amboy. This necessitated a change in the programme, which proved to be a very agreeable change to all concerned, for it gave the party an opportunity to take a sail around the battery and view the Russian fleet lying at anchor in the North River, while waiting the arrival of the cars at Jersey City. Each of the vessels of the fleet was visited in turn and greeted with rousing cheers from the party, which were cordially responded to from the Russian decks. After calling upon each member of the fleet, and calling three times round the flag-ship of Rear-Admiral LASOF[???]KY, the Andrews turned her prow toward the Jersey docks. Gen. GRAHAM had already arrived at the depot, where he was met by Mr. MUNSON, Judge HILTON, Judge BEACH, and JAS T. BRADY, and escorted on board the Andrews. The General was accompanied by Mrs. GRAHAM, who met her husband at Fortress Monroe, and to whose perseverance and energy his early exchange and release from the rebel prison is mainly due. As the General came on board, he was welcomed with the most enthusiastic and prolonged cheers from his friends, the band meanwhile playing "Hail to the Chief." The boat was immediately headed cown the bay, and before Gen. GRAHAM and his lady had got through receiving the congratulations of their friends, the party found themselves passing through the Narrows and out into the open sea. The bright sunshine, the placid waters of the ocean, which was as calm and smooth as a lake, and the general enjoyment of the scene by all on board, to which the harmonious strains of the Seventh regiment band greatly contributed, tempting the Committee to prolong the sail, and the pilot was directed to round the light-ship oil Sandy Hook. Just as this had been accomplished, a dense volume of black smoke was descried in the Eastern horizon, which the Revenue officers on hoard conjectured came from the steamer City of Washington, just row due here from Liverpool. The Andrews was directed to steer for her, and after an hour's sail, encountered the craft, which proved to be the French naval steam frigate C[???]reur. On drawing near the frigate the [???] st[???]uck up the "Marseliaise." which was responded to by the frigate's band playing the "Star Spargled Ban[???]." The Emperor NAPOLEON's favorite National air was also played by the Seventh regiment band, and several rounds of cheers were interchanged between the Andrews and the Coureur: though it is worthy of rem[???] that the Yankee cheers were much less spontaneous and ne[???]rty than those which greeted the Russian fleet at the outset of the excursion. After paying all the respect to the new French visitor [???] the party thought she deserved, the Andrews was i[???]led for the Narrows, and soon felt the Coureur far in her stern. On the return trip an ce[???]ent [???]tion was spread out on the main deck, and all hands proceeded to enjoy it with a relish which a se[???] p[???]etite alone can give. At the close of [???]re; JAMES T. BRADY, Esq., was agreed upon, and in all ch[???]t and touching speech, filled with re[???] of his early acquaintance with Gen. GRAHAM, and with his father and his two brothers, THOMAS and DAVID GRAHAM, tendered [???]m a hearty we come home to his friends. He closed by proposing the health of Gen. GRAHAM.

abstract: It must be obvious to every intelligent watcher of military affairs that a fundamental change in the whole war programme is now taking place--a change more radical, more complete than any of the shiftings we have hitherto had on the great chess-board. The
lead_paragraph: It must be obvious to every intelligent watcher of military affairs that a fundamental change in the whole war programme is now taking place -- a change more radical, more complete than any of the shiftings we have hitherto had on the great chess-board. The effect of this, in the gross and scope, is to transfer the main weight and interest of the war from the wings of our long line of operations to the centre in Southeastern Tennessee. In that region both we and the rebels are bending every energy to mass two great armies, which must henceforth become the cynosure of all eyes. A battle, which will make all the previous battles of the war secondary, must ere long take place there. On that battle, in a great measure, hangs the issue of the war, for both the magnitude of the proportions of the contending forces, and the strategic relations of the theatre of war, conspire to give a decisive character to the coming contest. If a victory shall crown the Union arms, nothing can be imagined to stop their conquering, onward march. If, on the other hand, ROSECRANS should be defeated, the defeat must be under circumstances that would make it ruin to him and open up for the country a vista which need not be contemplated in advance.

abstract: One of the interesting musical events of the season is the competition in instruments, and the success that has attended the exhibition of BRADBURY's piano-fortes at the several Fairs recently held. This success is the more remarkable from the fact that a new competitor for public favor has always to contend with the prejudices of those who are interested in keeping their old favorites in the front rank, and it is only when the intrinsic merits of a new instrument are so apparent as to render opposition to it hazardous to their professional reputation, that it can get a fair start.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met yesterday and adopted further resolutions of compliment to the Russian naval officers whose vessels now lie in the harbor, the present resolutions tendering the hospitalities of the City to the Admiral and the officers who arrived here with him since courtesies were voted to the officers of the frigate Osliaba. A message was received from the Mayor
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met yesterday and adopted further resolutions of compliment to the Russian naval officers whose vessels now lie in the harbor, the present resolutions tendering the hospitalities of the City to the Admiral and the officers who arrived here with him since courtesies were voted to the officers of the frigate Osliaba. A message was received from the Mayor vetoing the resolution instructing the Corporation Counsel to have the injunction upon the Comptroller and Mayor, restraining them from acting under the Common Council draft ordinance, dissolved. Mr. FROMENT was surprised that the Mayor should re-present his views upon the ordinance as his reasons for the veto, and yet say nothing about his having acted illegally with the Supervisors in passing a similar ordinance. The Board adjourned to Thursday.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. PRICE FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports. Items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; am marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The desire to buy good pictures is fortunately so far ahead of the desire to see them, that speculators, who have lost all faith in the public, still continue to import masterpieces for the sake of the few. This is especially true of the proprietors of the Derby Gallery, No. 625 Broadway. Only a few months ago they were compelled to sell off a superb collection of paintings of the modern school of German art, simply because the public seemed to have lost all interest in the artists thus represented. The pictures, however, brought exceedingly good prices, and hence the proprietors have imported a new lot, and with a degree of success which we hardly thought could be attained. The collection of paintings by Dusseldorff, French and Belgian artists, which was exhibited last night for the first time, in the rooms of the Derby Gallery, is really one of the most meritorious exhibitions that we have had in this City for many years. Not only are the best masters represented, but many of the newest and most promising men of to-day are introduced to our public for the first time. We shall take another opportunity of referring to the principal features of the exhibition. In the meantime we advise all lovers of art to spend an hour or so at the Derby Gallery.

abstract: Bammill and Ward champion boat-race at Poughkeepsie
snippet: Bammill and Ward champion boat-race at Poughkeepsie
lead_paragraph: The five-mile boat race between JAMES HAMMILL, of Pittsburgh, Pa., and JAMES WARD, of Cornwall, N.Y., took place yesterday at Poughkeepsie in presence of between 20,000 and 30,000 spectrators, who lined the banks of the Hudson, a few being a[???]oat on a tug, and a few row-boats. A large number went up from New-York on the tow-boat Stevens on Sunday, and also on the Hudson River Railroad by the early trains from New-York and the river towns; besides, many lovers of aquatics from Canada, Boston, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and other places, who naturally felt great interest in the result of an event which was to furnish a suitable antagonist for the great English champion of the waters, ROBERT CHAMBERS, of Newcastle, England. It was broadly asserted by the Poughkeepsians, Newburghers and Cornwa[???]ians that if -- as they confidently believed he would do -- JOSHUA WARD beat HAMMILL, he would certainly challenge ROBERT CHAMBERS, the English champion.

abstract: The award of the first premium over all competition to the Grover & Baker sewing-machines at the Kentucky State Fair, held last week at Louisville, adds another to the many victories which these machines have achieved this year. abstract: To-day is the twenty-first anniversary of the Order of the Sons of Temperance. It has but just come of age, and yet already has over 1,250,000 men, women and children in its healthful care. The anniversary will be celebrated in every city and village in the United States where the Order has an existence; in some by processions, meetings, balls and other festivities. In this City there will be a public meeting this evening Cooper Institute, whereat some of the most eloquent speakers of the Order are expected to be present, among them S.L. Tilley, P.M.W.P. and Provincial Secretary of New-Brunswick; E. Carswell, M.W.C., the great Canadian orator; Benjamin E. Gantt, P.G.W.P., of Maryland; Rev. P.L. Cuvler, P.G.W.P., and others. S.L. Carleton, M.W.P., of Maine, will preside. Mr. CARSWELL, one of the gentlemen above named, is considered by many quite the equal of Mr. GOUGH.

abstract: FREDERICK AT  HOCHKIRCH. Military critics, whose experience entitles their opinions to weight, have considered ROSECRANS the most military General ...
lead_paragraph: -- FREDERICK AT HOCHKIRCH. -- Military critics, whose experience entitles their opinions to weight, have considered ROSECRANS the most military General that we have. His conduct throughout this war, especially his manipulation of his troops, prove that he understands his business professionally. His conduct in this last battle so nearly resembles that of FREDERICK the Great at Hochkirch that it is worth while to signalize roughly the comparison. Maj.-Gen. THOMAS likewise played his part with as much zeal, discretion and courage as FREDERICK's Lieutenant-General, DE ZIETHER, whose prescience and intrepidity saved the Prussians from a greater disaster. DAUN had 90,000 men, FREDERICK 43,000. The former took advantage of FREDERICK's confidence to deal him a "malicious blow." He attacked him by surprise, Oct. 14, 1758, in a mountain region, and, with a loss of about 6,000 men and five Major-Generals, (just the number the rebels are reported to have had killed,) drove him from his position, with a loss of 9,000 men and 101 cannon. Yet, notwithstanding, the King made such a magnificent retreat that the Austrians did not dare to renew their attack. In a few days the Prussian army was as formidable as before the battle. Such, too, was FREDERICK's vigor and activity, that, despite this reverse and its attendant consequences, he was able to raise the siege of Neisse, drive the Austrians out of Silesia, relieve Dresden, besieged by the victorious DAUN in person, and force him to fall back across his own (the Austrian) boundaries. With this analogy to FREDERICK, let us see if ROSECRANS can emulate his after energy.

abstract: Sons of Temperance Visit the President; Twenty-first Anniversary in New-York
snippet: Sons of Temperance Visit the President; Twenty-first Anniversary in New-York
lead_paragraph: The programme accompanying the announcement that the Sons of Temperance would meet at the Cooper Institute last evening, to celebrate their twenty-first anniversary, attracted thither a concourse of people sufficient to fill the Hall to its utmost capacity. Not only were all the seats occupied, but every standing place in the aisles was appropriated. By far the larger portion of the audience was composed of ladies. Members of the various lodges were present, decorated with the emblems and honorary insignia of the Order. The officers and speakers, on coming upon the stage, were loudly applauded. The exercises were opened by singing the song. "Thrice Welcome, Brothers," after which an eloquent and impressive prayer was offered by Rev. Mr. TEMPLE, of New-Brunswick. The Chairman for the evening, Mr. S.L. CARLETON, M.W.P., of Maine, thanking the audience for the honor they had done him in selecting him as their presiding officer, indulged in some reminiscences connected with the Society at the period of its earliest existence -- of the one who, now no more, first presided over their deliberations, and who, he said, was ever faithful to their glorious motto. "Love, Purity and Fidelity," after which he introduced the Union Glee Club, who sang "Come, till your goblets," a song which the audience, by their hearty cheering, seemed fully to appreciate. A compilation from the records of the National Division, giving the number of lodges now and at different former periods, and the prospects of the Order for the future, together with a statement of some of the benefits already flowing from it, was read by Mr. STEARNS, at the close of which reading another song, "Our Glorious Order," was sung by the Club, many of the audience joining in the chorus. After a few pertinent remarks by an old member of the Order, Rev. Mr. LATHROP, of Connecticut. Mr. BARNUM, who had been alluded to by the Chairman as one of the many good things that they had at their anniversary, responded to the loud calls of the audience, and made a few humorous and characteristic remarks, declaring that he was the great showman showing himself, as he had not arisen to make a speech, but only because there might be some in the audience who had never "seen BARNUM." He was followed by Rev. THEODORE L. CUYLER, whose speech was brief and to the point, abounding in illustration and sentiment, and concluding with an eloquent and touching allusion to the present unhappy condition of our country, imploring his countrymen, each and all not to give up the old ship. The concluding speech was made by Mr. CARSWELL, of Canada West. His speech abounded in anecdote and illustration and was loudly applauded by the audience. He thanked the people of the United States for sending the red, white and blue, in the form of their badges to Canada, where many lodges had been established. He closed his remarks by declaring that Canadians were not all Secessionists, that the bone and sinew of the country were sympathizers with our Government in its attempts to crush the rebellion, that many had come from Canada to join our armies and fight for the Union, and that thousands would rejoice when our efforts should be crowned with success. The Glee Club then sang medley, and the assembly dispersed.

abstract: Our Summer victories over the rebels produced, to some extent, the same effect in Europe that they did in this country. They increased the fame of the Union armies, magnified the National power, elevated the National prospects, and strengthened the general faith in our ultimate success. They showed the instability of the Confederacy, and its mili  tary as well as its political failure they depressed ...
lead_paragraph: Our Summer victories over the rebels produced, to some extent, the same effect in Europe that they did in this country. They increased the fame of the Union armies, magnified the National power, elevated the National prospects, and strengthened the general faith in our ultimate success. They showed the instability of the Confederacy, and its mili tary as well as its political failure -- they depressed the Confederate loan, and changed the exultation of Confederate sympathizers into despair. Those who sustained the Confederacy because of its successful display of power, now sustained the Union, because it showed itself possessed of still greater power. Those who had been against us because they thought the job we had undertaken an impossible one, now turned in our favor when they saw that it was not only possible but well nigh accomplishment. Those who were demanding the immediate recognition of the Confederacy, were now willing to wait and see whether the Confederacy would remain in condition to be recognized. Judging from the tone of the English Press, and by private letters, we should say that the Union cause never stood so well abroad, as the United States certainly were never treated with so much fairness, as during the three months past. It is true that we have had the ram controversy with England; but the rams were contracted for and mainly built before the close of July, and even in this matter the English Government, by latest advices, seems disposed to deal justly.

abstract: The great Union Ratification Meeting takes place at Cooper Institute this evening, and all loyal men, without distinction of party, are expected to be present. It will undoubtedly be an immense demonstration of fidelity to the country, and to the Government. Very many prominent speakers will be present. The large hall and the stands outside will be plentifully and satisfactorily supplied with them. Let there be a general rally and such a demonstration as will give renewed assurance of the "good time coming," in November, when the Union vote will sweep the State by its thousands of majority.
