abstract: The arrival of the steamship Arago, from Charleston Bar on the morning of the 26th inst., puts us in possession of our correspondence from Morris Island and Port Royal to that date. Our troops on Morris Island still continued most sedulously engaged in the construction of batteries and mounting of siege guns, with the object of attacking Charleston.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of the steamship Arago, from Charleston Bar on the morning of the 26th inst., puts us in possession of our correspondence from Morris Island and Port Royal to that date. Our troops on Morris Island still continued most sedulously engaged in the construction of batteries and mounting of siege guns, with the object of attacking Charleston. The prosecution of this work, though not seriously retarded, was yet difficult of accomplishment on account of the severe fire to which the working parties are subjected by the batteries on James and Sullivan's Islands. The naval vessels still maintained a position of dignified inactivity, having failed to make an offensive movement since the attack on Fort Moultrie and the Sullivan Island batteries three weeks ago, and the damage inflicted upon that occasion is likely ere this to have been thoroughly repaired. There had been great rejoicing in the Department of the South at the news of Gen. GILLMORE's promotion to the double stars of a Major-General.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship City of Washington from Liverpool on the 16th inst. and Queenstown on the 17th, we have one day's later news from Europe. Our files furnish us with additional news of interest. It now appears that that the Florida's crew, instead of being paid off ...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship City of Washington from Liverpool on the 16th inst. and Queenstown on the 17th, we have one day's later news from Europe. Our files furnish us with additional news of interest. It now appears that that the Florida's crew, instead of being paid off at Brest and going to Liverpool to join a new pirate vessel, deserted MAFFIT in dudgeon because of his failure to pay them. The Post states that they are both indignant and destitute, and threaten vengeance. The London Star's Paris correspondence announces the rumored recognition of the South by the Mexican Emperor in obedience to the behests of LOUIS NAPOLEON. There is little change in Commercial and Financial matters to note.

abstract: There appears to be little doubt that ROSECRANS' check has been due to his being assailed by a vastly superior force, and this superiority of force the rebels owed, as we now know, to the facility with which they are able to hurry troops from one point of their frontier to another in other words, to their possession of what is now so well known to the ...
lead_paragraph: There appears to be little doubt that ROSECRANS' check has been due to his being assailed by a vastly superior force, and this superiority of force the rebels owed, as we now know, to the facility with which they are able to hurry troops from one point of their frontier to another -- in other words, to their possession of what is now so well known to the public as "interior lines." He started from Murfreesboro with several weighty disadvantages, which grew in magnitude as he progressed. He was penetrating a difficult country, and that country the enemy's; he was far from his base of supplies, and in case of reverse had to look hundreds of miles for succor or shelter. In short, he was an invader, and an invader who had every reason to expect a tenacious resistance, all the more tenacious the further he penetrated. There was, therefore, every conceivable reason for his advancing in at least as strong force as any that there was even a possibility of his finding opposed to him on the road. In fact, all the rules that the military experience of ages has prescribed for the conduct of invasions required that he should have run no risk of encountering any body of troops superior to his own.

abstract: The season at this establishment commences to-night, and with it the fashionable world will enter upon its genuine and Metropolitan round of amusement for the Winter. Mr. WALLACK has made ample and splended preparations for his patrons. He opens with a new play, and a house that has been completely renovated, regilt and redecorated. The scenery, dresses and appointments for the play, which is called "Rosedale, or the Rifle Ball," are entirely new, and will be on the liberal scale for which this house has become famous. That the patrons of the establishment are not behind hand is proved by the fact that the box-office, which opened on Monday morning at 8 o'clock, had to close at 10. In the short space of two hours every seat and box in the house had been sold out. Every one will, of course, be present to-night, and simply as an exhibition of brilliant and fashionable people, it will be an agreeable treat to a looker on.

abstract: The Morning Star, Capt. J.M. COURTENAY, arrived at her wharf at an early hour yesterday, having left New-Orleans on the 22d, at 9 A.M. The bar pilot who brought the Morning Star out of Southwest Pass, reported that the small tug Leviathan, then lying under the guns of the De Soto, was boarded the night before (Sept. 21) by a party of men who came out in a small boat from shore, took possession of the tug and carried her out to sea. Two or three gunboats were lying by when the tug was taken, but the loss was not discovered till the Leviathan was several miles out in the Gulf. At daylight the De Solo signaled one of the other gunboats, and both put out for the tug. They overhauled her 20 miles out, captured her and brought her back, with all on board, to the Pass. The men who attempted to "confiscate" the tug were brought back in irons.
lead_paragraph: The Morning Star, Capt. J.M. COURTENAY, arrived at her wharf at an early hour yesterday, having left New-Orleans on the 22d, at 9 A.M. abstract: at New-York
lead_paragraph: The Russian Squadron of five vessels, now lying in the mouth of the North River, carry about 170 guns, and are manned by about 2,400 men. There is no distinctive class known as marines in the Russian navy; but every man on board a Russian vessel-of-war is taught and drilled in the use of a musket, as well as in the use of the ship's guns, or in the special duties of seagoing. A Russian naval squadron goes always prepared to make a descent on land, to assault and carry a fort by storm, or do any other work that a land force may attempt. It will be perceived, therefore, that our present visitors compose an efficient and formidable force, quite able to take care of themselves under any contingencies likely to happen to them.

lead_paragraph: A most unwonted and curious incident signalized the celebration of Michaelmas in Trinity Church, yesterday. The peculiar novelty of the occasion consisted in the presence of the Chaplain of the Russian flagship, Alexander Nevsky. This gentleman is a fine specimen of the genuine Russian "Pope," or "Papa," to whom some so singularly apply the Spanish title of "padre," the latter word indeed meaning the same thing, but not exactly fitting the Russian tongue. The festival of St. Michael and of all Angels is one of those most reverenced in the Greek Catholic Church, and the worthy "Papa" saw fit to observe it in an Episcopalian cathedral, which he did with every semblance of intense curiosity, interest and devotion. He was received with distinction and conducted to a conspicuous and comfortable seat near the altar, on the right side of which sat the Rt. Reverend Bishop SOUTHGATE, in the ceremonial Chair of the Episcopate.
